urn:contentItem:5JC7-M1X1-DY0W-42XJ-00000-00White House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks2011-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:58ZLexisNexisWhite House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake RocksLanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST: You know, who won the football game last night, Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: This Sunday night game, I don't. I went to the Jets game yesterday, they won, 38-7. But you know that already.

IMUS: Yes, I don't care about the Jets game because they were already in the playoffs. So I don't care about the Seattle Seahawks and the Rams people, but I'll find out apparently from Warner.

MCSHANE: So one of them with - record made the playoffs. I'm being told in my ear, you want to know who won now or no?

IMUS: No, let me find out from Warner, because, Warner likes to tell me stuff like that.

MCSHANE: It is Warner's job.

IMUS: Santa brought us a goofy tie? Is that what happened?

MCSHANE: No, I had that one already, I-man.

IMUS: The funny tie, under the tree.

MCSHANE: So you got two weeks off and that is the best you could come up with.

IMUS: That's all I could come up with.

MCSHANE: You sound great, by the way. How this is voice, good?

IMUS: Well, I don't have throat cancer, they tell me, but I do have -- pre-cancerous cells.

MCSHANE: Really?

IMUS: Yes --and, like if you had a colonoscopy and they find this -- remove them, so, these are -- they have to take them off with a laser here in a couple of weeks, and this is way too much information.

MCSHANE: I actually care. I told you, I care.

IMUS: I'll be fine.

MCSHANE: You will be OK, that is the main point.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, and Mary Matalin coming up this morning. Three new radio affiliates - have you even seen that guy who does the red eye thing here on Fox.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Is he any good.

MCSHANE: Yes, sure. It's fine. I don't watch it. It is on in the middle of the night, but a lot of people like it.

IMUS: I saw him on the news with Megyn Kelly and -- too happy to suit me, but he seemed funny.

MCSHANE: He is pretty funny.

IMUS: I wonder if we should have him on.

MCSHANE: Sure, why not. Give it a try.

IMUS: Is he any good? He is good. You are saying that because we're on - - on TV, here, aren't you.

MCSHANE: That is why, yes.

IMUS: What is going on with business -- how this is Facebook deal, Goldman Sachs.

MCSHANE: Yes, $50 billion valuation on Facebook. It's no joke right there.

IMUS: Please.

MCSHANE: That's what Goldman thinks it's worth anyway. I will get to that in a second, but thank you, I-man and good morning. First, let's bring up the markets and look up some numbers here because stocks are starting off the new week and the New Year with some gains here globally.

China showed manufacturing slipped for the first time in five months and if anything that's actually easing concerns about inflation and the Chinese market at the bottom screen is up 1-3/4 percent overnight.

Markets in Hong Kong and South Korea are also up, and Japan has not resumed trading yet in the New Year. Over in Europe, London is closed today for the New Year's holiday, but Paris and Frankfurt are both up significantly, Paris by more than 2 percent and our futures indicating a higher open on Wall Street as well up by 76 points on Dow futures, pretty good numbers.

Now as for the major indexes and how they fared in 2010, the Dow gained 11 percent, S&P 13 percent, the Nasdaq the best performer of the bunch, 17 percent gain.

The White House wants Congress to let the federal government take on more debt national debt is getting closer to the $14.3 trillion ceiling and the White House Council of Economic Advisors, Chairman Austin Goolsbee on ABC's "This Week" saying it's crucial the ceiling is raised.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AUSTIN GOOLSBEE, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISORS: This is not a game, you know, the debt ceiling is not something to toy with. That is the -- if we hit the debt ceiling, that is the -- essentially defaulting on our obligations, which is unprecedented in American history. The impact on the economy would be catastrophic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Many Republicans agree it does need to be raised but, many of them are also saying they will not go along with it unless they get promises to change Washington's spending habits and argue there is no point in having a debt ceiling if they raise it every time the national debt gets close. Now here's the story that the I-man was referring to a moment ago.

Goldman Sachs investing $450 million in Facebook, according to the "New York Times." A Russian company also buying $50 million worth of Facebook's stock. "The Times" says these deals value Facebook at $50 billion. Now, as we have reported the FCC now looking into secondary market trading at Facebook's privately held shares.

Expedia dropping American Airlines fares from its web site, the latest development in the conflict between airlines and online travel agencies, since American cut ties with Orbitz, the airline says Expedia intentionally listed its flights and schedules lower in search results. American is looking to push consumers to buy tickets on its own web site and every effort to save money. Expedia says the move will only cost them ticket sales and believes Americans' efforts are bad for travellers.

All right, let's take a live look now at commodities this morning. The oil price is above $92 per barrel and gold is down by a dollar per ounce.

Coming up, a little bit later on in the hour, Bo Dietl will be the I-man's guest as IMUS IN THE MORNING does get started, right now, Fox Business, power to prosper.

IMUS: Warner, who won the football game last night?

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Seahawks, man, they finished 7-9. Win the division and are in the playoffs.

IMUS: So the giants, who are 10-6, they are not in the playoffs.

WOLF: You got it. No, you have to change the rule.

CHARLES MCCORD, NEWSMAN: That is crazy.

WOLF: Absurd, yes.

IMUS: I will whip somebody's butt over there -- Charles and I.

WOLF: Now you're talking.

IMUS: Charles and me, yes. And, I get my grammar screwed up. Happy New Year, everybody.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Shucks.

IMUS: Bring you up on my medical, last time --

MCCORD: Let's have the latest.

IMUS: I'm had a biopsy -- let me say this about Mt. Sinai. It is a great hospital. You know, I'm a big fan of Hackensack and Cornell and Mt. Sinai is a great hospital. The nurses are unbelievable and Dr. Peekaboo Woo, and Dr. Allen Reid, the anesthesiologist, are fabulous.

MCCORD: Good.

IMUS: They all did a great job and I apparently do not have throat cancer. What I have are these pre-cancerous cells.

MCCORD: Dysplasia, yes.

IMUS: Yes. Charles knows more about what I have than I do.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: So, they have to remove them with a laser, and, at a high level, and they would develop into --

MCCORD: Get rid of them, that is why we get rid of them.

IMUS: And you know how I got them? Smoking.

MCCORD: Really? That is what they say? OK.

IMUS: I haven't smoked for 15 years, but -

MCCORD: Listen to that, ladies and gentlemen.

IMUS: Anyway, so I'm fine, Bo Dietl, Jerry Greenfield.

MCCORD: That's great news to start the new year.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, still have prostate cancer but, I think I do. I'm not sure anymore whether I do or not.

MCCORD: Yes, may have defeated that.

IMUS: And, I came back from the ranch on Saturday.

MCCORDs: That's 700 miles an hour with the freaking tail wind.

IMUS: What a great vacation. It's 10 degrees. We have to go out there, because we run the place. It's 10 degrees -- the wind - there's not a ski resort.

MCCORD: How about that wind?

IMUS: The wind blows and I'm not exaggerating, 60 miles an hour. Anyway, Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, Mary Matalin, coming up and we have three new radio affiliates, and when I put my glasses on I'll tell you who they are.

I'm not going to do it now and, ratings came out in New York and for people -- the ratings are broken down, all kinds of demographics and I don't believe in them but I think they give you a rough idea, of you know - - I mean, you can -- like lit-fm or one of those -- hot 97 or one of these. Whoever these stations are, that do well.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And if it is consistent over a long period of time, like when stern was on terrestrial radio, you knew he was number one, and had been on a long time, a trend that remains supported, consistency.

IMUS: So, but on these 12-plus numbers they measure people by demographics like break it down to 12 to 18, 25-54, 18-34, it is ridiculous. Men, women, all of this and there's another one they do and it is just everybody who is 12 years of age or older. And, this program, the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, is the number 2 program in New York.

MCGUIRK: Get out of town!

MCCORD: Shut the front door!

IMUS: Now, of course, I told Connell and Dagen that part of that, because, they are about the only new thing we have done here, other than I have a better attitude. They were partly responsible for that and then I got to thinking about it and if it weren't for them, we could have easily been number one.

MCCORD: Number one. Yes.

MCSHANE: I'm sorry, I-man.

IMUS: Which is the reason, when I got fired, and got the job at ABC I insisted on bringing Lou and Bernie, and Charles and everybody else, because, I knew without them, I would just be -- if it weren't for them, I would be on some station, in Jersey with Uncle Floyd.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Uncle Floyd!

IMUS: I'd be on Sirius satellite radio. Mel likes me, to give me a job for 50 grand a year. And sit there -

RUFINO: At UHF --

IMUS: The I-man's blues channel, Blues and alternate country on Sirius. But, as it is -- so the show -- I've never been number 2, ever. Not back when --

MCCORD: Your best ratings.

IMUS: Not back when I was. So I'm happy about that and it is a great program. It's a better program than it ever was. Having very little to do -- not being self-effacing, having we little to do with me, Bernie, Lou, they are all great. Time for a little news and here with that is Chuck McCord. Good morning, Charles.

MCCORD: Good morning, I-man. Speaking of the weather, the main highway between southern and central California, shut down, both directions, blowing snow and ice from another big storm. The grapevine area of I-5 closed indefinitely, winds gusting to -- reminded me, winds, gusting to 90 miles per hour in mountain areas, and still accumulating at elevations, as low as just 1,500 feet.

President Obama, says he is honored to sign the bill to provide aid to survivors of the 9/11 attacks, and first responders, all of whom --

IMUS: You know --

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: "The New York Times" did an article about the stuff that Jon Stewart, who as you know, I like, stuff Jon Stewart did about the 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: I saw it and all of that.

IMUS: And wondering if Jon Stewart was under Edward R. Murrow, which I would hope even Jon Stewart would be embarrassed about. But perhaps he's not or we don't know because I don't know him, but I would suggest -- and it has nothing do with anything, but until Shep Smith went on the rant that he went on, as a result of seeing Jon Stewart's show, which Shep said he did, and -- hey, big foot --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, sir.

IMUS: There's the famous rap that Shep Smith did, he was talking to somebody, and he referenced Jon Stewart, and he had seen the Jon Stewart show apparently the night before, there's got to be a way to find that, right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, we'll find it.

IMUS: He was -- first of all, they are both terrific, both Stewart and Shep Smith is magnificent. Few better, in fact -- I don't know if there is anybody better, but it was a respond -- did you site, Bernie.

MCGUIRK: Yes. I did --

IMUS: Am I right?

MCGUIRK: On the money, a 100 percent.

IMUS: He was absolutely spectacular.

MCGUIRK: I happened to see that.

IMUS: And it seemed to me it was spontaneous.

MCGUIRK: Certainly seemed that way.

IMUS: And the boy seemed to be articulate to me and I have to play it for you. So I think that if you are a bunch of Republicans, I -- remember I had John Thune on and he was giving me some nonsense about -- didn't wanted to rush into it.

I didn't press him hard on that, not as much as I should have, and, you know, the -- I started to say to him, you know, don't want to rush into anything and, I hope we get it before all of these people die. So, people like Senator Thune, who I am no longer supporting for anything --

MCGUIRK: That may be premature. The Republicans -- they ended up saving $3 billion from that particular bill. That is what they were holding out for, eliminate --

IMUS: They weren't going to do it until they got shamed into it by Jon Stewart and by Shep Smith, I'm saying. And when Shep Smith attacked them, I'm sure they were thinking, that is our home boy there, at Fox.

I mean, I'm sure in their minds they are thinking if we lost Shep Smith we lost the country. You would expect Jon Stewart. I thought it was magnificent what he did, by the way, but you expect him to do what he did but you wouldn't expect Shep Smith to do what he did and if you lose him you lost everybody. I mean, I'm sure they are thinking that and go that the scared into passing it, didn't they, Bernie, talking about the money they saved, because you carry water for them.

MCGUIRK: That's the fact. Chuck Schumer's bill was $7 billion and, the bill ended up being $4 billion and they saved --

IMUS: But they wouldn't have done anything, had there not been those two events, am I right.

MCGUIRK: Perhaps, there's no way to conclusively prove that, but it sure seems that way.

IMUS: And let me ask you this, for everybody who thinks, Sarah Palin is a moron, and I would be one of them, would you would this country be any worse off today if she were president? Answer me that. Tell me. I'm waiting --

MCGUIRK: Checkmate for the I-man.

MCCORD: There you go.

IMUS: Because, at least -- think whatever you want to think about her, and think as I do, maybe, even. I don't know that I think she is a moron but she'd have sense enough to at least ask the people rather than get the same people bush had. But, this dope has been doing -- I mean, is he still on vacation in Hawaii, by the way?

MCCORD: Yes. He comes back I think late today.

IMUS: And then, on I-25, out there in Santa Fe, when you go up to the ranch into Santa Fe, before you get into Santa Fe, there was a guy has a houses -- a lot of people have houses, a guy has a house, puts up these goofy billboards, a homemade billboard.

And, makes me laugh every time, they change and he's obviously a Hannity devotee or one of them and once he has had up there for a while. Where is the birth certificate? The hand lettered dopey sign, where is the birth certificate. Here's my question -- where is it? I mean, I'm not a -- obviously I'm not one of those --

MCGUIRK: A birther?

IMUS: Of course not. But, where is it?

MCCORD: I don't know.

IMUS: Isn't the governor of ha walkers wasn't he screaming all about it?

MCGUIRK: He's claiming --

IMUS: Where is it?

MCGUIRK: Yes, let's see it. Clear this up.

IMUS: I mean, if the guy who is supporting the president -- which I would tend to support him, too, by the way. But I just say.

MCCORD: Let's resolve this.

IMUS: Why haven't we ever seen it or why don't they produce it, I can't answer that.

IMUS: It just adds fuel to these nuts.

MCCORD: Of course it does.

IMUS: Anyway, 16 after the hour, taking way too much time with my nonsense, did you do any news at all? I interrupted you, 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: The James Zadroga bill has been signed by the president there in Hawaii, yes.

IMUS: Carly? Anymore coffee? She left --

MCCORD: I'll go get you some.

IMUS: She said what did Wyatt get for Christmas and I couldn't remember, horse stuff. She said, well does she still believe in Santa Claus?

MCCORD: And your reply.

IMUS: I said, well, I still believe in Santa Claus. Why wouldn't he? You know, 17 after the hour, Warner will do a little sports and before that, a quick business update, from Connell McShane here on the Fox Business Network and on the radio as well. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Good morning, I-man. I'm talking about the markets here, as we start off the new trading year to the up side, after a pretty good year in 2010, stocks are up, globally, this morning.

News out of China that show the economy there slowing down a little bit, seen as a good sign because it eases concerns about inflation. Anyway, the futures are up. The European markets that are open are all up and the Asian markets were up, overnight as well.

Now, as for the year in 2010, the Dow ended the year, with a gain of 11 percent, the S&P was up 13 percent, and the Nasdaq, the best of the bunch, with a rise of nearly 17 percent, in 2010.

IMUS: Connell McShane with business news throughout the morning and Dagen McDowell will be along -- you guys still have your show 11:00 a.m.

MCSHANE: So far, I believe, yes.

IMUS: OK, we'll start the year, brand new year with their show and they'll still do that and, that's good. Three new radio affiliates, WAUB at 1590 and 98.1 FM, out there in Auburn, New York and WGVA, at 1240, in Geneva, New York. Finger Lakes news radio, they call that.

And, KWKC, 1340, on the AM dial, down there in Abiline, Texas, talk radio 1340 and they joined the IMUS In The Morning line-up of stations around the country beginning this morning. Time for a little sports now and here with that is Warner Wolf. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man, well, completing the NFL picture, the playoffs last night, Seattle wins the NFC West with a record of 7-9. Come on!

IMUS: Who do they play, New Orleans?

WOLF: They'll play the Saints, yes, on Saturday. You have to change the rule here very quickly. You know, forget winning the division, if you have a losing record you are not in the playoffs. You take the team with the next best record, which would have been the Giants or the Bucks at 10-6.

Earlier, the Packers beat the Bears, 10-3. The Packers, 10-6, win the final wildcard. AFC, the Colts win the AFC South, on the 43 yard field goal, last play of the game, although the Colts had won it minutes earlier when the Jags were eliminated. Steelers, win the AFC. North Falcons win the NFC South so the playoffs are all set.

Packers, Eagles, in Philadelphia and Saints and Seahawks in Seattle, Jets and Colts in Indianapolis and the Ravens and Chiefs in Kansas City, yes, did you watch any of the bowl games?

WOLF: None.

IMUS: You know, I've watched them all, except I didn't pay any attention to them because they don't mean anything.

WOLF: No.

IMUS: Including the one -- a week from tonight, Auburn and Oregon, you make me watch that.

WOLF: Yes, I'll watch that.

IMUS: I won't be watching it. So, you'll watch that?

WOLF: Yes, I will.

IMUS: Why wouldn't you be at Imus on Broadway, wouldn't you want to see that?

WOLF: A conflicting time.

IMUS: It is that night. It's already sold out, so, I mean -- I could try to get you in, but -- you don't express any interest, and every day you can go to some stupid movie and routinely get a half a chicken sandwich or tuna, whatever the hell you eat, a bottle of wine and go to the gym and, see a stupid movie, park in the handicapped zone and then, go to some idiot's Broadway musical or play of some sort and yet you won't come see Imus on Broadway. That is Monday night. You will watch the stupid game between Auburn and Oregon?

WOLF: No, forget that bowl game!

MCGUIRK: Too late.

IMUS: They got to get a playoff. They have playoffs, I mean, just stupid they don't have that. Don't you agree, Warner?

WOLF: Absolutely, every baseball, basketball, college, hockey and -- everything, all have playoffs, except football.

IMUS: Speaking of Imus on Broadway, Colin Quinn, who stars in long story short, which I saw which is genius stuff, directed by Jerry Seinfeld, Colin now joined the line-up of Broadway musical shows that will perform Monday night at the Hard Rock.

MCCORD: Great.

IMUS: For the Imus cattle ranch for kids with cancer. And, the legendary emcee, which I exchanged e-mails throughout the past two weeks with, Dick Cavett is our emcee and that is worth going to see, to see him.

And I'll be there, just to introduce him. I wanted to thank our title sponsor, GMC and, one place you can go to look great, feel good and feel great and a GMC sales associate will show you the latest and greatest health and fitness products. Imus on Broadway, brought do you by GMC, which we're going to tape that -- probably -- are we going to tape it, big foot, or not.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We'll tape it if you want.

IMUS: I don't know, I don't know, if you can or not. Anyway, Warner Wolf sports, sponsored by American-made Peerless Boilers and the new 96 percent efficient purifier series. You have any more sports, Warner?

WOLF: There's one more thing, listen to this, I-man the Grizzlies beat the slumping Lakers last night, in L.A., by 19 points. And after the game, Phil Jackson really took it on Kobe Bryant.

PHIL JACKSON, LOS ANGELES LAKERS COACH: As a result, you know, behind early in the third quarter, on -- stupid plays, and, Kobe has to screw up, you know, the game and start energizing the team by going one-on-one, and takes the rest of the guys out --

WOLF: Wow. Kobe's screwing up the game. Phil Jackson. That is pretty harsh.

IMUS: You know who I have become a fan of now?

WOLF: Kevin Durant?

IMUS: No. The Miami Heat. I'll tell you why --

WOLF: Why, I-man?

RUFINO: Can't wait for this.

IMUS: Shut up, Lou! I'll tell you why.

WOLF: I wonder why.

RUFINO: Miami heat, good God!

MCGUIRK: Courageous.

WOLF: It has nothing to do with the fact they've won 17 out of the last 18 and 11 in a row.

IMUS: No. No. Because, something Magic Johnson said. He said, LeBron James is playing out of his mind, and he said it is time to stop booing him. He may -- you may be unhappy that he left Cleveland and the way he went about it but, you have to get over that. The guy is a great basketball player. So, they have got that together.

MCCORD: This is why?

IMUS: What's wrong?

MCGUIRK: Why didn't he go to a team that didn't have a bunch of star players and elevate them as most great players do?

IMUS: Because that wasn't our plan. It's 24 after the hour. All right, Steven Stills is 66 years old today.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Looking for an investment opportunity but not sure where to start? Check out Planet Fitness's -- what "Inc. Magazine" calls one of the fastest growing companies in America. Miami heat, God.

MCCORD: Pathetic.

IMUS: You shut up! A huge outfit, available in the Midwest, and, western states, and - I-man enough to know when I make a mistake, forget about the Lakers. Forget about them. Oklahoma -- forget -- Oklahoma?

They don't play basketball. Forget about the northeast that is sold out and full of happy Planet Fitness franchise ease and get on board the recession-proof business. With a big time opportunity in places like Arizona, southern California and Oregon, Washington State and think about it.

They are looking for convenient ways to exercise without a lot of hassles and looking to save money, too. Planet Fitness, good outfit and guy who runs the thing is in good shape and that tells you a lot, go to planetfitness.com and get in on this thing, come on.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

We need to make sure we can compete. (END VIDEO CLIP) MCSHANE: Issa has indicated he's going to call a lot of hearings ...

urn:contentItem:51W7-BB01-JD2T-F3PF-00000-00White House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks2011-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWhite House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks

DON IMUS, HOST: You know, who won the football game last night, Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: This Sunday night game, I don't. I went to the Jets game yesterday, they won, 38-7. But you know that already.

IMUS: Yes, I don't care about the Jets game because they were already in the playoffs. So I don't care about the Seattle Seahawks and the Rams people, but I'll find out apparently from Warner.

MCSHANE: So one of them with - record made the playoffs. I'm being told in my ear, you want to know who won now or no?

IMUS: No, let me find out from Warner, because, Warner likes to tell me stuff like that.

MCSHANE: It is Warner's job.

IMUS: Santa brought us a goofy tie? Is that what happened?

MCSHANE: No, I had that one already, I-man.

IMUS: The funny tie, under the tree.

MCSHANE: So you got two weeks off and that is the best you could come up with.

IMUS: That's all I could come up with.

MCSHANE: You sound great, by the way. How this is voice, good?

IMUS: Well, I don't have throat cancer, they tell me, but I do have -- pre-cancerous cells.

MCSHANE: Really?

IMUS: Yes --and, like if you had a colonoscopy and they find this -- remove them, so, these are -- they have to take them off with a laser here in a couple of weeks, and this is way too much information.

MCSHANE: I actually care. I told you, I care.

IMUS: I'll be fine.

MCSHANE: You will be OK, that is the main point.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, and Mary Matalin coming up this morning. Three new radio affiliates - have you even seen that guy who does the red eye thing here on Fox.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Is he any good.

MCSHANE: Yes, sure. It's fine. I don't watch it. It is on in the middle of the night, but a lot of people like it.

IMUS: I saw him on the news with Megyn Kelly and -- too happy to suit me, but he seemed funny.

MCSHANE: He is pretty funny.

IMUS: I wonder if we should have him on.

MCSHANE: Sure, why not. Give it a try.

IMUS: Is he any good? He is good. You are saying that because we're on - - on TV, here, aren't you.

MCSHANE: That is why, yes.

IMUS: What is going on with business -- how this is Facebook deal, Goldman Sachs.

MCSHANE: Yes, $50 billion valuation on Facebook. It's no joke right there.

IMUS: Please.

MCSHANE: That's what Goldman thinks it's worth anyway. I will get to that in a second, but thank you, I-man and good morning. First, let's bring up the markets and look up some numbers here because stocks are starting off the new week and the New Year with some gains here globally.

China showed manufacturing slipped for the first time in five months and if anything that's actually easing concerns about inflation and the Chinese market at the bottom screen is up 1-3/4 percent overnight.

Markets in Hong Kong and South Korea are also up, and Japan has not resumed trading yet in the New Year. Over in Europe, London is closed today for the New Year's holiday, but Paris and Frankfurt are both up significantly, Paris by more than 2 percent and our futures indicating a higher open on Wall Street as well up by 76 points on Dow futures, pretty good numbers.

Now as for the major indexes and how they fared in 2010, the Dow gained 11 percent, S&P 13 percent, the Nasdaq the best performer of the bunch, 17 percent gain.

The White House wants Congress to let the federal government take on more debt national debt is getting closer to the $14.3 trillion ceiling and the White House Council of Economic Advisors, Chairman Austin Goolsbee on ABC's "This Week" saying it's crucial the ceiling is raised.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AUSTIN GOOLSBEE, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISORS: This is not a game, you know, the debt ceiling is not something to toy with. That is the -- if we hit the debt ceiling, that is the -- essentially defaulting on our obligations, which is unprecedented in American history. The impact on the economy would be catastrophic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Many Republicans agree it does need to be raised but, many of them are also saying they will not go along with it unless they get promises to change Washington's spending habits and argue there is no point in having a debt ceiling if they raise it every time the national debt gets close. Now here's the story that the I-man was referring to a moment ago.

Goldman Sachs investing $450 million in Facebook, according to the "New York Times." A Russian company also buying $50 million worth of Facebook's stock. "The Times" says these deals value Facebook at $50 billion. Now, as we have reported the FCC now looking into secondary market trading at Facebook's privately held shares.

Expedia dropping American Airlines fares from its web site, the latest development in the conflict between airlines and online travel agencies, since American cut ties with Orbitz, the airline says Expedia intentionally listed its flights and schedules lower in search results. American is looking to push consumers to buy tickets on its own web site and every effort to save money. Expedia says the move will only cost them ticket sales and believes Americans' efforts are bad for travellers.

All right, let's take a live look now at commodities this morning. The oil price is above $92 per barrel and gold is down by a dollar per ounce.

Coming up, a little bit later on in the hour, Bo Dietl will be the I-man's guest as IMUS IN THE MORNING does get started, right now, Fox Business, power to prosper.

IMUS: Warner, who won the football game last night?

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Seahawks, man, they finished 7-9. Win the division and are in the playoffs.

IMUS: So the giants, who are 10-6, they are not in the playoffs.

WOLF: You got it. No, you have to change the rule.

CHARLES MCCORD, NEWSMAN: That is crazy.

WOLF: Absurd, yes.

IMUS: I will whip somebody's butt over there -- Charles and I.

WOLF: Now you're talking.

IMUS: Charles and me, yes. And, I get my grammar screwed up. Happy New Year, everybody.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Shucks.

IMUS: Bring you up on my medical, last time --

MCCORD: Let's have the latest.

IMUS: I'm had a biopsy -- let me say this about Mt. Sinai. It is a great hospital. You know, I'm a big fan of Hackensack and Cornell and Mt. Sinai is a great hospital. The nurses are unbelievable and Dr. Peekaboo Woo, and Dr. Allen Reid, the anesthesiologist, are fabulous.

MCCORD: Good.

IMUS: They all did a great job and I apparently do not have throat cancer. What I have are these pre-cancerous cells.

MCCORD: Dysplasia, yes.

IMUS: Yes. Charles knows more about what I have than I do.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: So, they have to remove them with a laser, and, at a high level, and they would develop into --

MCCORD: Get rid of them, that is why we get rid of them.

IMUS: And you know how I got them? Smoking.

MCCORD: Really? That is what they say? OK.

IMUS: I haven't smoked for 15 years, but -

MCCORD: Listen to that, ladies and gentlemen.

IMUS: Anyway, so I'm fine, Bo Dietl, Jerry Greenfield.

MCCORD: That's great news to start the new year.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, still have prostate cancer but, I think I do. I'm not sure anymore whether I do or not.

MCCORD: Yes, may have defeated that.

IMUS: And, I came back from the ranch on Saturday.

MCCORDs: That's 700 miles an hour with the freaking tail wind.

IMUS: What a great vacation. It's 10 degrees. We have to go out there, because we run the place. It's 10 degrees -- the wind - there's not a ski resort.

MCCORD: How about that wind?

IMUS: The wind blows and I'm not exaggerating, 60 miles an hour. Anyway, Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, Mary Matalin, coming up and we have three new radio affiliates, and when I put my glasses on I'll tell you who they are.

I'm not going to do it now and, ratings came out in New York and for people -- the ratings are broken down, all kinds of demographics and I don't believe in them but I think they give you a rough idea, of you know - - I mean, you can -- like lit-fm or one of those -- hot 97 or one of these. Whoever these stations are, that do well.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And if it is consistent over a long period of time, like when stern was on terrestrial radio, you knew he was number one, and had been on a long time, a trend that remains supported, consistency.

IMUS: So, but on these 12-plus numbers they measure people by demographics like break it down to 12 to 18, 25-54, 18-34, it is ridiculous. Men, women, all of this and there's another one they do and it is just everybody who is 12 years of age or older. And, this program, the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, is the number 2 program in New York.

MCGUIRK: Get out of town!

MCCORD: Shut the front door!

IMUS: Now, of course, I told Connell and Dagen that part of that, because, they are about the only new thing we have done here, other than I have a better attitude. They were partly responsible for that and then I got to thinking about it and if it weren't for them, we could have easily been number one.

MCCORD: Number one. Yes.

MCSHANE: I'm sorry, I-man.

IMUS: Which is the reason, when I got fired, and got the job at ABC I insisted on bringing Lou and Bernie, and Charles and everybody else, because, I knew without them, I would just be -- if it weren't for them, I would be on some station, in Jersey with Uncle Floyd.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Uncle Floyd!

IMUS: I'd be on Sirius satellite radio. Mel likes me, to give me a job for 50 grand a year. And sit there -

RUFINO: At UHF --

IMUS: The I-man's blues channel, Blues and alternate country on Sirius. But, as it is -- so the show -- I've never been number 2, ever. Not back when --

MCCORD: Your best ratings.

IMUS: Not back when I was. So I'm happy about that and it is a great program. It's a better program than it ever was. Having very little to do -- not being self-effacing, having we little to do with me, Bernie, Lou, they are all great. Time for a little news and here with that is Chuck McCord. Good morning, Charles.

MCCORD: Good morning, I-man. Speaking of the weather, the main highway between southern and central California, shut down, both directions, blowing snow and ice from another big storm. The grapevine area of I-5 closed indefinitely, winds gusting to -- reminded me, winds, gusting to 90 miles per hour in mountain areas, and still accumulating at elevations, as low as just 1,500 feet.

President Obama, says he is honored to sign the bill to provide aid to survivors of the 9/11 attacks, and first responders, all of whom --

IMUS: You know --

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: "The New York Times" did an article about the stuff that Jon Stewart, who as you know, I like, stuff Jon Stewart did about the 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: I saw it and all of that.

IMUS: And wondering if Jon Stewart was under Edward R. Murrow, which I would hope even Jon Stewart would be embarrassed about. But perhaps he's not or we don't know because I don't know him, but I would suggest -- and it has nothing do with anything, but until Shep Smith went on the rant that he went on, as a result of seeing Jon Stewart's show, which Shep said he did, and -- hey, big foot --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, sir.

IMUS: There's the famous rap that Shep Smith did, he was talking to somebody, and he referenced Jon Stewart, and he had seen the Jon Stewart show apparently the night before, there's got to be a way to find that, right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, we'll find it.

IMUS: He was -- first of all, they are both terrific, both Stewart and Shep Smith is magnificent. Few better, in fact -- I don't know if there is anybody better, but it was a respond -- did you site, Bernie.

MCGUIRK: Yes. I did --

IMUS: Am I right?

MCGUIRK: On the money, a 100 percent.

IMUS: He was absolutely spectacular.

MCGUIRK: I happened to see that.

IMUS: And it seemed to me it was spontaneous.

MCGUIRK: Certainly seemed that way.

IMUS: And the boy seemed to be articulate to me and I have to play it for you. So I think that if you are a bunch of Republicans, I -- remember I had John Thune on and he was giving me some nonsense about -- didn't wanted to rush into it.

I didn't press him hard on that, not as much as I should have, and, you know, the -- I started to say to him, you know, don't want to rush into anything and, I hope we get it before all of these people die. So, people like Senator Thune, who I am no longer supporting for anything --

MCGUIRK: That may be premature. The Republicans -- they ended up saving $3 billion from that particular bill. That is what they were holding out for, eliminate --

IMUS: They weren't going to do it until they got shamed into it by Jon Stewart and by Shep Smith, I'm saying. And when Shep Smith attacked them, I'm sure they were thinking, that is our home boy there, at Fox.

I mean, I'm sure in their minds they are thinking if we lost Shep Smith we lost the country. You would expect Jon Stewart. I thought it was magnificent what he did, by the way, but you expect him to do what he did but you wouldn't expect Shep Smith to do what he did and if you lose him you lost everybody. I mean, I'm sure they are thinking that and go that the scared into passing it, didn't they, Bernie, talking about the money they saved, because you carry water for them.

MCGUIRK: That's the fact. Chuck Schumer's bill was $7 billion and, the bill ended up being $4 billion and they saved --

IMUS: But they wouldn't have done anything, had there not been those two events, am I right.

MCGUIRK: Perhaps, there's no way to conclusively prove that, but it sure seems that way.

IMUS: And let me ask you this, for everybody who thinks, Sarah Palin is a moron, and I would be one of them, would you would this country be any worse off today if she were president? Answer me that. Tell me. I'm waiting --

MCGUIRK: Checkmate for the I-man.

MCCORD: There you go.

IMUS: Because, at least -- think whatever you want to think about her, and think as I do, maybe, even. I don't know that I think she is a moron but she'd have sense enough to at least ask the people rather than get the same people bush had. But, this dope has been doing -- I mean, is he still on vacation in Hawaii, by the way?

MCCORD: Yes. He comes back I think late today.

IMUS: And then, on I-25, out there in Santa Fe, when you go up to the ranch into Santa Fe, before you get into Santa Fe, there was a guy has a houses -- a lot of people have houses, a guy has a house, puts up these goofy billboards, a homemade billboard.

And, makes me laugh every time, they change and he's obviously a Hannity devotee or one of them and once he has had up there for a while. Where is the birth certificate? The hand lettered dopey sign, where is the birth certificate. Here's my question -- where is it? I mean, I'm not a -- obviously I'm not one of those --

MCGUIRK: A birther?

IMUS: Of course not. But, where is it?

MCCORD: I don't know.

IMUS: Isn't the governor of ha walkers wasn't he screaming all about it?

MCGUIRK: He's claiming --

IMUS: Where is it?

MCGUIRK: Yes, let's see it. Clear this up.

IMUS: I mean, if the guy who is supporting the president -- which I would tend to support him, too, by the way. But I just say.

MCCORD: Let's resolve this.

IMUS: Why haven't we ever seen it or why don't they produce it, I can't answer that.

IMUS: It just adds fuel to these nuts.

MCCORD: Of course it does.

IMUS: Anyway, 16 after the hour, taking way too much time with my nonsense, did you do any news at all? I interrupted you, 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: The James Zadroga bill has been signed by the president there in Hawaii, yes.

IMUS: Carly? Anymore coffee? She left --

MCCORD: I'll go get you some.

IMUS: She said what did Wyatt get for Christmas and I couldn't remember, horse stuff. She said, well does she still believe in Santa Claus?

MCCORD: And your reply.

IMUS: I said, well, I still believe in Santa Claus. Why wouldn't he? You know, 17 after the hour, Warner will do a little sports and before that, a quick business update, from Connell McShane here on the Fox Business Network and on the radio as well. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Good morning, I-man. I'm talking about the markets here, as we start off the new trading year to the up side, after a pretty good year in 2010, stocks are up, globally, this morning.

News out of China that show the economy there slowing down a little bit, seen as a good sign because it eases concerns about inflation. Anyway, the futures are up. The European markets that are open are all up and the Asian markets were up, overnight as well.

Now, as for the year in 2010, the Dow ended the year, with a gain of 11 percent, the S&P was up 13 percent, and the Nasdaq, the best of the bunch, with a rise of nearly 17 percent, in 2010.

IMUS: Connell McShane with business news throughout the morning and Dagen McDowell will be along -- you guys still have your show 11:00 a.m.

MCSHANE: So far, I believe, yes.

IMUS: OK, we'll start the year, brand new year with their show and they'll still do that and, that's good. Three new radio affiliates, WAUB at 1590 and 98.1 FM, out there in Auburn, New York and WGVA, at 1240, in Geneva, New York. Finger Lakes news radio, they call that.

And, KWKC, 1340, on the AM dial, down there in Abiline, Texas, talk radio 1340 and they joined the IMUS In The Morning line-up of stations around the country beginning this morning. Time for a little sports now and here with that is Warner Wolf. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man, well, completing the NFL picture, the playoffs last night, Seattle wins the NFC West with a record of 7-9. Come on!

IMUS: Who do they play, New Orleans?

WOLF: They'll play the Saints, yes, on Saturday. You have to change the rule here very quickly. You know, forget winning the division, if you have a losing record you are not in the playoffs. You take the team with the next best record, which would have been the Giants or the Bucks at 10-6.

Earlier, the Packers beat the Bears, 10-3. The Packers, 10-6, win the final wildcard. AFC, the Colts win the AFC South, on the 43 yard field goal, last play of the game, although the Colts had won it minutes earlier when the Jags were eliminated. Steelers, win the AFC. North Falcons win the NFC South so the playoffs are all set.

Packers, Eagles, in Philadelphia and Saints and Seahawks in Seattle, Jets and Colts in Indianapolis and the Ravens and Chiefs in Kansas City, yes, did you watch any of the bowl games?

WOLF: None.

IMUS: You know, I've watched them all, except I didn't pay any attention to them because they don't mean anything.

WOLF: No.

IMUS: Including the one -- a week from tonight, Auburn and Oregon, you make me watch that.

WOLF: Yes, I'll watch that.

IMUS: I won't be watching it. So, you'll watch that?

WOLF: Yes, I will.

IMUS: Why wouldn't you be at Imus on Broadway, wouldn't you want to see that?

WOLF: A conflicting time.

IMUS: It is that night. It's already sold out, so, I mean -- I could try to get you in, but -- you don't express any interest, and every day you can go to some stupid movie and routinely get a half a chicken sandwich or tuna, whatever the hell you eat, a bottle of wine and go to the gym and, see a stupid movie, park in the handicapped zone and then, go to some idiot's Broadway musical or play of some sort and yet you won't come see Imus on Broadway. That is Monday night. You will watch the stupid game between Auburn and Oregon?

WOLF: No, forget that bowl game!

MCGUIRK: Too late.

IMUS: They got to get a playoff. They have playoffs, I mean, just stupid they don't have that. Don't you agree, Warner?

WOLF: Absolutely, every baseball, basketball, college, hockey and -- everything, all have playoffs, except football.

IMUS: Speaking of Imus on Broadway, Colin Quinn, who stars in long story short, which I saw which is genius stuff, directed by Jerry Seinfeld, Colin now joined the line-up of Broadway musical shows that will perform Monday night at the Hard Rock.

MCCORD: Great.

IMUS: For the Imus cattle ranch for kids with cancer. And, the legendary emcee, which I exchanged e-mails throughout the past two weeks with, Dick Cavett is our emcee and that is worth going to see, to see him.

And I'll be there, just to introduce him. I wanted to thank our title sponsor, GMC and, one place you can go to look great, feel good and feel great and a GMC sales associate will show you the latest and greatest health and fitness products. Imus on Broadway, brought do you by GMC, which we're going to tape that -- probably -- are we going to tape it, big foot, or not.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We'll tape it if you want.

IMUS: I don't know, I don't know, if you can or not. Anyway, Warner Wolf sports, sponsored by American-made Peerless Boilers and the new 96 percent efficient purifier series. You have any more sports, Warner?

WOLF: There's one more thing, listen to this, I-man the Grizzlies beat the slumping Lakers last night, in L.A., by 19 points. And after the game, Phil Jackson really took it on Kobe Bryant.

PHIL JACKSON, LOS ANGELES LAKERS COACH: As a result, you know, behind early in the third quarter, on -- stupid plays, and, Kobe has to screw up, you know, the game and start energizing the team by going one-on-one, and takes the rest of the guys out --

WOLF: Wow. Kobe's screwing up the game. Phil Jackson. That is pretty harsh.

IMUS: You know who I have become a fan of now?

WOLF: Kevin Durant?

IMUS: No. The Miami Heat. I'll tell you why --

WOLF: Why, I-man?

RUFINO: Can't wait for this.

IMUS: Shut up, Lou! I'll tell you why.

WOLF: I wonder why.

RUFINO: Miami heat, good God!

MCGUIRK: Courageous.

WOLF: It has nothing to do with the fact they've won 17 out of the last 18 and 11 in a row.

IMUS: No. No. Because, something Magic Johnson said. He said, LeBron James is playing out of his mind, and he said it is time to stop booing him. He may -- you may be unhappy that he left Cleveland and the way he went about it but, you have to get over that. The guy is a great basketball player. So, they have got that together.

MCCORD: This is why?

IMUS: What's wrong?

MCGUIRK: Why didn't he go to a team that didn't have a bunch of star players and elevate them as most great players do?

IMUS: Because that wasn't our plan. It's 24 after the hour. All right, Steven Stills is 66 years old today.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Looking for an investment opportunity but not sure where to start? Check out Planet Fitness's -- what "Inc. Magazine" calls one of the fastest growing companies in America. Miami heat, God.

MCCORD: Pathetic.

IMUS: You shut up! A huge outfit, available in the Midwest, and, western states, and - I-man enough to know when I make a mistake, forget about the Lakers. Forget about them. Oklahoma -- forget -- Oklahoma?

They don't play basketball. Forget about the northeast that is sold out and full of happy Planet Fitness franchise ease and get on board the recession-proof business. With a big time opportunity in places like Arizona, southern California and Oregon, Washington State and think about it.

They are looking for convenient ways to exercise without a lot of hassles and looking to save money, too. Planet Fitness, good outfit and guy who runs the thing is in good shape and that tells you a lot, go to planetfitness.com and get in on this thing, come on.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Johnson & Johnson will announce a powerful cancer test it wants to put on the market, able to spot a single cancer cell out of a billion healthy cells and is teaming up with the scientist who invented the test to make it cheaper and better and the hope is the test can take the place of more invasive cancer tests at some point.

<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA : We have about $1.7 trillion worth of <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> costs already in the government. If the president wants to throw ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h3" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA : We have about $1.7 trillion worth of <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> costs already in the government. If the President wants to throw ...</xhtml:span>

urn:contentItem:5JD9-VJN1-JBHT-D20D-00000-00White House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks2011-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWhite House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake RocksLanhamFULL TEXT

DON IMUS, HOST: You know, who won the football game last night, Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: This Sunday night game, I don't. I went to the Jets game yesterday, they won, 38-7. But you know that already.

IMUS: Yes, I don't care about the Jets game because they were already in the playoffs. So I don't care about the Seattle Seahawks and the Rams people, but I'll find out apparently from Warner.

MCSHANE: So one of them with - record made the playoffs. I'm being told in my ear, you want to know who won now or no?

IMUS: No, let me find out from Warner, because, Warner likes to tell me stuff like that.

MCSHANE: It is Warner's job.

IMUS: Santa brought us a goofy tie? Is that what happened?

MCSHANE: No, I had that one already, I-man.

IMUS: The funny tie, under the tree.

MCSHANE: So you got two weeks off and that is the best you could come up with.

IMUS: That's all I could come up with.

MCSHANE: You sound great, by the way. How this is voice, good?

IMUS: Well, I don't have throat cancer, they tell me, but I do have -- pre-cancerous cells.

MCSHANE: Really?

IMUS: Yes --and, like if you had a colonoscopy and they find this -- remove them, so, these are -- they have to take them off with a laser here in a couple of weeks, and this is way too much information.

MCSHANE: I actually care. I told you, I care.

IMUS: I'll be fine.

MCSHANE: You will be OK, that is the main point.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, and Mary Matalin coming up this morning. Three new radio affiliates - have you even seen that guy who does the red eye thing here on Fox.

MCSHANE: Yes.

IMUS: Is he any good.

MCSHANE: Yes, sure. It's fine. I don't watch it. It is on in the middle of the night, but a lot of people like it.

IMUS: I saw him on the news with Megyn Kelly and -- too happy to suit me, but he seemed funny.

MCSHANE: He is pretty funny.

IMUS: I wonder if we should have him on.

MCSHANE: Sure, why not. Give it a try.

IMUS: Is he any good? He is good. You are saying that because we're on - - on TV, here, aren't you.

MCSHANE: That is why, yes.

IMUS: What is going on with business -- how this is Facebook deal, Goldman Sachs.

MCSHANE: Yes, $50 billion valuation on Facebook. It's no joke right there.

IMUS: Please.

MCSHANE: That's what Goldman thinks it's worth anyway. I will get to that in a second, but thank you, I-man and good morning. First, let's bring up the markets and look up some numbers here because stocks are starting off the new week and the New Year with some gains here globally.

China showed manufacturing slipped for the first time in five months and if anything that's actually easing concerns about inflation and the Chinese market at the bottom screen is up 1-3/4 percent overnight.

Markets in Hong Kong and South Korea are also up, and Japan has not resumed trading yet in the New Year. Over in Europe, London is closed today for the New Year's holiday, but Paris and Frankfurt are both up significantly, Paris by more than 2 percent and our futures indicating a higher open on Wall Street as well up by 76 points on Dow futures, pretty good numbers.

Now as for the major indexes and how they fared in 2010, the Dow gained 11 percent, S&P 13 percent, the Nasdaq the best performer of the bunch, 17 percent gain.

The White House wants Congress to let the federal government take on more debt national debt is getting closer to the $14.3 trillion ceiling and the White House Council of Economic Advisors, Chairman Austin Goolsbee on ABC's "This Week" saying it's crucial the ceiling is raised.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AUSTIN GOOLSBEE, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISORS: This is not a game, you know, the debt ceiling is not something to toy with. That is the -- if we hit the debt ceiling, that is the -- essentially defaulting on our obligations, which is unprecedented in American history. The impact on the economy would be catastrophic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Many Republicans agree it does need to be raised but, many of them are also saying they will not go along with it unless they get promises to change Washington's spending habits and argue there is no point in having a debt ceiling if they raise it every time the national debt gets close. Now here's the story that the I-man was referring to a moment ago.

Goldman Sachs investing $450 million in Facebook, according to the "New York Times." A Russian company also buying $50 million worth of Facebook's stock. "The Times" says these deals value Facebook at $50 billion. Now, as we have reported the FCC now looking into secondary market trading at Facebook's privately held shares.

Expedia dropping American Airlines fares from its web site, the latest development in the conflict between airlines and online travel agencies, since American cut ties with Orbitz, the airline says Expedia intentionally listed its flights and schedules lower in search results. American is looking to push consumers to buy tickets on its own web site and every effort to save money. Expedia says the move will only cost them ticket sales and believes Americans' efforts are bad for travellers.

All right, let's take a live look now at commodities this morning. The oil price is above $92 per barrel and gold is down by a dollar per ounce.

Coming up, a little bit later on in the hour, Bo Dietl will be the I-man's guest as IMUS IN THE MORNING does get started, right now, Fox Business, power to prosper.

IMUS: Warner, who won the football game last night?

WARNER WOLF, SPORTSCASTER: Seahawks, man, they finished 7-9. Win the division and are in the playoffs.

IMUS: So the giants, who are 10-6, they are not in the playoffs.

WOLF: You got it. No, you have to change the rule.

CHARLES MCCORD, NEWSMAN: That is crazy.

WOLF: Absurd, yes.

IMUS: I will whip somebody's butt over there -- Charles and I.

WOLF: Now you're talking.

IMUS: Charles and me, yes. And, I get my grammar screwed up. Happy New Year, everybody.

BERNARD MCGUIRK, PROGRAM PRODUCER: Shucks.

IMUS: Bring you up on my medical, last time --

MCCORD: Let's have the latest.

IMUS: I'm had a biopsy -- let me say this about Mt. Sinai. It is a great hospital. You know, I'm a big fan of Hackensack and Cornell and Mt. Sinai is a great hospital. The nurses are unbelievable and Dr. Peekaboo Woo, and Dr. Allen Reid, the anesthesiologist, are fabulous.

MCCORD: Good.

IMUS: They all did a great job and I apparently do not have throat cancer. What I have are these pre-cancerous cells.

MCCORD: Dysplasia, yes.

IMUS: Yes. Charles knows more about what I have than I do.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: So, they have to remove them with a laser, and, at a high level, and they would develop into --

MCCORD: Get rid of them, that is why we get rid of them.

IMUS: And you know how I got them? Smoking.

MCCORD: Really? That is what they say? OK.

IMUS: I haven't smoked for 15 years, but -

MCCORD: Listen to that, ladies and gentlemen.

IMUS: Anyway, so I'm fine, Bo Dietl, Jerry Greenfield.

MCCORD: That's great news to start the new year.

IMUS: Bo Dietl, still have prostate cancer but, I think I do. I'm not sure anymore whether I do or not.

MCCORD: Yes, may have defeated that.

IMUS: And, I came back from the ranch on Saturday.

MCCORDs: That's 700 miles an hour with the freaking tail wind.

IMUS: What a great vacation. It's 10 degrees. We have to go out there, because we run the place. It's 10 degrees -- the wind - there's not a ski resort.

MCCORD: How about that wind?

IMUS: The wind blows and I'm not exaggerating, 60 miles an hour. Anyway, Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, Mary Matalin, coming up and we have three new radio affiliates, and when I put my glasses on I'll tell you who they are.

I'm not going to do it now and, ratings came out in New York and for people -- the ratings are broken down, all kinds of demographics and I don't believe in them but I think they give you a rough idea, of you know - - I mean, you can -- like lit-fm or one of those -- hot 97 or one of these. Whoever these stations are, that do well.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: And if it is consistent over a long period of time, like when stern was on terrestrial radio, you knew he was number one, and had been on a long time, a trend that remains supported, consistency.

IMUS: So, but on these 12-plus numbers they measure people by demographics like break it down to 12 to 18, 25-54, 18-34, it is ridiculous. Men, women, all of this and there's another one they do and it is just everybody who is 12 years of age or older. And, this program, the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, is the number 2 program in New York.

MCGUIRK: Get out of town!

MCCORD: Shut the front door!

IMUS: Now, of course, I told Connell and Dagen that part of that, because, they are about the only new thing we have done here, other than I have a better attitude. They were partly responsible for that and then I got to thinking about it and if it weren't for them, we could have easily been number one.

MCCORD: Number one. Yes.

MCSHANE: I'm sorry, I-man.

IMUS: Which is the reason, when I got fired, and got the job at ABC I insisted on bringing Lou and Bernie, and Charles and everybody else, because, I knew without them, I would just be -- if it weren't for them, I would be on some station, in Jersey with Uncle Floyd.

LOU RUFINO, PROGRAM ENGINEER: Uncle Floyd!

IMUS: I'd be on Sirius satellite radio. Mel likes me, to give me a job for 50 grand a year. And sit there -

RUFINO: At UHF --

IMUS: The I-man's blues channel, Blues and alternate country on Sirius. But, as it is -- so the show -- I've never been number 2, ever. Not back when --

MCCORD: Your best ratings.

IMUS: Not back when I was. So I'm happy about that and it is a great program. It's a better program than it ever was. Having very little to do -- not being self-effacing, having we little to do with me, Bernie, Lou, they are all great. Time for a little news and here with that is Chuck McCord. Good morning, Charles.

MCCORD: Good morning, I-man. Speaking of the weather, the main highway between southern and central California, shut down, both directions, blowing snow and ice from another big storm. The grapevine area of I-5 closed indefinitely, winds gusting to -- reminded me, winds, gusting to 90 miles per hour in mountain areas, and still accumulating at elevations, as low as just 1,500 feet.

President Obama, says he is honored to sign the bill to provide aid to survivors of the 9/11 attacks, and first responders, all of whom --

IMUS: You know --

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: "The New York Times" did an article about the stuff that Jon Stewart, who as you know, I like, stuff Jon Stewart did about the 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: I saw it and all of that.

IMUS: And wondering if Jon Stewart was under Edward R. Murrow, which I would hope even Jon Stewart would be embarrassed about. But perhaps he's not or we don't know because I don't know him, but I would suggest -- and it has nothing do with anything, but until Shep Smith went on the rant that he went on, as a result of seeing Jon Stewart's show, which Shep said he did, and -- hey, big foot --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, sir.

IMUS: There's the famous rap that Shep Smith did, he was talking to somebody, and he referenced Jon Stewart, and he had seen the Jon Stewart show apparently the night before, there's got to be a way to find that, right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, we'll find it.

IMUS: He was -- first of all, they are both terrific, both Stewart and Shep Smith is magnificent. Few better, in fact -- I don't know if there is anybody better, but it was a respond -- did you site, Bernie.

MCGUIRK: Yes. I did --

IMUS: Am I right?

MCGUIRK: On the money, a 100 percent.

IMUS: He was absolutely spectacular.

MCGUIRK: I happened to see that.

IMUS: And it seemed to me it was spontaneous.

MCGUIRK: Certainly seemed that way.

IMUS: And the boy seemed to be articulate to me and I have to play it for you. So I think that if you are a bunch of Republicans, I -- remember I had John Thune on and he was giving me some nonsense about -- didn't wanted to rush into it.

I didn't press him hard on that, not as much as I should have, and, you know, the -- I started to say to him, you know, don't want to rush into anything and, I hope we get it before all of these people die. So, people like Senator Thune, who I am no longer supporting for anything --

MCGUIRK: That may be premature. The Republicans -- they ended up saving $3 billion from that particular bill. That is what they were holding out for, eliminate --

IMUS: They weren't going to do it until they got shamed into it by Jon Stewart and by Shep Smith, I'm saying. And when Shep Smith attacked them, I'm sure they were thinking, that is our home boy there, at Fox.

I mean, I'm sure in their minds they are thinking if we lost Shep Smith we lost the country. You would expect Jon Stewart. I thought it was magnificent what he did, by the way, but you expect him to do what he did but you wouldn't expect Shep Smith to do what he did and if you lose him you lost everybody. I mean, I'm sure they are thinking that and go that the scared into passing it, didn't they, Bernie, talking about the money they saved, because you carry water for them.

MCGUIRK: That's the fact. Chuck Schumer's bill was $7 billion and, the bill ended up being $4 billion and they saved --

IMUS: But they wouldn't have done anything, had there not been those two events, am I right.

MCGUIRK: Perhaps, there's no way to conclusively prove that, but it sure seems that way.

IMUS: And let me ask you this, for everybody who thinks, Sarah Palin is a moron, and I would be one of them, would you would this country be any worse off today if she were president? Answer me that. Tell me. I'm waiting --

MCGUIRK: Checkmate for the I-man.

MCCORD: There you go.

IMUS: Because, at least -- think whatever you want to think about her, and think as I do, maybe, even. I don't know that I think she is a moron but she'd have sense enough to at least ask the people rather than get the same people bush had. But, this dope has been doing -- I mean, is he still on vacation in Hawaii, by the way?

MCCORD: Yes. He comes back I think late today.

IMUS: And then, on I-25, out there in Santa Fe, when you go up to the ranch into Santa Fe, before you get into Santa Fe, there was a guy has a houses -- a lot of people have houses, a guy has a house, puts up these goofy billboards, a homemade billboard.

And, makes me laugh every time, they change and he's obviously a Hannity devotee or one of them and once he has had up there for a while. Where is the birth certificate? The hand lettered dopey sign, where is the birth certificate. Here's my question -- where is it? I mean, I'm not a -- obviously I'm not one of those --

MCGUIRK: A birther?

IMUS: Of course not. But, where is it?

MCCORD: I don't know.

IMUS: Isn't the governor of ha walkers wasn't he screaming all about it?

MCGUIRK: He's claiming --

IMUS: Where is it?

MCGUIRK: Yes, let's see it. Clear this up.

IMUS: I mean, if the guy who is supporting the president -- which I would tend to support him, too, by the way. But I just say.

MCCORD: Let's resolve this.

IMUS: Why haven't we ever seen it or why don't they produce it, I can't answer that.

IMUS: It just adds fuel to these nuts.

MCCORD: Of course it does.

IMUS: Anyway, 16 after the hour, taking way too much time with my nonsense, did you do any news at all? I interrupted you, 9/11 bill.

MCCORD: The James Zadroga bill has been signed by the president there in Hawaii, yes.

IMUS: Carly? Anymore coffee? She left --

MCCORD: I'll go get you some.

IMUS: She said what did Wyatt get for Christmas and I couldn't remember, horse stuff. She said, well does she still believe in Santa Claus?

MCCORD: And your reply.

IMUS: I said, well, I still believe in Santa Claus. Why wouldn't he? You know, 17 after the hour, Warner will do a little sports and before that, a quick business update, from Connell McShane here on the Fox Business Network and on the radio as well. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Good morning, I-man. I'm talking about the markets here, as we start off the new trading year to the up side, after a pretty good year in 2010, stocks are up, globally, this morning.

News out of China that show the economy there slowing down a little bit, seen as a good sign because it eases concerns about inflation. Anyway, the futures are up. The European markets that are open are all up and the Asian markets were up, overnight as well.

Now, as for the year in 2010, the Dow ended the year, with a gain of 11 percent, the S&P was up 13 percent, and the Nasdaq, the best of the bunch, with a rise of nearly 17 percent, in 2010.

IMUS: Connell McShane with business news throughout the morning and Dagen McDowell will be along -- you guys still have your show 11:00 a.m.

MCSHANE: So far, I believe, yes.

IMUS: OK, we'll start the year, brand new year with their show and they'll still do that and, that's good. Three new radio affiliates, WAUB at 1590 and 98.1 FM, out there in Auburn, New York and WGVA, at 1240, in Geneva, New York. Finger Lakes news radio, they call that.

And, KWKC, 1340, on the AM dial, down there in Abiline, Texas, talk radio 1340 and they joined the IMUS In The Morning line-up of stations around the country beginning this morning. Time for a little sports now and here with that is Warner Wolf. Good morning, Warner.

WOLF: Good morning, I-man, well, completing the NFL picture, the playoffs last night, Seattle wins the NFC West with a record of 7-9. Come on!

IMUS: Who do they play, New Orleans?

WOLF: They'll play the Saints, yes, on Saturday. You have to change the rule here very quickly. You know, forget winning the division, if you have a losing record you are not in the playoffs. You take the team with the next best record, which would have been the Giants or the Bucks at 10-6.

Earlier, the Packers beat the Bears, 10-3. The Packers, 10-6, win the final wildcard. AFC, the Colts win the AFC South, on the 43 yard field goal, last play of the game, although the Colts had won it minutes earlier when the Jags were eliminated. Steelers, win the AFC. North Falcons win the NFC South so the playoffs are all set.

Packers, Eagles, in Philadelphia and Saints and Seahawks in Seattle, Jets and Colts in Indianapolis and the Ravens and Chiefs in Kansas City, yes, did you watch any of the bowl games?

WOLF: None.

IMUS: You know, I've watched them all, except I didn't pay any attention to them because they don't mean anything.

WOLF: No.

IMUS: Including the one -- a week from tonight, Auburn and Oregon, you make me watch that.

WOLF: Yes, I'll watch that.

IMUS: I won't be watching it. So, you'll watch that?

WOLF: Yes, I will.

IMUS: Why wouldn't you be at Imus on Broadway, wouldn't you want to see that?

WOLF: A conflicting time.

IMUS: It is that night. It's already sold out, so, I mean -- I could try to get you in, but -- you don't express any interest, and every day you can go to some stupid movie and routinely get a half a chicken sandwich or tuna, whatever the hell you eat, a bottle of wine and go to the gym and, see a stupid movie, park in the handicapped zone and then, go to some idiot's Broadway musical or play of some sort and yet you won't come see Imus on Broadway. That is Monday night. You will watch the stupid game between Auburn and Oregon?

WOLF: No, forget that bowl game!

MCGUIRK: Too late.

IMUS: They got to get a playoff. They have playoffs, I mean, just stupid they don't have that. Don't you agree, Warner?

WOLF: Absolutely, every baseball, basketball, college, hockey and -- everything, all have playoffs, except football.

IMUS: Speaking of Imus on Broadway, Colin Quinn, who stars in long story short, which I saw which is genius stuff, directed by Jerry Seinfeld, Colin now joined the line-up of Broadway musical shows that will perform Monday night at the Hard Rock.

MCCORD: Great.

IMUS: For the Imus cattle ranch for kids with cancer. And, the legendary emcee, which I exchanged e-mails throughout the past two weeks with, Dick Cavett is our emcee and that is worth going to see, to see him.

And I'll be there, just to introduce him. I wanted to thank our title sponsor, GMC and, one place you can go to look great, feel good and feel great and a GMC sales associate will show you the latest and greatest health and fitness products. Imus on Broadway, brought do you by GMC, which we're going to tape that -- probably -- are we going to tape it, big foot, or not.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We'll tape it if you want.

IMUS: I don't know, I don't know, if you can or not. Anyway, Warner Wolf sports, sponsored by American-made Peerless Boilers and the new 96 percent efficient purifier series. You have any more sports, Warner?

WOLF: There's one more thing, listen to this, I-man the Grizzlies beat the slumping Lakers last night, in L.A., by 19 points. And after the game, Phil Jackson really took it on Kobe Bryant.

PHIL JACKSON, LOS ANGELES LAKERS COACH: As a result, you know, behind early in the third quarter, on -- stupid plays, and, Kobe has to screw up, you know, the game and start energizing the team by going one-on-one, and takes the rest of the guys out --

WOLF: Wow. Kobe's screwing up the game. Phil Jackson. That is pretty harsh.

IMUS: You know who I have become a fan of now?

WOLF: Kevin Durant?

IMUS: No. The Miami Heat. I'll tell you why --

WOLF: Why, I-man?

RUFINO: Can't wait for this.

IMUS: Shut up, Lou! I'll tell you why.

WOLF: I wonder why.

RUFINO: Miami heat, good God!

MCGUIRK: Courageous.

WOLF: It has nothing to do with the fact they've won 17 out of the last 18 and 11 in a row.

IMUS: No. No. Because, something Magic Johnson said. He said, LeBron James is playing out of his mind, and he said it is time to stop booing him. He may -- you may be unhappy that he left Cleveland and the way he went about it but, you have to get over that. The guy is a great basketball player. So, they have got that together.

MCCORD: This is why?

IMUS: What's wrong?

MCGUIRK: Why didn't he go to a team that didn't have a bunch of star players and elevate them as most great players do?

IMUS: Because that wasn't our plan. It's 24 after the hour. All right, Steven Stills is 66 years old today.

(MUSIC)

IMUS: Looking for an investment opportunity but not sure where to start? Check out Planet Fitness's -- what "Inc. Magazine" calls one of the fastest growing companies in America. Miami heat, God.

MCCORD: Pathetic.

IMUS: You shut up! A huge outfit, available in the Midwest, and, western states, and - I-man enough to know when I make a mistake, forget about the Lakers. Forget about them. Oklahoma -- forget -- Oklahoma?

They don't play basketball. Forget about the northeast that is sold out and full of happy Planet Fitness franchise ease and get on board the recession-proof business. With a big time opportunity in places like Arizona, southern California and Oregon, Washington State and think about it.

They are looking for convenient ways to exercise without a lot of hassles and looking to save money, too. Planet Fitness, good outfit and guy who runs the thing is in good shape and that tells you a lot, go to planetfitness.com and get in on this thing, come on.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCSHANE: Johnson & Johnson will announce a powerful cancer test it wants to put on the market, able to spot a single cancer cell out of a billion healthy cells and is teaming up with the scientist who invented the test to make it cheaper and better and the hope is the test can take the place of more invasive cancer tests at some point.

As for the markets, this morning, stocks starting off the New Year with gains, monthly survey in China showed manufacturing slipped for the first time in five months and if anything, that is easing concerns about inflation, and being seen as a positive for world markets, up in Paris, 2 percent, up in Germany, 1.5 percent, the European markets, and, monitoring morning because London is closed for the holiday and new year's holiday and futures in the U.S. indicating the open may be a higher one on Wall Street, up 72 points, already on the Dow futures, this morning.

Quick look at commodities, when have oil at around $92 per barrel and gold is a little bit unchanged at $1,420 per ounce. All right back now to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on FOX Business, the power to prosper.

WILLIS: Tonight on "THE WILLIS REPORT," he says Americans will be paying $5 a gallon for gas as soon as next year, I'll be joined by former president of Shell John Hofmeister for his scary predictions, tune in tonight and every weeknight at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time for "THE WILLIS REPORT" on the FOX Business Network, the power to prosper.

IMUS: All right. Thirty minutes after the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, Bo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, Mary Matalin, all coming up this morning, this week we are playing the five favorite songs of Peter Rodriguez from New York, New York. His five favorite songs, the Allman Brothers, "One Way Out," "Jungleland," Bruce Springsteen, "Give me Shelter," The Stones, "While my Guitar Gently Weeps," the Beatles, and, "Landslide," Fleetwood Mac, not a horrible list.

MCCORD: Peta.

IMUS: Huh?

RUFINO: Peta Griffin.

MCCORD: Peta.

(LAUGHTER)

MCCORD: This song sucks.

IMUS: Time for little business news and here with all that, on the FOX Business Network and on the radio as well is Dagen McDowell. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, sir.

IMUS: How are you?

MCDOWELL: I'm good, welcome back, good to see you, sound great, look even better.

IMUS: All right.

MCDOWELL: All righty. So, iPhone, the Apple in its iPhone seemed to fall down on the job during the first two days of 2011 when the alarms that some iPhone owners set failed to go off, leaving folks to oversleep, apparently, it was one time alarm settings, not the recurrent ones saying, Apple will not say what went wrong with it but, apparently it will be fixed from here on out. I gave my mama an iPad for Christmas.

IMUS: Oh, you did?

MCDOWELL: Yes, and, she opened it up and it was sealed, bought it at the Apples store at Danbury Mall, it was sealed she opened it and it said Happy Holidays, Dennis Piper and Alan Rosenthal (ph). It was engraved by two Endodontists that worked in Norwalk, that was my mama's Christmas gift from us. She kept it though.

IMUS: I don't quite understand you. Did you Charles?

MCCORD: No.

MCDOWELL: The iPad was engraved by these two Endodontists who apparently given them to their staff or costumers and somebody returned it to the Apple store and exchange it. But Apple.

IMUS: Oh, they sold to you for.

MCDOWELL: .and they sold it to me at no discounted, I might add.

IMUS: What was the story then, the Apple store?

MCDOWELL: Yes, Apple store, so, mama got a kick out of it. I thought it was appropriate, you know, Christmas gift, root canals, you know, spending time with your family, all kinds of seems, dove tell together.

IMUS: I thought she would have been offended that it didn't say Merry Christmas.

MCDOWELL: Oh, no. She was probably offended by the fact we got her the cheaper one, see the Wi-Fi, we got her the one with where you can -- the AT&T.

IMUS: That's the one you got to have, so.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Well, we chintz out on that, Merry Christmas, mama, that's it.

IMUS: Why wouldn't you take it back?

MCDOWELL: Too lazy, too much trouble.

IMUS: For your mama?

MCDOWELL: Yes. She seems happy with it. She's fine. And, I only have to see her like twice a year, what she'll going to do about it?

IMUS: She's crying inside.
