MCDOWELL: Oh, well, of him.

IMUS: You were telling me how hot he was.

MCDOWELL: He's got -- well, he's got curly -- he's got curly hair and it kind of has a little bit of a mullet if memory serves. He's pretty cute. He's better looking than Mutt Lange, I'll put it that way.

IMUS: That's a white trash deal on that, isn't it?

MCCORD: Oh, brother.

IMUS: That's a white trash trailer park situation.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but you get to watch it for free, though, when you watch it on the TV. That's -- or you can come over to my house, which I don't think you want to do.

IMUS: Yes. How did that go, by the way, over the holidays at your house?

MCDOWELL: It was all right. I got trapped in the house with six adults, three kids and three dogs. And one of the dogs, being a four month old border collie puppy. So that was a good time.

IMUS: Who were the adults?

MCDOWELL: Mama, daddy, brother, his wife, Jonas and me. If you could call us all adults.

IMUS: How is your brother's wife? How do you get along with her?

MCDOWELL: I adore her.

IMUS: Oh, you do?

MCDOWELL: Yes. We get along good.

IMUS: Oh, that's too bad.

MCDOWELL: Why?

IMUS: Well, we'd just like a little friction and stuff going on. So there wasn't any animosity that bubbled to the surface there or any long held resentments or anything?

MCDOWELL: No, I wasn't happy with -- no, I wasn't happy with my Christmas gifts from Jonas. But other than that.

IMUS: What did he get you?

MCDOWELL: Underwear that he bought -- I know he bought on sale because I saw it on sale on the Internet. And a computer, a laptop, which is just business. I didn't want something business related. And I wanted underwear that fit that was nicer than what he gave me. So, I was mad. At least I didn't get those pajama jeans. I mean I can look on the bright side.

IMUS: Oh, he didn't get you like them big ole granny drawers, did he?

MCDOWELL: Some were, yes, large in size. Some, too small. There was no happy medium.

IMUS: He didn't' get --

MCDOWELL: There was no happy medium. They were either to small and uncomfortable or they were too big and loose.

IMUS: So he didn't go the Victoria's Secret thong deal?

MCDOWELL: No, he went on the Internet to one of these private sales sites and bought drawers on sale.

IMUS: Oh, he got you some -- he got you some of those Hanes -- big old -- them Hanes big beefy drawers.

MCCORD: Off of eBay.

IMUS: All right, time for a Bernard McGuirk briefing, a "Bernie Briefing," sponsored by -- these big old beefy drawers.

MCCORD: That ain't right.

IMUS: Sponsored by P.C. Richard & Son. A hundred and one years they've got it going on. Still going on.

What's up, B?

MCGUIRK: Well, chief, on the "New Year's Rocking Eve" fright night, the TV shows, I confess I was one of the losers who was up at midnight watching. And I was watching Dick Clark --

IMUS: No, don't do this.

MCGUIRK: And -- well, no, no, this is -- this is a big story. There are competing, differing opinions as to whether or not Dick Clark should still be out there. Some people say it's an inspiration, but --

IMUS: No, no. It's too humiliating for him. Whoever is around him shouldn't let him do this. It's terrible.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DICK CLARK, BROADCASTER: But don't you go anywhere.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: Where did that come from?

IMUS: I didn't hear the sound. There's no point in playing it.

MCGUIRK: We have audio here. Lou will play it.

Here, Lou. Go ahead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLARK: Thank you, Ryan, very much. Now, take a look at all the people up on Broadway. I don't know how people pull off this party year after year, but they do a whale of a job. And tonight it will be bigger and better than ever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: Again, some people say that's inspiring, and some people say it's out of place. But in any case, he won the night far and away. He was the most watched show that night of all the broadcast and cable New Year's Eve shows. And God bless poor old Dick Clark.

IMUS: You bastard.

MCGUIRK: What?

IMUS: You evil bastard.

MCGUIRK: Why?

IMUS: You just can't --

MCCORD: Well, he shouldn't be going on.

MCGUIRK: I didn't put him on ABC.

IMUS: No, no.

MCGUIRK: I think he should be on. I think he is an inspiration.

IMUS: Put him on Fox. No. No.

MCCORD: He was just presenting the controversy.

IMUS: You put him on ABC. You can't be. You can't do that. It's horrible.

MCGUIRK: Well, I happen to disagree. I think it's a good thing. I think it's a nice thing. And again, it inspires people who have been ill.

My dad had a stroke, he came back from it. It makes people say, yes, I can do it.

IMUS: I don't know. Here he is on -- who is that Ryan Seacrest? Do you have any sound on that, Big Foot.

MCGUIRK: We have a little -- we have sound. Lou and I have some sound from Ryan Seacrest just before --

IMUS: Well, there's Dick and -- Big Foot, we can't hear any sound on this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Maybe he doesn't want to.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RYAN SEACREST: Sorry. Sorry, not my fault.

CLARK: Happy New Year.

SEACREST: Happy New Year. Great job.

CLARK: Thank you, Ryan. Thank you.

SEACREST: Thank you so much.

Dick Clark, ladies and gentlemen.

Well, we are inside, and it's even warmer in here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: That's a nice thing. The man's been through hell and back. Way to kick off the new year.

Charles, push him. Is he all right?

MCCORD: He's all right, but he's --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Looking to the future.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: You son of a bitch!

MCGUIRK: Tom goes for the easy joke.

IMUS: Call that funny, Charles?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good. Now everybody is --

MCGUIRK: Everybody is waiting to see who is going to say it.

IMUS: Tom.

(LAUGHTER)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, Tom, have you got that clip? Lou?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'll he come up here and I'll find you. Are you coming down here?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just got to e-mail from Neil Cavuto.

IMUS: That's not funny.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I was down at the ranch last we week.

MCCORD: This is not -- stop.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not funny. It's not funny, no.

MCCORD: This is not good.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not funny, Bernard. It's not.

MCGUIRK: Look, God bless Dick Clark, is all I'm saying.

MCCORD: There is an is inspirational story.

MCGUIRK: Yes. That Ryan Seacrest, too.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: No.

MCCORD: You've got to stop.

IMUS: Oh, God.

MCGUIRK: "Blonde on Blonde" is coming up tomorrow.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: That's just horrible. God.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Imus at night -- be there.

IMUS: Why do they do that? That's horrible.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Why are they wheeling him out there?

MCGUIRK: No, it's his show. He's as lucid as they come. He just can't speak properly. So why not?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's the way he's going to go out though.

MCGUIRK: So what? That's his choice.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, it's not.

IMUS: That's not right.

MCGUIRK: It was a ratings winner for the night.

IMUS: Well, I don't think it had much to do --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Let's go see how he is?

IMUS: Do you?

MCGUIRK: Ryan Seacrest. You had a bunch of great performers. Kesha was there.

IMUS: Well, Ryan Seacrest, if you get down and you -- I mean, I like him, but if you get down and you scrape the bottom of the show biz barrel, that's where you find Ryan Seacrest. I mean, he's on the E! Channel, for God's sake.

MCGUIRK: He's "American Idol." He's at the top of his game, that guys.

IMUS: Oh, whatever. He's at the bottom of the barrel. He may be at the top of the game, but --

(MUSIC)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here's Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: And when Congress gets back to work on Wednesday, California Congressman Darrell Issa getting a big promotion. He'll become the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, which basically means he'll be the one or heading up the committee that oversees the government.

And appearing on "Fox News Sunday," Issa telling Chris Wallace he's going to target government spending.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: We have about $1.7 trillion worth of regulatory costs already in the government. If the president wants to throw another $300 or $400 billion, what he's doing is taking it right out of businesses, right out of employment, right out of competitiveness. We need to make sure we can compete.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Issa has indicated he's going to call a lot of hearings as committee chairman on topics including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and also Medicare.

Checking in on the markets here this morning for you, up all morning long. And we are indicated higher on the futures by 85 points now on Dow futures. It looks like a strong start to the new year coming on Wall Street in just a little while.

It's the IMUS IN THE MORNING program that continues right now with a check of the forecast.

(WEATHER REPORT)

IMUS: Twenty minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, on the radio all over the country, and on the Fox Business Network all over the world. Three new radio affiliates today -- WAUB, 1590, way up there on the right-hand side of the dial where the dogs can listen, and at 94.1 FM here in Auburn, New York.

MCCORD: But you can't.

IMUS: On WGBA, 1240 on the dial there in Geneva, New York, Finger Lakes News Radio. And KWKC, 1340 AM, in Abilene, Texas, Talk Radio 1340.

Tomorrow, on this program, Tom Friedman. Wednesday, "Blonde on Blonde."

Please welcome now to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, our old friend, former assistant to the president, vice president, a bunch of other stuff, Mary Matlin.

Good morning, Ms. Matalin.

MARY MATALIN, FMR. ASSISTANT TO VICE PRESIDENT CHENEY: Here, kitty kitty. Hey. Good morning. Happy New Year.

IMUS: Are you calling the cat?

MATALIN: Hey, kitty, kitty, kitty. Here, kitty kitty. She was trapped outside and was about to unleash the dogs of my hell, my mini dachshund. I said, "Kitty."

It irritates I-Man. He doesn't want to hear you.

IMUS: I like cats and dogs. What's your cat's name?

MATALIN: Witchy. She has one green eye and one blue eye.

IMUS: Why are you out of breath?

MATALIN: Because I had to move the chair, open the shades, and open the window from the bottom up, while I was holding the phone in my ear. And I'm old now.

IMUS: Did you -- what did you do New Year's Eve?

MATALIN: Made black eyed peas and cabbage and listened to WWOZ and had a glass of wine by myself.

IMUS: Where was James?

MATALIN: Was it after 9:00? If it's after 9:00, he's in bed.

IMUS: So did you stay up and watch the ball come down?

MATALIN: I listened to WWOZ, which is the best jazz in the world -- Irvin Mayfield, jazz play club on Bourbon Street live.

IMUS: Radio?

MATALIN: Yes.

IMUS: Oh, you didn't make that clear.

MATALIN: Oh, I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. I should know everybody doesn't know WWOZ. But if you don't, you can get it live streaming. It's the best jazz.

IMUS: Because Bernie just played a cut of Dick Clark's New Year's Rocking Eve in which Mr. Clark was on. And, of course, he's had a stroke some years ago.

MATALIN: Yes, I saw it on, and I have to take Bernie's side as I do on most things on this. I thought it was an inspiration.

IMUS: You thought it was an inspiration?

MATALIN: I guess you don't.

IMUS: Well, an inspiration to who?

MATALIN: Just what Bernie said. If you've been -- if you've come back from something that -- a disease that people -- or suffered from something that would normally render you hidden away for whatever reason, and you can come back, that's an inspiration to others who are similarly afflicted. Heart disease or cancer or anything, you can talk about it and show people that everything is workable, and life is worth living.

IMUS: Does she have a point, Charles?

MCCORD: Yes, and a point that it need not be in all cases the end and --

MATALIN: Or it can be a different reality.

MCCORD: Exactly. And Mr. Clark is a textbook example of that.

IMUS: Well, but my problem with it is --

MCCORD: What?

IMUS: -- is that whenever it gets played on this program, and the reason that it's intended to be a source of amusement, that's the problem.

MATALIN: So it's not -- so, as always, it's always about you. This is about what, is that you're saying? You didn't like it?

IMUS: Well, guess what? It's 2011. Suddenly, it's not going to be about me this year. Well, of course.

(LAUGHTER)

MATALIN: This is your new New Year's resolution?

IMUS: Well, no, but I don't know --

MCCORD: It could be about him a few years down the road.

IMUS: I just don't -- I don't know. I feel bad for the guy and I don't think it's funny. I mean, you can make it funny. They did make it funny, Bernie and Lou, of course, and Charles.

MCCORD: You made it funny.

IMUS: Huh?

MATALIN: You made it funny. Bernie made it about --

IMUS: Then they made it about me, a window to the future.

MATALIN: You invited it. You invited it by being so --

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I don't invite the ridicule that I constantly get on this program.

MATALIN: Oh.

IMUS: Anyway.

MATALIN: OK.

IMUS: So the Bush tax cuts, I guess, have been extended. What does that mean?

MATALIN: That means these rich bastards who don't need them, you know, are now going to get them.

IMUS: Well, why do you think the president did it?

MATALIN: Because he's -- he just wanted to screw his own guys.

IMUS: Really?

MATALIN: No. None of the above.

IMUS: Well what then?

MATALIN: It's -- I think we -- he did it because he didn't want to be blamed for not doing it. And Larry Summers and everybody else came out and said that reality, which will give us a double-dip recession if taxes are affected in a recession.

IMUS: So you think it's going to have an impact on the economy?

MATALIN: I think the opposite would have had a severe impact, a better impact --

IMUS: That's not what I asked you.

MATALIN: Well, these aren't yes or no questions.

IMUS: Well, answer it as best as you can, as you're capable of.

MATALIN: I'm answering it.

IMUS: By opening the window and choking your cat.

MATALIN: One of the cats, the one that still has a tail.

A better package would have been to have no spending increases and leave the tax structure as it was, and leave the estate tax where it was so people don't make decisions upon -- about their final days based on their tax situation, which I think is immoral. That would have been the better package, but that's not what happened because politics --

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Well, the rap we were hearing, Mary Matalin, is that if we gave the tax cuts to all these rich bastards and these other folks, that that would all -- that they would then invest in the economy and hire more people and all that sort of thing.

So, my question is, do you think that's going to happen?

MATALIN: No, that's the rap that -- that's -- the case for tax cuts as a stimulative economic policy do not --

IMUS: I like that phrase.

MATALIN: -- go to those tax cuts. That was maintaining a tax rate, the changing of which would have exacerbated recessionary problems.

Stimulative taxes -- not all tax cuts are created equal -- would have been further reductions of the top rates, a reduction in the corporate tax rate, eradication of corporate taxes loopholes and such, and tax reform, which the president's talking about. That's stimulative tax policy, not just keeping the same rates. So that's one of their canards.

And what would be most stimulative now is to continue to reduce or make some effort to stop spending and roll back the debt, starting with health care. So that will be the plan, and I hope they get some of it done.

IMUS: And your scummy Republican friends were shamed into caving in on the 9/11 Responders Bill.

MATALIN: In response to scummy liberals, who --

IMUS: And inspired quite a bit by Shep Smith (ph).

MATALIN: -- let it sit there for years and did nothing about it, and wait until it's Christmas Eve and lard it up. Yes, it should have been passed. It should have been passed two years earlier. There shouldn't have been anybody who had any problem getting any health care at any time from 9/11 on.

IMUS: By the way, that's a very good point.

Hey, how are things in New Orleans? You live there now, right?

MATALIN: We're going on year three.

IMUS: Huh?

MATALIN: This is our third year here. It's wonderful.

IMUS: Who is the new mayor there?

MATALIN: He's spectacular.

IMUS: Who is it -- huh?

MATALIN: He's going to be up in New York. He comes a lot. He's got a new police chief.

IMUS: What is his name?

Oh, I'm sorry. Mitch Landrieu, Mayor Mitch.

IMUS: Has he been indicted yet?

MATALIN: We used to -- half the state was under water and other half was under indictment. But we're not like that now. We're all cleaned up now.

IMUS: Happy New Year to you, the kids, him.

MATALIN: And Happy New Year. You'll never be -- you'll always be you, Imus. You'll just always be you.

IMUS: Well, let's hope so. Thank you.

MATALIN: Happy New Year.

IMUS: Mary Matalin.

MCSHANE: All right. Here is the "Fox Business Minute."

Many iPhone users getting some unwanted extra sleep on New Year's Day. There was a glitch in the phone's alarm clock feature. Users who set their alarm for a single wakeup finding it didn't go off when 2011 arrived.

An Apple spokesperson says the fix is in the works and all alarms will work properly starting today. But users in Europe and Asia saying the problem has not yet been fixed.

Vizio, maker of inexpensive flat-TV screens, is looking to expand. "The Wall Street Journal" reports the company wants to branch out into cell phones and tablet computers, and those two products, the Via Phone and the Via Tablet, will be introduced this summer. The announcement comes just days ahead of the Consumer Electronics Show taking place this week in Las Vegas.

And "Little Fockers" holding on to the top spot at the weekend box office. That movie bringing in just over $26 million this past weekend, so it's total now $103 million.

With no other movies -- no new movies being released over the New Year's weekend, the rest of the lineup looks similar to last week. The number two and three movies are still "True Grit" and "TRON Legacy."

As for the futures this morning, they have been higher all morning long, indicating the Wall Street open will be to the upside, as Dow futures are up by 83 points.

And IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business, "The Power to Prosper."

IMUS: Coming up on five minutes to the hour. This portion of the IMUS IN THE MORNING program sponsored by State Bank. Put your business in a better state. Visit statebankofli.com.

Well, coming up next hour, Jeff Greenfield. We'll talk to him, CBS News. And then Stuart Varney.

Is Stuart here today, Connell? Do you know?

MCSHANE: I think he would be, yes. Back to full strength.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, he is. He's here.

IMUS: Oh, he is?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

IMUS: Well, that's unusual, because ordinarily he would stretch one of these New Year's deals into an extra week's vacation, but apparently he's not done that.

Gangsta Mickey is here, and so is Charles Rangel, neither of whom have been on this morning, but they will get on coming up.

It's five minutes now until the hour.

IMUS: Why are you looking at me -- with your mouth hanging open like a $2 suitcase?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Huh?

IMUS: Made you look -- huh? What's the matter?

POWELL: No, it's just another day at the home. That's what it is. Just dropping my fork.

MCCORD: Yes, that's not good.

Hi, dude.

IMUS: What?

MCCORD: When you start dropping your utensils.

IMUS: Well, no. I wasn't eating, you idiot.

POWELL: Well, you freaked out about it though. It's like, "Oh, my fork."

IMUS: I dropped it because I have this tea, and they have hunks of lemon in it. And I eat the lemon.

POWELL: Sucking on a lemon.

MCCORD: Eat the lemon, baby.

IMUS: That's what I had for breakfast.

MCCORD: Eat the worm.

POWELL: So that's what's putting on all those pounds, those lemons and the condiment sandwiches?

IMUS: Yes.

MCCORD: You're going to have to cut out those lemon wedges. Those lemon wedges are killing you, I-Dude.

IMUS: Ballooned up to 153 pounds.

POWELL: Yes, less tomato in your sandwich. Maybe just one slice of onion.

IMUS: I'm not happy with either one of you bastards. Got to get some new blood in here.

BARTLETT: Why don't you do that?

IMUS: Huh?

BARTLETT: Why don't you do that? And let me know how that works out for you.

IMUS: Get old Cara (ph) to call, see what she is he' doing.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTLETT: Yes, she'll commute back and forth from L.A.

IMUS: Did you tell me her new boyfriend died?

BARTLETT: Yes.

POWELL: This is a boyfriend or girlfriend?

BARTLETT: Yes, it's -- I don't know if -- obviously not the one she's dating now.

(REPEAT PACKAGE)

urn:contentItem:51VT-SW41-JBKP-N13Y-00000-00White House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks Southern Areas of Chile; Johnson and Johnson Plans to Bring New Cancer Test to Market; NY Times: Goldman Sachs Invests $450 Million in Facebook; Expedia Dropping American Airlines Fares from its Web Site; iPhone Glitch Causes Alarm Clock Failure on New Year's Day; WSJ: Vizio to Expand Into Cell Phone and Tablet Markets; "Little Fockers" Holds on to Top Spot at Box Office; Interview With Mary Matalin2011-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTBo Dietl, Jeff Greenfield, Mary MatalinNEWSInternational010301cb.220White House Adviser Warns About Debt Ceiling Debate; President Obama Signs 9/11 Health Bill for Ground Zero Workers; 7.1 Magnitude Quake Rocks Southern Areas of Chile; Johnson and Johnson Plans to Bring New Cancer Test to Market; NY Times: Goldman SachsInvests $450 Million in Facebook; Expedia Dropping American Airlines Fares from its Web Site; iPhone Glitch Causes Alarm Clock Failure on New Year's Day; WSJ: Vizio to Expand Into Cell Phone and Tablet Markets; "Little Fockers" Holds on to Top Spot at Box Office; Interview With Mary MatalinDon Imus, Charles McCord, Bernard McGuirk, Connell McShane, Lou Rufino, Dagen McDowell, Shay Ryan, Rob Bartlett, Warner Wolf, Gerri Willis

DON IMUS, HOST: You know, who won the football game last night, Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: This Sunday night game, I don't. I went to the Jets game yesterday, they won, 38-7. But you know that already.

IMUS: Yes, I don't care about the Jets game because they were already in the playoffs. So I don't care about the Seattle Seahawks and the Rams people, but I'll find out apparently from Warner.

MCSHANE: So one of them with - record made the playoffs. I'm being told in my ear, you want to know who won now or no?

IMUS: No, let me find out from Warner, because, Warner likes to tell me stuff like that.

MCSHANE: It is Warner's job.

IMUS: So he didn't go the Victoria's Secret thong deal?

MCDOWELL: No, he went on the Internet to one of these private sales sites and bought drawers on sale.

IMUS: Oh, he got you some -- he got you some of those Hanes -- big old -- them Hanes big beefy drawers.

MCCORD: Off of eBay.

IMUS: All right, time for a Bernard McGuirk briefing, a "Bernie Briefing," sponsored by -- these big old beefy drawers.

MCCORD: That ain't right.

IMUS: Sponsored by P.C. Richard & Son. A hundred and one years they've got it going on. Still going on.

What's up, B?

MCGUIRK: Well, chief, on the "New Year's Rocking Eve" fright night, the TV shows, I confess I was one of the losers who was up at midnight watching. And I was watching Dick Clark --

IMUS: No, don't do this.

MCGUIRK: And -- well, no, no, this is -- this is a big story. There are competing, differing opinions as to whether or not Dick Clark should still be out there. Some people say it's an inspiration, but --

IMUS: No, no. It's too humiliating for him. Whoever is around him shouldn't let him do this. It's terrible.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DICK CLARK, BROADCASTER: But don't you go anywhere.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: Where did that come from?

IMUS: I didn't hear the sound. There's no point in playing it.

MCGUIRK: We have audio here. Lou will play it.

Here, Lou. Go ahead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLARK: Thank you, Ryan, very much. Now, take a look at all the people up on Broadway. I don't know how people pull off this party year after year, but they do a whale of a job. And tonight it will be bigger and better than ever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: Again, some people say that's inspiring, and some people say it's out of place. But in any case, he won the night far and away. He was the most watched show that night of all the broadcast and cable New Year's Eve shows. And God bless poor old Dick Clark.

IMUS: You bastard.

MCGUIRK: What?

IMUS: You evil bastard.

MCGUIRK: Why?

IMUS: You just can't --

MCCORD: Well, he shouldn't be going on.

MCGUIRK: I didn't put him on ABC.

IMUS: No, no.

MCGUIRK: I think he should be on. I think he is an inspiration.

IMUS: Put him on Fox. No. No.

MCCORD: He was just presenting the controversy.

IMUS: You put him on ABC. You can't be. You can't do that. It's horrible.

MCGUIRK: Well, I happen to disagree. I think it's a good thing. I think it's a nice thing. And again, it inspires people who have been ill.

My dad had a stroke, he came back from it. It makes people say, yes, I can do it.

IMUS: I don't know. Here he is on -- who is that Ryan Seacrest? Do you have any sound on that, Big Foot.

MCGUIRK: We have a little -- we have sound. Lou and I have some sound from Ryan Seacrest just before --

IMUS: Well, there's Dick and -- Big Foot, we can't hear any sound on this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Maybe he doesn't want to.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RYAN SEACREST: Sorry. Sorry, not my fault.

CLARK: Happy New Year.

SEACREST: Happy New Year. Great job.

CLARK: Thank you, Ryan. Thank you.

SEACREST: Thank you so much.

Dick Clark, ladies and gentlemen.

Well, we are inside, and it's even warmer in here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCGUIRK: That's a nice thing. The man's been through hell and back. Way to kick off the new year.

Charles, push him. Is he all right?

MCCORD: He's all right, but he's --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Looking to the future.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: You son of a bitch!

MCGUIRK: Tom goes for the easy joke.

IMUS: Call that funny, Charles?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good. Now everybody is --

MCGUIRK: Everybody is waiting to see who is going to say it.

IMUS: Tom.

(LAUGHTER)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, Tom, have you got that clip? Lou?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'll he come up here and I'll find you. Are you coming down here?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just got to e-mail from Neil Cavuto.

IMUS: That's not funny.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I was down at the ranch last we week.

MCCORD: This is not -- stop.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not funny. It's not funny, no.

MCCORD: This is not good.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not funny, Bernard. It's not.

MCGUIRK: Look, God bless Dick Clark, is all I'm saying.

MCCORD: There is an is inspirational story.

MCGUIRK: Yes. That Ryan Seacrest, too.

MCCORD: Yes.

IMUS: No.

MCCORD: You've got to stop.

IMUS: Oh, God.

MCGUIRK: "Blonde on Blonde" is coming up tomorrow.

(LAUGHTER)

IMUS: That's just horrible. God.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Imus at night -- be there.

IMUS: Why do they do that? That's horrible.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Why are they wheeling him out there?

MCGUIRK: No, it's his show. He's as lucid as they come. He just can't speak properly. So why not?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's the way he's going to go out though.

MCGUIRK: So what? That's his choice.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, it's not.

IMUS: That's not right.

MCGUIRK: It was a ratings winner for the night.

IMUS: Well, I don't think it had much to do --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Let's go see how he is?

IMUS: Do you?

MCGUIRK: Ryan Seacrest. You had a bunch of great performers. Kesha was there.

IMUS: Well, Ryan Seacrest, if you get down and you -- I mean, I like him, but if you get down and you scrape the bottom of the show biz barrel, that's where you find Ryan Seacrest. I mean, he's on the E! Channel, for God's sake.

MCGUIRK: He's "American Idol." He's at the top of his game, that guys.

IMUS: Oh, whatever. He's at the bottom of the barrel. He may be at the top of the game, but --

(MUSIC)

IMUS: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program. Time now for a business update from the Fox Business Network. Here's Connell McShane.

MCSHANE: And when Congress gets back to work on Wednesday, California Congressman Darrell Issa getting a big promotion. He'll become the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, which basically means he'll be the one or heading up the committee that oversees the government.

And appearing on "Fox News Sunday," Issa telling Chris Wallace he's going to target government spending.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: We have about $1.7 trillion worth of regulatory costs already in the government. If the president wants to throw another $300 or $400 billion, what he's doing is taking it right out of businesses, right out of employment, right out of competitiveness. We need to make sure we can compete.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Issa has indicated he's going to call a lot of hearings as committee chairman on topics including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and also Medicare.

Checking in on the markets here this morning for you, up all morning long. And we are indicated higher on the futures by 85 points now on Dow futures. It looks like a strong start to the new year coming on Wall Street in just a little while.

It's the IMUS IN THE MORNING program that continues right now with a check of the forecast.

(WEATHER REPORT)

IMUS: Twenty minutes until the hour here on the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, on the radio all over the country, and on the Fox Business Network all over the world. Three new radio affiliates today -- WAUB, 1590, way up there on the right-hand side of the dial where the dogs can listen, and at 94.1 FM here in Auburn, New York.

MCCORD: But you can't.

IMUS: On WGBA, 1240 on the dial there in Geneva, New York, Finger Lakes News Radio. And KWKC, 1340 AM, in Abilene, Texas, Talk Radio 1340.

Tomorrow, on this program, Tom Friedman. Wednesday, "Blonde on Blonde."

Please welcome now to the IMUS IN THE MORNING program, our old friend, former assistant to the president, vice president, a bunch of other stuff, Mary Matlin.

Good morning, Ms. Matalin.

MARY MATALIN, FMR. ASSISTANT TO VICE PRESIDENT CHENEY: Here, kitty kitty. Hey. Good morning. Happy New Year.

IMUS: Are you calling the cat?

MATALIN: Hey, kitty, kitty, kitty. Here, kitty kitty. She was trapped outside and was about to unleash the dogs of my hell, my mini dachshund. I said, "Kitty."

It irritates I-Man. He doesn't want to hear you.

IMUS: I like cats and dogs. What's your cat's name?

MATALIN: Witchy. She has one green eye and one blue eye.

IMUS: Why are you out of breath?

MATALIN: Because I had to move the chair, open the shades, and open the window from the bottom up, while I was holding the phone in my ear. And I'm old now.

IMUS: Did you -- what did you do New Year's Eve?

MATALIN: Made black eyed peas and cabbage and listened to WWOZ and had a glass of wine by myself.

IMUS: Where was James?

MATALIN: Was it after 9:00? If it's after 9:00, he's in bed.

IMUS: So did you stay up and watch the ball come down?

MATALIN: I listened to WWOZ, which is the best jazz in the world -- Irvin Mayfield, jazz play club on Bourbon Street live.

IMUS: Radio?

MATALIN: Yes.

IMUS: Oh, you didn't make that clear.

MATALIN: Oh, I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. I should know everybody doesn't know WWOZ. But if you don't, you can get it live streaming. It's the best jazz.

IMUS: Because Bernie just played a cut of Dick Clark's New Year's Rocking Eve in which Mr. Clark was on. And, of course, he's had a stroke some years ago.

MATALIN: Yes, I saw it on, and I have to take Bernie's side as I do on most things on this. I thought it was an inspiration.

IMUS: You thought it was an inspiration?

MATALIN: I guess you don't.

IMUS: Well, an inspiration to who?

MATALIN: Just what Bernie said. If you've been -- if you've come back from something that -- a disease that people -- or suffered from something that would normally render you hidden away for whatever reason, and you can come back, that's an inspiration to others who are similarly afflicted. Heart disease or cancer or anything, you can talk about it and show people that everything is workable, and life is worth living.

IMUS: Does she have a point, Charles?

MCCORD: Yes, and a point that it need not be in all cases the end and --

MATALIN: Or it can be a different reality.

MCCORD: Exactly. And Mr. Clark is a textbook example of that.

IMUS: Well, but my problem with it is --

MCCORD: What?

IMUS: -- is that whenever it gets played on this program, and the reason that it's intended to be a source of amusement, that's the problem.

MATALIN: So it's not -- so, as always, it's always about you. This is about what, is that you're saying? You didn't like it?

IMUS: Well, guess what? It's 2011. Suddenly, it's not going to be about me this year. Well, of course.

(LAUGHTER)

MATALIN: This is your new New Year's resolution?

IMUS: Well, no, but I don't know --

MCCORD: It could be about him a few years down the road.

IMUS: I just don't -- I don't know. I feel bad for the guy and I don't think it's funny. I mean, you can make it funny. They did make it funny, Bernie and Lou, of course, and Charles.

MCCORD: You made it funny.

IMUS: Huh?

MATALIN: You made it funny. Bernie made it about --

IMUS: Then they made it about me, a window to the future.

MATALIN: You invited it. You invited it by being so --

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: I don't invite the ridicule that I constantly get on this program.

MATALIN: Oh.

IMUS: Anyway.

MATALIN: OK.

IMUS: So the Bush tax cuts, I guess, have been extended. What does that mean?

MATALIN: That means these rich bastards who don't need them, you know, are now going to get them.

IMUS: Well, why do you think the president did it?

MATALIN: Because he's -- he just wanted to screw his own guys.

IMUS: Really?

MATALIN: No. None of the above.

IMUS: Well what then?

MATALIN: It's -- I think we -- he did it because he didn't want to be blamed for not doing it. And Larry Summers and everybody else came out and said that reality, which will give us a double-dip recession if taxes are affected in a recession.

IMUS: So you think it's going to have an impact on the economy?

MATALIN: I think the opposite would have had a severe impact, a better impact --

IMUS: That's not what I asked you.

MATALIN: Well, these aren't yes or no questions.

IMUS: Well, answer it as best as you can, as you're capable of.

MATALIN: I'm answering it.

IMUS: By opening the window and choking your cat.

MATALIN: One of the cats, the one that still has a tail.

A better package would have been to have no spending increases and leave the tax structure as it was, and leave the estate tax where it was so people don't make decisions upon -- about their final days based on their tax situation, which I think is immoral. That would have been the better package, but that's not what happened because politics --

(CROSSTALK)

IMUS: Well, the rap we were hearing, Mary Matalin, is that if we gave the tax cuts to all these rich bastards and these other folks, that that would all -- that they would then invest in the economy and hire more people and all that sort of thing.

So, my question is, do you think that's going to happen?

MATALIN: No, that's the rap that -- that's -- the case for tax cuts as a stimulative economic policy do not --

IMUS: I like that phrase.

MATALIN: -- go to those tax cuts. That was maintaining a tax rate, the changing of which would have exacerbated recessionary problems.

Stimulative taxes -- not all tax cuts are created equal -- would have been further reductions of the top rates, a reduction in the corporate tax rate, eradication of corporate taxes loopholes and such, and tax reform, which the president's talking about. That's stimulative tax policy, not just keeping the same rates. So that's one of their canards.

And what would be most stimulative now is to continue to reduce or make some effort to stop spending and roll back the debt, starting with health care. So that will be the plan, and I hope they get some of it done.

IMUS: And your scummy Republican friends were shamed into caving in on the 9/11 Responders Bill.

MATALIN: In response to scummy liberals, who --

IMUS: And inspired quite a bit by Shep Smith (ph).

MATALIN: -- let it sit there for years and did nothing about it, and wait until it's Christmas Eve and lard it up. Yes, it should have been passed. It should have been passed two years earlier. There shouldn't have been anybody who had any problem getting any health care at any time from 9/11 on.

IMUS: By the way, that's a very good point.

Hey, how are things in New Orleans? You live there now, right?

MATALIN: We're going on year three.

IMUS: Huh?

MATALIN: This is our third year here. It's wonderful.

IMUS: Who is the new mayor there?

MATALIN: He's spectacular.

IMUS: Who is it -- huh?

MATALIN: He's going to be up in New York. He comes a lot. He's got a new police chief.

IMUS: What is his name?

Oh, I'm sorry. Mitch Landrieu, Mayor Mitch.

IMUS: Has he been indicted yet?

MATALIN: We used to -- half the state was under water and other half was under indictment. But we're not like that now. We're all cleaned up now.

IMUS: Happy New Year to you, the kids, him.

MATALIN: And Happy New Year. You'll never be -- you'll always be you, Imus. You'll just always be you.

IMUS: Well, let's hope so. Thank you.

MATALIN: Happy New Year.

IMUS: Mary Matalin.

MCSHANE: All right. Here is the "Fox Business Minute."

Many iPhone users getting some unwanted extra sleep on New Year's Day. There was a glitch in the phone's alarm clock feature. Users who set their alarm for a single wakeup finding it didn't go off when 2011 arrived.

An Apple spokesperson says the fix is in the works and all alarms will work properly starting today. But users in Europe and Asia saying the problem has not yet been fixed.

Vizio, maker of inexpensive flat-TV screens, is looking to expand. "The Wall Street Journal" reports the company wants to branch out into cell phones and tablet computers, and those two products, the Via Phone and the Via Tablet, will be introduced this summer. The announcement comes just days ahead of the Consumer Electronics Show taking place this week in Las Vegas.

And "Little Fockers" holding on to the top spot at the weekend box office. That movie bringing in just over $26 million this past weekend, so it's total now $103 million.

With no other movies -- no new movies being released over the New Year's weekend, the rest of the lineup looks similar to last week. The number two and three movies are still "True Grit" and "TRON Legacy."

As for the futures this morning, they have been higher all morning long, indicating the Wall Street open will be to the upside, as Dow futures are up by 83 points.

And IMUS IN THE MORNING continues right now on Fox Business, "The Power to Prosper."

IMUS: Coming up on five minutes to the hour. This portion of the IMUS IN THE MORNING program sponsored by State Bank. Put your business in a better state. Visit statebankofli.com.

Well, coming up next hour, Jeff Greenfield. We'll talk to him, CBS News. And then Stuart Varney.

Is Stuart here today, Connell? Do you know?

MCSHANE: I think he would be, yes. Back to full strength.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, he is. He's here.

IMUS: Oh, he is?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

IMUS: Well, that's unusual, because ordinarily he would stretch one of these New Year's deals into an extra week's vacation, but apparently he's not done that.

Gangsta Mickey is here, and so is Charles Rangel, neither of whom have been on this morning, but they will get on coming up.

It's five minutes now until the hour.

IMUS: Why are you looking at me -- with your mouth hanging open like a $2 suitcase?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Huh?

IMUS: Made you look -- huh? What's the matter?

POWELL: No, it's just another day at the home. That's what it is. Just dropping my fork.

MCCORD: Yes, that's not good.

Hi, dude.

IMUS: What?

MCCORD: When you start dropping your utensils.

IMUS: Well, no. I wasn't eating, you idiot.

POWELL: Well, you freaked out about it though. It's like, "Oh, my fork."

IMUS: I dropped it because I have this tea, and they have hunks of lemon in it. And I eat the lemon.

POWELL: Sucking on a lemon.

MCCORD: Eat the lemon, baby.

IMUS: That's what I had for breakfast.

MCCORD: Eat the worm.

POWELL: So that's what's putting on all those pounds, those lemons and the condiment sandwiches?

IMUS: Yes.

MCCORD: You're going to have to cut out those lemon wedges. Those lemon wedges are killing you, I-Dude.

IMUS: Ballooned up to 153 pounds.

POWELL: Yes, less tomato in your sandwich. Maybe just one slice of onion.

IMUS: I'm not happy with either one of you bastards. Got to get some new blood in here.

BARTLETT: Why don't you do that?

IMUS: Huh?

BARTLETT: Why don't you do that? And let me know how that works out for you.

IMUS: Get old Cara (ph) to call, see what she is he' doing.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTLETT: Yes, she'll commute back and forth from L.A.

IMUS: Did you tell me her new boyfriend died?

BARTLETT: Yes.

POWELL: This is a boyfriend or girlfriend?

BARTLETT: Yes, it's -- I don't know if -- obviously not the one she's dating now.

(REPEAT PACKAGE)
