urn:contentItem:5TSJ-HK11-DXH2-60J2-00000-00White House Backs Down From Legal Fight, Restores Jim Acosta's Press; Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, Is Arrested Over Financial Misconduct Allegations; Tech & Media Outlook 2019; Tips For Making The Holiday Season Work Financially2018-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Steve Forbes, Sean Spicer, Chris HoganNEWSDomestic112003cb.231White House Backs Down From Legal Fight, Restores Jim Acosta's Press; Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, Is Arrested Over Financial Misconduct Allegations; Tech & Media Outlook 2019; Tips For Making The Holiday Season Work FinanciallyMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Cheryl Casone, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, November 20th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Global markets are in sell-off mode and we are at the lows of the morning right now. Looks like it's going to be a 300-point sell-off right out of the gate this morning.

Dow Industrials right now down 288 points. Better than one percent lower on the Dow, the NASDAQ and the S&P 500. The NASDAQ down 115 points right now. That's 1-3/4 percent lower extending a sharp decline of yesterday. Take a look at the damage yesterday with the Dow and the S&P 500 were both down roughly 1-1/2 percent apiece but the real weakness was technology and the NASDAQ slid three percent on the session 220 points lower yesterday.

This morning is no different, we're looking at declines across the board and some of the biggest names in the sector and the premarket, Facebook down two percent, Amazon down almost three percent as is Apple. Netflix down better than three percent. Alphabet, parent of Google down almost two percent down across the board on tech. Global markets are following the U.S. lower.

European Indices are down across the board, the FT-100 down a half of a percent, 34 points lower. The CAC Quarante in Paris down better than one percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down 1-1/4 percent right now. In Asia overnight, declines across the board as well as you can see there. Meanwhile, from the tech wreck to the retail route, Target, Lowe's and Kohl's all under pressure this morning on earnings.

Target and Lowe's same-store sales missed expectations. Kohl's stock is down almost 10 percent right now. 9-1/2 percent down on Kohl's, reporting better-than-expected results and raising guidance. The people are not happy with the same-store situations. Target down 9-1/3 percent as you can see there. Lower's down six percent, down across the board. Meanwhile, the future of the Renault-Nissan Alliance hangs in the balance this morning.

Leaders from France to Japan, looking to take action following the shocking news of the arrest of Carlos Ghosn. We have the very latest this morning. The ultimate gift guide. Courtesy of Gwyneth Paltrow. You won't believe some of the items on goops list from marble dumbbells to an entire Spanish village. Yes. We've got it for you.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Forbes media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes and CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Good to see you this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good to be here. Man, that retail, those same store sales numbers are weaker than expected, those retails are down worse than techs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And meanwhile, we just had on the former CEO Toys"R"Us who said it's going to be a terrific black Friday, terrific fourth quarter. So what are missing here?

BELL: Well, I think that -- well, some of these same-store sales numbers came in just slightly below expectations but I think what the problem is we look out to the fourth, last year was a blockbuster fourth quarter. So the question is, are we going to be able to beat those exceptional numbers.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: The CEOs of these companies feel very good about it but then also I think people worried about inventory and most importantly, Steve, you pointed this out earlier, we're getting to 2019, tariffs that they got from 10 percent to 25 percent if they go on the additional 267 billion that's left out there, then we're going to have major problems at retailer.

BARTIROMO: And Jerry Storch made the -- made the comment that it's really margins under pressure for these companies.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. If you have to raise prices, that's great but the margin pressure comes if you have tariffs slapped on your goods that you're importing from China, and then you can't raise the prices that puts pressure on your with margins and then also that -- you have company -- again, it's not just about consumer prices and the - - oh your little can of soup isn't going up that much.

It's about essentially disrupting business and introducing uncertainty where there wasn't any, to a vast array of businesses in this country.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Yes. Huge complicated supply chains are going to be disrupted. These tariffs are going to hit profit margins saying, yes, will consumers pay more, will consumers don't like to pay more? That's going to impact them next year. And the longer they allow this trade thing to drag out the worse it's going to be. And the markets in unmerciful mood, any slight thing and they will smash you, not good sign.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We got all of that coming up this morning. Joining the conversation this hour, former White House Secretary Sean Spicer is here. The founder and partner of Activate, Michael Wolf is going to walk us through what's going on with technology and media. And the host of Varney & Varney, Stuart Varney weighs in as well. Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big hour coming up right here.

We kick it off right here with the tech wreck taking a toll on Wall Street. Lauren Simonetti is on the floor of the New York Stock exchange with that and the retail rout this morning. And Lauren, technology took the market down sharply yesterday. Looks like it's doing the same this morning.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Basically since Apple reported their latest earnings, investors are saying what is going on with Apple and we keep getting new news every day. The news today is Goldman Sachs came out and they cut their price target on the stock to $182 from $209. Why is that important? Well, that would be bear market territory. Apple is near bear market territory right now but down in the premarket, it probably gets there by the end of the day.

Two things they noted, Goldman says there is weakness in demand for Apple products in China, and the 10R is not being well-received thus far. Let's talk about retail getting killed today and a lot of the stores that are reporting here saying, why are they getting killed? Let's talk about Kohl's n general. Good news it's being sold. They raised their forecast, double beat but the stock is down and down in a big way.

Same-store sales a little bit light, investors also might have wanted more from that increase, forecast for earnings on the year. Target, the CEO comes out and says they are better position for this holiday than ever before. They grew their e-commerce sales 49 percent but with that fulfilling those orders, their margins are getting squeezed, this stock is getting hit hard and Lowe's is down in a big way as well. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thank you so much. We'll be watching what all this means for the open which we are looking at now, could be a 300- point selloff in the Dow Industrials at the opening of trading in an hour and half. Meanwhile, new rules at the White House. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders releasing new mandates that news conferences which state this.

Journalists will ask a single question and then will yield the floor to others. A follow-up question may be permitted at the discretion of the President. Failure to respect these rules may result in suspension or cancellation of a journalist's hard pass. This outline of course coming after officials dropped the effort to suspend CNN reporter Jim Acosta's press pass.

Joining us right now is former White House Press Secretary under President Trump, America First action PAC, senior advisor and author of the briefing book, Sean Spicer. Sean, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

SEAN SPICER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Good morning. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: New rules after the whole Acosta mess, a couple of weeks ago. What's your reaction to all of this?

SPICER: Well, I think it's sad and unfortunate that it's come to this. You have to mandate professional behavior and decorum because a few bad apples are trying to make it about themselves and make a show of what is supposed to be an opportunity for journalists to ask the President questions. As you saw at that press conferences up 100 plus members of the media from all sorts of backgrounds and publications that are seeking to ask the President of the United States a question.

And yet one journalist in particular wants to monopolize it for himself and make it into the Acosta show. So I think in the past, there have been sort of unwritten rules in terms of how you behave respect the office of the President. This one individual is clearly blown through them now we have come to the point we've got to treat them looks like children rules and now we've come to the point where we've got to treat them like children.

And put down rules and regulations so that people can actually behave and it's not just about the President, right? I think mostly comes out to treating other journalists with the respect that they deserve.

BARTIROMO: I don't think there's anything negative to have certain rules for decorum when you're speaking to the office of the President. I mean, I don't -- what do you guys think? I mean, I want to stand with journalist but at the same time I think there should be a respect for office of the President.

MCDOWELL: But if the White House had done this first Sean and just said, here are the rules of conduct that we're going to lay out rather than just pulling the guy's hard card. Again, you kind of -- you end up losing, you know, losing that initial battle. This happens over and over again where it seems like that somebody at the White House is behaving rationally and not stepping back in taking a breath which quite frankly the President just done when Jim Acosta was trying to grab that mic or keep the microphone from that young woman.

If he just stepped back and folded his arms and said nothing and said, I'm ending this press conference in five minutes unless Jim Acosta sits down, again, he would have won and it wouldn't have be a win for Jim Acosta.

SPICER: Yes. I think that's partially right and -- but I --and as I said at the outset, I think it's unfortunate that it's come to this because you won't -- you've been able to exist all along without having to go this route. I think that what it's going to mean is -- you know, I agree with Dagen in the sense that I don't know why he called him in the first place. But if you don't call on him then they -- then they do the antics as well and they start going, I haven't been called on any yells and he jumps up and down and disrupts them in the first place.

So the court basically said that the CNN in this case, Jim Acosta had a Fifth Amendment right to due process. So the White House is basically complying with the court order and saying great, then we will have a process, put in place, we will notify them what the -- what the rules are, and what the procedures will be if you violate them.

But this is a result of a court order that said that in this particular case, that there was not necessarily a first amendment right to enter the White House but that there was a Fifth Amendment due process rule to ensure that there was a way to know that what they violated and that there were rules so that they could follow in the first place.

FORBES: That gets to the whole thing, Sean, and that is -- there's no law that says the White House has to have these press conferences, they can set the rules any rules they want. And so the court I think was stretching things. The White House can could whatever it wants on the - on the -- on press availability with the press.

BARTIROMO: And not only that but CNN has been criticizing and poking President Trump for the last two years. And then he fights back and then it's like this big thing fighting back.

BELL: Well, I think this makes it just these press conferences much more orderly. This is how corporate earnings calls go for a lot of these bigger companies you get one question and you move to the next analyst.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point.

BELL: What's so wrong with that?

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

SPICER: Yes, I mean -- and look, and here is the thing, it's just -- I think it's sad and unfortunate all around because I think Steve is right, you don't have to have a press conference, you don't have to call on reporters, you don't have to do a lot of things but I think it's good for democracy that the President of the United States from time to time gets up and as he does so often engages with these members of the press so that they can ask their questions. I think it's good for --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Well, I don't know about that. I mean -- I mean, we are living in America where we have free speech and we are, you know, I mean they have to answer reporter's questions. I'm not saying that. I mean, when you say they don't have to --

(CROSSTALK)

SPICER: No, no, no. What I'm saying is --

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess so. But you do have to speak to the press. You do have to --

SPICER: Correct.

BARTIROMO: -- you know, answer questions. I'm just saying the way that he put on such a show that it was all about him I think there should be a level of decorum at the White House.

SPICER: I agree and that's what I'm -- I think that we should engage with the press, it's very healthy for democracy, it's great for the rest of the world to witness us doing this but I think at some point, here is what is think is missing in this discussion and I think it was sad and opportunity was missed by both CNN and the White House Correspondents Association which is this, they should have come forward and say, you know what, we believe in a free press.

We believe in access, we believe in transparency, but we also acknowledge that there are rules of decorum and professionalism that should stand as the model for our industry of journalists.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SPICER: And they failed to do that and I think that that speaks volumes about the state of journalism today where they defend this kind of inappropriate unprofessional behavior that is not only disrespectful to the President of the United States but disrespectful to other journalists.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's right. And let me -- let me get to this because there's so much dishonesty going on around this story as well. In fact, I saw it, I have to say on CNN this morning and it was incredibly dishonest. Ivanka Trump's lawyer is slamming this report that is alleging that the President's daughter used her private e-mail for government business. Her attorney says, Ivanka followed protocols like those who transitioned into government before her.

His statement reads in part. To address misinformation being pedaled about Ms. Trump's personal e-mail, she did not create a private server in her house or officer. There was never classified information transmitted. The account was never transferred our housed at Trump organization. No e-mails were ever deleted and the e-mails have been retained in official account in conformity with records preservation laws and rules.

So, the bottom line is CNN this morning was going crazy about this hypocrisy that Ivanka Trump used a private e-mails. The issue around Hillary Clinton was the fact that she had a server in her home, so there was nothing stopping her from just deleting anything she wanted because they weren't in White House, Sean. So again, so much dishonesty in the media about this story. What's your reaction, Sean?

SPICER: Well, exactly, but actually I think the bigger issue was Hillary Clinton was transmitting sensitive and classified information on an unsecured nongovernment e-mail, that was the bigger thing and then she tried to cover it up. And here is the thing that's interesting in that statement. Understand one thing that what is important about the statement that Ivanka's lawyer issued is that if you use a private e-mail which you're right. Maria, many government officials do.

The question isn't whether you use it, it's whether or not you forward it your government e-mail or preserve it, that's the key so that the government has a record of government transactions occurring. So it's not a question of using it or not, there are rules about using a personal e- mail in government service and it's just ensuring that if you do conduct government business even if it's just routine correspondence then it's actually housed and maintained for the presidential records act and other applicable laws which she did.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You can't have a record of it if the server is in your basement. Sean, thank you. Sean Spicer.

SPICER: You bet, guys.

BARTIROMO: Back in a moment with Carlos Ghosn and the (INAUDIBLE) shake- up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The fallout is continuing this morning following the arrest of Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. Ghosn -- well, we should add to this now. France's finance minister says that he should no longer lead Renault as the company's CEO and chairman. Renault's board reportedly going to meet today to discuss his replacement. Nissan set to fire him later this week. Ghosn is taken into custody of course in Japan yesterday for allegedly reporting a salary and there are other charges of financial misconduct.

Now, Ghosn's arrest also raising questions about the Renault-Nissan Alliance which sells more than 10 million vehicles a year. Board of Ghosn's arrest in Japan hitting Asian stocks hard today. Shares of Nissan closed down nearly six percent yesterday.

Well, California's raging wildfires now responsible for 82 deaths, 700 people are still missing with crews warning some people may never be found due to intensity of the flames. Some relief though could be on a way, four to six of rain is in the forecast but officials are worried about these heavy downpours because could trigger mudslides and already devastated areas.

Well switching gears, "MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL," pretty cool last night. The Los Angeles Rams and the Kansas City Chiefs honoring the first responders that worked tirelessly to combat the wildfires as well as those were first on the scene at the Borderline Bar & Grill shooting back on November 7th. Now the game itself, the Rams came up on top in the highest scoring "MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL" game ever. The final scores, Rams 54, Chiefs 51.

105 points. That's the third most of any NFL game and it was the first time two teams scored more than 50 in the same game. I think Steve Forbes said, where was the defense. Good point, Steve.

All right. Gwyneth Paltrow's lifestyle brand Goop has released its gifts guide for the holidays. The annual list known for being eco parts, nonsensical and expensive. One item that made the list this year, marble dumbbell. It's 2.2 pounds, it's $100 for one dumbbell. Then there's this, a banana lamp with a golden finish, that's $340 because he doesn't to pay $40.00 for that and if you really want to spend a lot of money, Goop has an entire Spanish village (INAUDIBLE) it can be all yours for just $172,000, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

CASONE: The Ridiculousness starts now for Christmas. Just letting you know.

BARTIROMO: No words.

CASONE: There will be more of these.

MCDOWELL: She apparently is bringing -- is inking a deal for Goop with Netflix.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MCDOWELL: So if you are -- if you are already annoyed by Gwyneth Paltrow, prepare to be more annoyed. Some of the garbage that Goop site has sold over the years, it's just --

BARTIROMO: I mean, a marble dumbbell, I guess that's just --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Right. Is that supposed to be like a statue, you're not using the dumbbells.

BELL: It's peeling crystals.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And the banana peel with gold.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: This is me self-editing.

BARTIROMO: Don't get me that for Christmas.

MCDOWELL: I -- you know what I will never --

BARTIROMO: You promise?

MCDOWELL: I promise to never, ever, ever buy you anything from Goop ever.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back. Screen time concerns. We are breaking down the alarming report about how much time Americans are spending glue to their phones. What do you think? Plus, Activate founder and partner, Michael Wolf weighs in on that and a lot more. Back in a moment right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tech revolution Activate's annual technology and media outlook report forecast the most important trends to watch for 2019 transformation from e-commerce to smart camera, even sports betting. The report finds Americans will spend an additional 11 minutes a day, every day with tech and media by the year 2022 bringing the total time per day spent with technology to 12 hours, 32 minutes.

Joining me right now is the founder and writer of that report, Activate founder and CEO Michael Wolff. Michael, it's great to see you.

MICHAEL WOLF, FOUNDER AND CEO, ACTIVATE, INC.: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Before we get to the report, your thoughts on what's happening with this tech wreck. You see companies like Amazon, Facebook, Netflix falling out of bed as people worry about growth, any thoughts?

WOLF: Well, I mean, first of all, they've lost cumulative over the last six weeks, they've lost about $700 billion in value. And so they drove the market up and they're driving the market down. There is a bunch of things that are concerning people. One of them is privacy and what's happened with Facebook in the last couple -- really in the last couple weeks. The other is, of course, security.

And there is also concern like how much more growth can they go through. I believe that these companies are going to continue to grow, I think that the biggest Black Friday bargain is Amazon because Amazon is going to continue to grow, they're going to continue to add a lot of revenue. And I don't think that Facebook's privacy problems are really going to have much of an impact on revenue. I mean, they may have --

BARTIROMO: OK.

WOLF: People may delete the app but with two billion users, advertisers are hooked on Facebook.

BARTIROMO: You would think. That's where the growth is the economy. So, you know, we're seeing an investor reaction but really when you look at the growth what's happening that's what you're writing about. Let's talk about your outlook report, the reports finding that we're spending more and more time on technology. What struck you most about this year's report?

WOLF: I think there are a couple things. One of them is smart cameras that the average American within three years is going to have 12 smart cameras in their homes. So we're talking about things like the ring camera, others cameras in their kitchens that help really cook, the camera on your car and what's fascinating as much as you might think people are worried about privacy, in reality all of our research shows that the people who were the most worried about privacy are the most likely buy a smart camera or own one.

BARTIROMO: Well, a smart camera is what? Like that I could pull up the cameras on my phone which a lot of people can do right now with their -- with their alarm systems, but the cameras talk to each other.

WOLF: The cameras talk to each other and it's not just the camera that talks to you, it's the people within neighborhoods are linking the other -- their cameras and either looking at ring for example from Amazon has an app that allows you to look at what's going on in your neighborhood and report things.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

WOLF: And lot of it's going in to the processing using A.I., so you know what's going on but you also can do a bunch of things that are predicting the camera in your kitchen that helps you cook. It's going to be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. So the cameras talking to each other and that's forming an intelligent network.

WOLF: And intelligent network, so it's not just the cameras in your homes, the cameras in the car, so they go together, to all the cars can talk to each other, they can talk to the cameras on light poles, they can talk to the camera on your phone. We're going to see a lot more intelligence in the network and it's going to enable things like self-driving cars.

BARTIROMO: What about E-commerce? Let's talk there because E-commerce growth dollars will surpass physical growth dollars from three trillion to six trillion you write by 2022.

WOLF: It -- this year is the inflection point. And so we've got e- commerce got dollars that are growing about 20 percent. We've got physical retail which continues to grow but only around two percent. So we're going to see consumers are going to be buying a lot more and the we've got -- if you look at the biggest companies, it's -- the biggest is Alibaba, it's followed by Amazon, then you go JD.com, and then you've got eBay.

And all of them are going -- are going to continue to see growth. What's fascinating is they're all marketplaces. They're really not --

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's interesting.

WOLF: They're not actually holding inventory, they're just selling other people's stuff.

BARTIROMO: That's fascinating actually. All right. Online betting is another item that's highlighted in the -- in the report. Online sports betting projected the industry to explode from six billion to 119 billion?

WOLF: 119 billion, a lot of it is money that was illegally bet, and now it's going to be coming online. This is all the big tech companies are going to benefit as well. So sports leagues and E-sports, and by the way, even the enterprise companies like Oracle. So it's going to end up being within three years about $35 billion in incremental revenue for tech and media. None of which is there -- so it -- today, so it really reflects my optimism for the stocks and the growth in these companies.

BARTIROMO: So where is the growth? When you look at this whole space of technology and media, what do you think are the most important growth takeaways that we should understand about where this industry is going?

WOLF: So, I think that we're still going to see a lot of advertising going from traditional media into these -- into these companies. We're -- it certainly going to be E-commerce, it's going to be new devices like the smart camera, still more home speakers and then finally we're going to see a lot of video out there. People -- we -- it's not just Netflix, it's Amazon, it's Hulu, so many of these companies.

BARTIROMO: Even Apple.

WOLF: Apple.

BARTIROMO: They're starting a streaming service.

WOLF: They're starting a streaming service. I'm not -- I'm not convinced that Apple is truly going to be a competitor to these others but YouTube with Google is already -- they're already starting YouTube premium and so it -- in each case it's new revenue streams coming in. I mean, betting is going to be enormous and we don't see this today in anybody's P&L.

BARTIROMO: Do you see new policies, regulations putting a hamper on any of this? I mean, the growth stories are still in place, and yet these stocks are falling out of bed because I think some people are worried about regulation because these companies keep getting more powerful and more powerful.

WOLF: It's not clear that regulation can do much, I mean, we -- I recall myself a technology determinist, which is anything people can do with technology, they're going to do, so there can be regulations but these industries are different, they're not like telecom where you're regulating a pipe. So, there's going to be some things I think that Facebook and others are going to identify where advertisements come from because there is this concern about people hacking elections, and it's not just foreign or -- foreign companies or government, it's also within the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLF: But I'm not convinced there's going to be a lot of regulation, the main thing is going to be the antitrust concerns, and the Time Warner merger ultimately has gone through. And a lot of that isn't just about concerns about monopolies and control, a lot of it is just political.

BARTIROMO: You doubt -- I mean, I would expect that this is not going to impact the innovation story because the innovation story is very much in place. I mean, the things that you've just brought up in terms of your report show real innovation, whether it's smart cameras, the online betting, or e-commerce.

WOLF: Artificial intelligence is going to be a massive enabler across most of these industries. I think we're going to see a great deal more functionality, even the phones. We're at a point where the phone has gotten very sophisticated would you could do with the phone is going to continue to grow and continue to play a bigger part on people's lives. And there's a lot of money that's going to flow from other places that hasn't been there.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Michael, it's great to see you so.

WOLF: Great to be here. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Congratulations on another fantastic report. Michael Wolf, a founder of Activate. We'll see you soon, Michael.

Coming up, technology titans tumbling. We're watching Silicon Valley giants this morning after yesterday's big selloff, and more selling this morning. And then, gift-giving guilt next. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, November 20th, your top stories right now 8:35 a.m. on the East Coast. Futures headed lower this morning. Again, we're at the lows of the morning with a decline of almost 300 points right now on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, down one percent. We're expecting the S&P to be down one percent as well. And the NASDAQ to be down almost two percent, out of the open, this morning. NASDAQ is down 115 points right now.

Technologies stocks bringing the markets down, that's what happened yesterday. Google parent, Alphabet joining Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix in bear market territory. Apple, also, very close to bear market territory this morning. The technology giants hit in the premarket. Goldman Sachs cutting its price target on Apple from 209 to 182. I'm not sure how to get to 122 at Goldman, but stock is down 2-2/3 percent on that news this morning.

European indices down across the board as well. Take a look, we're looking at selling, it's getting worse, down 33 points on the FT-100, half a percent. CAC Quarante in Paris down better than one percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down 1-1/4 percent right now, 135 points lower there. We are looking at Asian markets, also down across the board, closing lower overnight, as you can see, down two percent apiece on Shanghai and Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Retailers are reporting today, and the reaction from investors is not good. Best Buy out with its better-than-expected numbers that beat both on earnings and revenue compared to estimates. TJX Companies also hitting the tape moments ago, the company behind TJ Maxx, Marshalls, and HomeGoods also missed on earnings expectations. TJX is down three percent, and Ross Stores is down almost eight percent. We are also looking at the rest of the sector, down across the board.

Meanwhile, we just got a look at the housing market, the October housing starts coming in slightly higher than expected, the building permit number is slightly lower than expected. We've got housing starts looking -- we were expecting a weak showing here, Steve Forbes, but it looks to me like it's a miss in terms of housing starts. What's your take?

FORBES: It is -- it is a mix, and once interest rates -- once people can get used to four, five percent mortgages and this economy continues to grow, so we get China out of the way, which I think we will, that market will recover. We forget we grew up with four or five percent mortgages. And once that shock is over, I think housing will come back as the economy comes back.

BELL: I think, though, that the problem is that you have first-time buyers going out there, and we've seen interest rates -- Dagen always point this out -- in the mid-2016, the 10-year was at 1.16, something like that. Now, we're twice that. So, that moved up so quickly makes a difference. And if you're a first-time buyer, you're looking at that change in interest rates, and it makes a difference on your mortgage payments. So, this isn't the weakness in the housing market. It isn't -- this is kind of a reminder, it's nothing new. The existing home sales we get tomorrow have been down year-over-year for seven months in a row now. And that the decline is increasing.

MCDOWELL: In order for like these houses to make sense at higher mortgage rates, you look at a house like in Connecticut, it's for sale for a million and a half dollars. If you go back to mortgage rates that were eight percent which is kind of the longer -- about in the ballpark of the longer- term average over the last several decades, eight percent mortgage takes that home price -- what did it sell for in the early 90s -- less than $400,000. It was like a $300,000 house is now selling for a million and a half dollars, so I think that you have to -- that's the grave worry here is that housing prices, in order to move the inventory that's piling up in a lot of places, they've got to come down.

BARTIROMO: Are you saying put it in perspective, you're coming off at such a rich time for prices.

FORBES: But you're also going to see I think a real sharper divergence between red states, blue states, i.e., high-tax states versus low-tax states in this region, tri-state region. Forget it. You're just going to be worse and worse. You go to place like Texas, Florida --

BARTIROMO: Because you've lost your deduction in the high-tax states.

FORBES: You've lost your deduction, and -- but Texas, Florida, I think those places are going to still boom.

BELL: It's just like the equity market, as interest rates go up, when you have some of these assets that prices have gone up so significantly, so quickly, they have to come back down, you know, when you have interest rates rising.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, what about this market in terms of retail, Lowe's out earlier this morning beating expectations but Futures on the decline. Look at the stock here, Lindsey, down 7-1/3 percent on lows, and you've got all of the majors, even when it was a double beat or earnings better, even a revenue was light, it was same-store sales that really triggered the move, but they're all down across the board.

BELL: Yes. And same-store sales is a key. When you look at Lowe's, their same-store sales is up I think 1.5 percent. Look at Home Depot in the U.S., 5.4 percent same-store sales. Meanwhile, Home Depot is also down. I think it was down three percent in the last week. Lowe's was down nine percent going into this earnings report, I think.

BARTIROMO: Well, the NASDAQ is down, what, almost 14 percent from the highs, on the NASDAQ. So, we're seeing, I mean, a serious correction happening as we speak.

MCDOWELL: So Amazon was in bear market, and it entered a bear market in October. Alphabet, Google's parent company also in a bear market now. And if you're talking about -- but this is -- this is moved way outside of technology. You were talking about how hard these retail stocks have been hit going into this earnings report, Target since November, like early November 11-9 is down -- was already down 10-1/2 percent, and then it's down another almost 10 percent in premarket trading. And this is for -- Kohl's was down 14 percent before today, Lowe's down, 12 percent decline for TJX, Ross Stores down more than 11 percent. This is before the rout that you're seeing this morning, which is astonishing.

BELL: But this morning, Kohl's -- like Target was still off like 20 percent going into this morning. Kohl's was still up 30 percent year-to- date, going into this morning, so look at that versus the market. And some of these other sectors, and they were looking pretty good and maybe still highfliers, so they're being brought down, too. Even -- so, even the good quality names. And look, Target five percent comp that it's slightly missed. It was a -- that's an amazing number like Gerri said earlier.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: Well, the market tries to anticipate the future, and the future, next year for the consumers is not going to be so good as this tariff thing kicks in.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's the issue. And if you're worried about growth going forward and you want to get out of some of these stocks and you want to just allocation shift, you're going to sell what you can sell. So, you've got, what, Apple still up whatever you said, 30 percent.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, where's money been going or what have people been buying, they've been buying treasuries which does seem to suggest people are worried about what the economy and growth looks like moving into next year. So, they were -- the yield was down I think through yesterday, six days in a row, and that's the longest winning streak for the 10-year treasury, I believe in more than two years. Let me go back 2016.

BARTIROMO: You're worried about growth, you're going to sell what you can sell and if you've got gains of 40 percent as some of these retail names or tech names, well, take some profits. Even in the face of good consumer and a good economy now, there's a new Gallup Poll showing the approval of President Trump handling of the economy is up, 53 percent of Americans approve how the President is handling the economy. Those are his best numbers yet, up from a previous high of 51 percent. So, how many people have come on this show, Dagen, and said that things are going really well? You had the head of shop -- international shopping says, it's going to be a blowout fourth-quarter. You had Jerry Stork (ph) saying it's going to be a terrific Black Friday. And yet, people are selling their holdings.

MCDOWELL: And I -- but some of what's going on, some of the nervousness, some of the uncertainty among businesses is this self-inflicted wound by this administration. And Steve has talked about that all-year long, and it is a -- trade is the problem.

FORBES: We're talking during the break about Larry Kudlow that's going on Stuart Varney.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: He says nice things about maybe something is going to happen with China, you'll see this reverse. If something does happen in that meeting in a few days between Xi and Trump --

BARTIROMO: The G20.

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) framework that they might negotiate, sentiment can turn pretty quickly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true.

BELL: The market needs to see more though than just talk, they need action, they need a game plan on trade. I think that the market is not going to believe like some positive rhetoric out of the G20.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, Stuart Varney is going to weigh in on the technology titans' tumbling this morning. Plus, gift-giving guilt. Check this out, the shocking study on the pressure to overspend during the holidays. That's up next. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We want to give you this market alert because Futures are near the lows of the morning, again, just shy of them, Dow Industrials down 350 points, 1-1/3 percent. The NASDAQ is down 145 points right now, that's better than two percent lower. Yesterday, of course, the NASDAQ was down three percent, the Dow was down two percent.

Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in. And Stu, you say all of the news is bad news for the market.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, it's a perfect storm of bad news, isn't it? I mean, let me list some of the items here. Number one, the Democrats have won the house, so you're not going to get any new stimulus for the economy for next year. Number two, you got a global slowdown, that is going to hurt us. Three, no good news at this point from the trade talks with China, that is a negative. Four, Goldman Sachs says that by the end of next year, we'll be growing at a less than two percent growth rate. That's not good. Number five, most important, you've got a tech sell-off and then some. They did lead the market, now they don't, now they're leading it down. If you add them all up, we could be facing one of those blowout situations, and if we are, maybe that sets up a buying opportunity. But everything points south at this moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it seems like, at some point, it's going to be a big buying opportunity, Stu. I think you're right about that. I mean, we're seeing expectations of a slowdown in the economy, but how much slower -- I mean, how significant will that slowdown be? I mean, this has been the issue for about a year now that people are saying things will slow down considerably going into 2020.

VARNEY: Well, the people that we're talking to and you're talking to, are looking more towards a 2-1/2 percent growth rate for next year. That's nowhere near recession, and it's not that bad. It's a slowdown but it's not that bad. So, I think we may be setting up a really good buying opportunity but we're not quite there yet.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

VARNEY: You've got to see that just -- I forget the exact word for it, but you got a blowout of sort -- capitulation.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: We haven't got that yet, but when we do, then maybe you see the (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: No, it's not capitulation when a market closes off of the lows, we were down better than 500 yesterday and we closed down 395. So, I know you're going to have a lot more on it in about 10 minutes, Stu, we'll see you then.

VARNEY: Oh, yes, Larry Kudlow, by the way.

BARTIROMO: Larry Kudlow is coming up. That's going to be such an important interview. Join "VARNEY & COMPANY" as Larry Kudlow join Stuart to talk about where we are in this economic story.

First though, a news alert as we go to break, Boeing reportedly canceling a conference call on the 737 Max jet to discuss the systems on the model. This is the same model involved in a Lion Aircraft that crashed. Here's what Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg told me in exclusive interview earlier this month.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DENNIS MUILENBURG, CEO, BOEING: This is an ongoing investigation, so it will take whatever time is necessary to make sure it's done thoroughly, again, we participate fully in these investigations, we provided technical assistance, we'll continue to do that until the work is complete. The bottom line here is the 737 Max is safe.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Boeing shares up -- down 3.8 percent right now. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Holiday shopping headache, a new bank rate survey claims nearly half of Americans feel pressure to overspend during the holiday season. Parents feel the pinch even more with over half of respondents with kids overspending. Joining us now is Ramsey Solutions' financial expert, author of the upcoming book, "Everyday Millionaires," Chris Hogan is here. Chris, good to see you.

CHRIS HOGAN, FINANCIAL EXPERT, RAMSEY SOLUTIONS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you avoid overspending?

HOGAN: Well, Maria, you have to start off with a plan. Make a list of the people that you're going to shop for, assign a dollar amount on what you can afford to spend for that individual, and only spend that amount. I don't want people to wake up in January and have a holiday hangover for the next 18 months, trying to pay off credit card debt when they bought things they couldn't afford.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That makes sense. Lindsey?

BELL: Yes. Well, what about the ability to just take some people off your list and just not get gifts?

HOGAN: I don't think there's a problem with that at all, Lindsey, I really don't. If you can't afford to buy a gift, then be creative, think of ways you can make a gift. If they have kids, gift them with babysitting, take them out for a dinner, or make someone a dinner. We've got this mind-set in America that we have to buy a gift in order to give a gift. We can give the gift of time or we can use our talents to be creative.

MCDOWELL: Because when you give people something like I'll babysit your kids, the recipient of that gift knows that that babysitter is never going to show up, and then they're going to have a problem. Again, it's the fact that like at least a gift that you bought in a store is something tangible that like, oh, I can use this bath bomb, not something that, you know, well, I'm going to -- you know, I'll drive you to the mall when you need me to. It just never materializes.

HOGAN: Dagen, you sound like you've stood some people up with babysitting before.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I don't -- I don't babysit.

HOGAN: But I think -- I think if you --

BELL: You're cracking me up. You're cracking me up.

HOGAN: Yes, I think if you give them a certificate or something. I just don't want people to dig themselves further into a hole. Spending in our debt (INAUDIBLE) situation is pushing toward a trillion dollars. This holiday season is a season where people dig themselves into a hole, that some of them still haven't crawled out from for the last three to four years. So, the definition of insanity is to keep doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HOGAN: Let's approach this Christmas with cash, make this a cash Christmas, and don't have financial regret.

FORBES: Well, one way to do it, I won't mention a family member who does it, and that is -- he has a great gift for recycling. So, recycle some of the presents --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Oh, recycled gift. You mean, regift?

FORBES: Regift.

MCDOWELL: Steve Forbes, I know who it is. Should I say who it is on television? It's --

FORBES: No.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: The Forbes name has nothing to do -- it doesn't represent like somebody who has an endless supply of money, they'll regift something that they got in previous holiday.

BARTIROMO: Well, what's wrong with regifting if it wasn't used?

MCDOWELL: Well, you were the --

FORBES: It's the thought that counts.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's like I gave Steve a gift and he gives it back to me the following Christmas, it's a little bit --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes, that's a problem. Chris, thank you, sir. Happy Thanksgiving, Chris Hogan. We'll be right back.

HOGAN: Happy Thanksgiving.

BARTIROMO: Thanks, everybody, great show.

MCDOWELL: Great show.

FORBES: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day, everybody. Let's get to "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stuart, take it away.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VTN-K471-DXH2-6346-00000-00White House Battles Democrats on Mueller Report; Democrats Demand Trump & Trump Organization's Tax Returns; Cohen Says He Has New Evidence in Bid to Stay Out of Prison; Soon Biden Makes 1st Public Appearance Since Complaints of Unwanted Touching; Warren Says Filibuster A Tool to Block Racial Justice; Boeing Makes Admission after 2 Deadly Plane Crashes. Aired 11-11:30a ET2019-04-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisAT THIS HOUR11:00 AM ESTNEWSInternational040501CN.V59White House Battles Democrats on Mueller Report; Democrats Demand Trump & Trump Organization's Tax Returns; Cohen Says He Has New Evidence in Bid to Stay Out of Prison; Soon Biden Makes 1st Public Appearance Since Complaints of Unwanted Touching; Warren Says Filibuster A Tool to Block Racial Justice; Boeing Makes Admission after 2 Deadly Plane Crashes. Aired 11-11:30a ETErica Hill, Abby Phillip, Manu Raju, Joe Lockhart, Gloria Borger, Nia Malika Henderson, Alex Burns, Drew Griffin

The White House is threatening to block Democrats' demand for six years of President Trump's tax filings, as the president suggests the Justice Department could get involved. Michael Cohen wrote a letter to Congress saying he needs their help to persuade the SDNY to delay his jail time because he has more information that could help their investigations of President Trump. Joe Biden makes his first public appearance since multiple women alleged inappropriate contact by the former vice president, so will he address the issue this morning? Elizabeth Warren is going to call for an end to the filibuster this morning, saying it's a tool to block racial justice, and she wants Democrats to get on board. A rare admission from Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg, accepting blame for the two deadly plane crashes, as regulators order a fix for a second software problem.

[11:00:05] ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR: Hello. I'm Erica Hill, in for Kate Bolduan.

Right now, President Trump is on his way to visit the U.S. border with Mexico.

Back in Washington, the attorney general and the president's legal team are gearing up for two big fights. On the Mueller report, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler is demanding the Justice Department produce all communications between Bill Barr and the special counsel. Sources tell CNN some members of the Mueller team were unhappy with the attorney general's four-page summary of their nearly 400-page report because it didn't properly convey just how damaging their findings were for President Trump.

And then there's the issue of the president's tax returns. The White House is threatening to block Democrats' demand for six years of filings, as the president himself suggests the Justice Department could get involved.

CNN's Abby Phillip is at the White House.

Right before leaving this morning, the president was asked again, Abby, about his tax returns. What's the latest from the president?

ABBY PHILLIP, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Well, Erica, the president hasn't said a whole lot about this issue, but he has reiterated one thing, which is that he is under audit, and while he's under audit, he does not believe he needs to release his tax returns. He's responding to what is not actually a request to him. It's a request from the House Ways and Means Committee to the IRS directly.

And here's how he responded to another question from reporters this morning about what he thinks about the possibility that his taxes could be released under the law that the Ways and Means Committee is citing in order to make this request.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I'm under audit. But that's up to whatever it is. From what I understand, the law is 100 percent on my side.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PHILLIP: But, Erica, it's really not clear whether the law is 100 percent on his side.

The Ways and Means Committee is citing a part of the IRS tax code that gives certain congressional committees the right to request an individual's tax returns. Nancy Pelosi said yesterday those kinds of requests have never been denied, but in this case, it would be up to the Trump administration to handle that.

One interesting point is that the "New York Times" is reporting that President Trump weighed in on the nominee for the attorney for the IRS, who would be dealing with these kinds of requests. He asked Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, to speed up this individual's nomination, and it seemed to be an effort for Trump to put someone in that position who might have -- who might see it his way. This is someone who's had some minor dealings with the Trump Organization in his past life before being nominated for this post. And so the implication here is that President Trump has known this is coming down the pike, that Democrats wanted to see his tax returns for a long time, and has been trying to slowly get in position so when there's a legal fight over this, he might be well positioned to win it. We'll see what happens now, but clearly, this is headed toward a big fight and potentially towards the courts.

HILL: Abby Phillip, with the latest from the White House. Abby, thank you.

For a closer look on what Democrats in Congress want, let's go to CNN's Manu Raju on Capitol Hill.

Manu, let's start first with Chairman Nadler and what he wants from the Department of Justice.

MANU RAJU, CNN SENIOR CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, one thing they want is the release of the full Mueller report and the underlying evidence, as, of course, the Judiciary Committee has authorized a subpoena for all that information. Nadler has not served the Justice Department yet. Nadler told me that he's waiting, trying to show accommodation to the Justice Department before ultimately deciding to serve the Justice Department in case this ends up in court so they can argue they did everything they could to convince the Justice Department to comply.

In the aftermath of these reports showing some tension among some people on Mueller's team with the Justice Department, Nadler is demanding all communications between the Justice Department and Mueller's team over the release of that report. He sent a letter to Bill Barr yesterday demanding this information. That is not a subpoena threat at the moment, but potentially they could turn into one. At the moment, that's where things are. They're trying to pressure the Justice Department to release the full unredacted report. But as we know, Erica, there's no sign yet that the Justice Department is going to listen to that request and there's no sign they won't redact at least some portion of the report. The big question is, how much of the report will be behind those black lines -- Erica?

HILL: Will be interesting to see.

Also, Manu, Michael Cohen writing a new letter to Congress. He wants a little more time. What is he asking for specifically?

RAJU: Yes, he says that he is urging -- his lawyers sent a letter to congressional committees yesterday, Democrats in particular, saying that he needs their help to persuade the Southern District of New York to delay his jail time because, according to this letter from Cohen's attorneys, he has more information that could be helpful to their investigations. Some files that he discovered on a hard drive, apparently, could be helpful to what the Democrats are investigating on the Hill.

He laid out a number of things he could be helpful in. And in this letter, it says this, it says, "We hope that this memorandum demonstrates that Mr. Cohen needs to be readily accessible and immediately available to provide ongoing assistance to Congress in order for it to fulfill its executive-branch oversight responsibilities."

[11:05:38] Erica, no word yet from Democrats about whether they will agree to try to persuade federal prosecutors to delay jail time. Republicans pushing back saying this is an effort by Cohen to try to get out of jail. We'll see what information he has to provide and how Democrats ultimately respond -- Erica?

HILL: Manu, thank you.

Joining me now, CNN chief political analyst, Gloria Borger, and CNN political commentator, Joe Lockhart, who served as press secretary under President Clinton.

I may be a little cynical, which happens sometimes, especially in this business, but this letter from Michael Cohen, this promise of, oh, I've got more, we should just wait, it feels a little 11th-hour desperate.

Joe, how do Democrats handle that?

JOE LOCKHART, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: I think it's a tough one for Democrats because I think there's a little bait here for there may be something very interesting, but I think Democrats have so far been very careful about calibrating their response. This is a little bit of a trap for them, I think. I think if they start weighing in with SDNY and trying to keep Michael Cohen, who was convicted of very serious crimes, out of jail, that opens them up to legitimate criticism. While it may be tempting, if they were listening to me, I would say stay away from this one.

HILL: Interesting to say it could be a trap. As we look at everything that is else happening, that has just been laid out for us, Gloria, Democrats turning up the pressure when it comes to -- they don't want to just see the president's personal tax returns. They want to know about his businesses, too. We should point that out because that's important.

GLORIA BORGER, CNN CHIEF POLITIAL ANALYST: Yes.

HILL: There's also new reporting from the "New York Times" about the president wanting to make sure that the chief counsel was installed at the IRS even before Bill Barr as attorney general, that it was so important to get him there. The White House and the president are not backing down in this fight. Where do Democrats take it?

BORGER: Well, first, why am I not surprised that the president wanted to install somebody he knew, who had once worked with the Trump Organization in that position, and that he was eager to do it. If you look at the timing of all this, as the "New York Times" piece points out, it was around the time the Democrats started saying we're going to get your tax returns, we need to get your tax returns. I think that the Democrats found a very narrow way -- they were very careful about this. They found a very narrow way to ask the president for his tax returns, to ask the IRS to release it. They believe they're on solid ground. The president says they are not on solid ground. Obviously, this may end up in court. We just -- you know, we don't know at this point. The danger here for Democrats, to Joe's point, is you can't be seen to be overreaching on everything. And they're investigating on a multitude of fronts right now. Not only in terms of the Mueller report, but now in terms of the president's tax returns. And so they have to be -- they do have to be careful about this and not to appear to be fishing on everything.

HILL: So to that point, we know that, in polling, 67 percent of Americans say the president should release his tax returns.

BORGER: Yes. Sure.

HILL: There's an appetite to see what's in there.

But to Gloria's point, Joe, is this the smartest fight right now for Democrats to be picking?

LOCKHART: Well, I would say, first, the flip side to the Democrats being careful about fishing is the Trump administration can't be stonewalling on everything.

(CROSSTALK)

BORGER: Exactly.

LOCKHART: And it really does create this atmosphere that they're hiding on every front.

I think Gloria makes the right point. Democrats were very smart the way they went after this. They didn't say we want every tax return ever, you know, and without reason. They found a section of the IRS tax code that allows them to get this, a very limited amount, and they're doing that. I expect the administration will block this. He has his man there now. And it will go to court. And if you listen to the legal analysts, who have been on the air talking back and forth, it's a pretty easy case, I think, for the Democrats to win. And you know, one of the things about fishing is, you know, it seems legitimate when the other side is pedaling so hard to stop you from catching anything. I think the Democrats are helped immensely by the strategy that the Trump administration has taken, I think, across the board. They ought to just pull the Band-Aid off on some of these things. It's very painful in the short term, but politics is a business where the subject changes very quickly.

[11:10:09] HILL: Especially these days.

LOCKHART: And with the way they're doing it, this is going to hang around until Election Day.

BORGER: Yes.

LOCKHART: And that I don't think that's a recipe for success.

BORGER: And on the release of the Mueller report, don't forget, the House voted unanimously -- and they don't vote unanimously on naming what day it is, right -- they voted unanimously to release the Mueller report. And 80 percent of the public wants to see what's in the Mueller report. And so I think the Democrats on that are on terra- firma. The public is with them on that.

HILL: But the way we're seeing Barr dig in, right, the changing of the messaging from the president, that's not a surprise. It should not be a surprise any time the messaging changes --

(CROSSTALK)

HILL: -- from the president. But the fact there have been these deadlines thrown out, and there have been demands thrown out, and now the latest letter from Chairman Nadler, and the DOJ responding. The fact is, Barr is not biting. He's not moving.

BORGER: No. No, but don't forget, on the redactions, he has Mueller sitting on his shoulder.

HILL: Right.

BORGER: We don't know if he's there every minute, but he's working with Mueller. I presume that Mueller and his team want their summaries out of what they did in the report, and they want more rather than less. Mueller wasn't born yesterday. He's been around Washington a long time. I presume they wrote a lot of this report knowing it would be released to the public.

HILL: Right, written in a way that it could be.

BORGER: Yes, exactly. Scrubbed, pre-scrubbed.

HILL: Yes. LOCKHART: Remember, what Congress is asking for now is not to release this to the public.

BORGER: Exactly.

LOCKHART: There's absolutely no precedent to hold back this information from Congress. Congress gets briefed on the most sensitive national security issues on an almost daily basis. And they are coequal branches with the executive, and there's a level of trust. There will be a debate on what goes to the public, but what Bill Barr is saying right now is, I'm not going to let Congress see anything I don't want Congress to see, and that position is not sustainable.

BORGER: There's also a question, how much you can say about the president, whom you cannot indict.

HILL: Right.

BORGER: So remember Jim Comey, who came out there and didn't -- I'm sure you remember --

LOCKHART: Yes.

BORGER: -- he didn't indict, you know, Hillary Clinton but he said she was reckless. So is this equivalent to that?

(CROSSTALK)

HILL: Right. That's the question that keeps coming up.

BORGER: Yes.

HILL: Just really quickly for both of you because I love to have you both weigh in, who do you think is winning the messaging war here with the American public? Is it Donald Trump and his camp and Republicans, more the president than Republicans, I would say, or is it the Democrats?

BORGER: Most of the public still believes the president is not an honest person. However, I think when Trump came out and said, I was exonerated, it had a lot of impact on people. I think the way it's impacted people is they have turned the page. Maybe they don't believe him, but they have turned the page.

LOCKHART: I think it depends on the messaging. He's won the messaging war. He's always won it with his own base. He's lost it with the Democrats and progressives, which it didn't matter, he was always going to lose it. I think he's lost it with the people in the middle. Let's remember, the day the Mueller -- the Barr letter came out -- let's not call it the Mueller report --

BORGER: Right.

LOCKHART: -- came out, he claimed total exoneration. The next poll that came out, three or four days later, said 29 percent of Americans -- only 29 percent of Americans, his base, believed that he was totally exonerated.

BORGER: Exactly.

LOCKHART: So on his best day --

(CROSSTALK)

HILL: And the letter said he was not totally exonerated. Let's not forget that.

LOCKHART: On his best day, he still had less than a third of the public who believed him. I think to -- what you need to get re- elected, the middle, and either the left or the right, he's lost the messaging war.

HILL: Joe, Gloria, appreciate it.

(CROSSTALK)

HILL: Thank you.

Coming up, Joe Biden makes his first public appearance since multiple women alleged inappropriate contact by the former vice president. So will he address the issue this morning?

[11:13:54] Plus, a rare admission from Boeing after two deadly plane crashes. All this as regulators order a fix for a second software problem. Could Boeing face criminal charges?

HILL: Minutes from now, Joe Biden will be speaking to the Electrical Workers Union in Washington, his first public appearance since allegations of inappropriate contact with several women surfaced. The big question, of course, today, will the former vice president and possible 2020 candidate address the issue. We'll find out once he takes to the microphone. It will be interesting if he mentions his Twitter tangle with President Trump. The president posted a video mocking Biden over the allegations. Biden tweeting back, "I see you're on the job and presidential as always."

Joining me now to discuss, CNN political analyst and "New York Times" correspondent, Alex Burns, and CNN senior political reporter, Nia Malika Henderson.

Good to see both of you.

Nia Malika, as we look at this, it's not clear that Joe Biden is actually planning to address what the rest of the world has been talking about for the last several days. Doesn't he need to?

NIA MALIKA HENDERSON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL REPORTER: You would think he would need to address this at some point. Of course, he had that video. It came up short for some people because it was a non-apology apology. Sorry not/sorry thing going on there. And I think it just highlights the odd position he's in as candidate in waiting presumably. You look at the sort of top words of his video, essentially says you'll be hearing more from me in the weeks to come. So here he is about to give this speech to these union guys, unlikely he will mention it or make any reference to it. But at some point, he will certainly have to. And you imagine those first interviews that he does once he announces, if he announces, as everything points to he will at some point, this will be something he'll have to address. Listen, it will likely be something that hangs over any campaign he launches, because all eyes will be on him as he's out there, if he runs, on the stump interacting with voters.

[11:20:15] HILL: The president having a field day with this, which is not surprising. The irony, however, appears to be lost on the president in the way he's weighing in.

But he also had this to say when he was asked this morning about Joe Biden. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I don't see him as a threat. I think he's only a threat to himself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILL: Alex, does the president have a point there? Is Joe Biden right now the biggest threat to Joe Biden?

ALEX BURNS, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST: The president has a point about that. The president is not being on the level when he says he's not concerned about Joe Biden. We know from our reporter and from CNN's reporting that the president is very concerned about Joe Biden. His advisers see Biden as the kind of candidate who would perform well in the areas the president demolished the blue wall of the Midwest in 2016. Absolutely, the biggest unresolved question about Joe Biden's potential campaign, other than whether he will launch it, is just how he will perform on the campaign trail. We haven't seen Joe Biden in the kind of freeform gaggles with reporters that we have seen folks like Beto O'Rourke and Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris. When you're suddenly surrounded by TV cameras or talking directly to voters and someone is throwing the Clarence Thomas hearings at you or your record on school busing or abortion or all the stuff over the last week, we have no sense of how prepared Biden is for that moment.

HILL: We should point out, this is something that has been discussed not just over the last few weeks but really for months as people have been gaming whether over not Joe Biden is going to get in. There's been talk about how extensive his record is, which he likes to play on, but is also a lot of fodder for people to dig through. And even the most recent issues. Maybe you couldn't predict Lucy Flores, but there was cringe-worthy video way back before #metoo that everyone knew was going to be brought up.

BURNS: It's one of the most frustrating parts of this Joe Biden not- quite campaign for people who are supportive of him. The sense he's taking his time to decide whether to run. He's had a long runway to figure out how to deal with the kinds of things you're talking and really hasn't clearly made the best use of it.

HILL: Nia Malika, we're waiting to hear from Elizabeth Warren, who is going to call for an end to the filibuster this morning. She wants Democrats to get on board. How do you think that's going to play out?

HENDERSON: You know, we'll see. As she's linking to this historic fact that the filibuster has been used, she'll say in this speech, basically to block advances in terms of civil rights. I think she's going to specifically refer to some lynching legislation. You know, she is the policy leader in this campaign so far. Policy after policy, whether it's this idea of ending the filibuster, something that the president himself actually agrees upon, other Democrats say, be careful what you wish for, Elizabeth Warren. Because, obviously, if it's Republicans in office, they can use it in the same way that Democrats could use in office as well. So we'll see how she is received at this event. Obviously, this is a cattle call for a number of candidates to try to connect with African-American voters. She's had little success so far in terms of polling. She's down in the low single digits. We'll see what her fundraising is so far. But she's intent on being a policy leader, and really bold policies, changing the Electoral College, this one here about ending the filibuster, breaking up big tech companies. We'll see how she wears with voters going forward, particularly how today she's received with African- American voters. Hasn't had much success so far and much sort of engagement with African-American voters, particularly in Massachusetts, but this, I think, will be a big test for her. We'll see how she handles it.

HILL: We'll be watching it all.

Nia Malika Henderson, Alex Burns, good to see you both. Thank you.

[11:23:57] Coming up, backlash for Boeing as federal regulators order a fix for a second software problem. Were pilots undertrained? And could Boeing face criminal charges?

HILL: Boeing now acknowledging to the "Washington Post" that regulators have ordered the fix of a second flaw in the flight control system of its 737 MAX planes. The planes have been grounded after two fatal crashes less than five months apart.

Boeing's CEO has made a statement that is actually raising more than a few eyebrows.

CNN's Drew Griffin has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DREW GRIFFIN, CNN INVESTIGATIVE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The CEO of Boeing making a rare admission, accepting blame for two of its airliners that crashed.

DENNIS MUILENBURG, CEO, BOEING: It's apparent that in both flights, the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System, known as MCAS, activated in response to erroneous angle-of-attack information. It's our responsibility to eliminate this risk. We own it. And we know how to do it.

GRIFFIN: The video message from Boeing comes after a devastating preliminary report laying out that a software issue apparently caused the crash of an Ethiopian Airlines flight last month. The report also suggesting the same issue may have caused a Lion Air flight to go down last year. The preliminary report finds the pilots did everything required to try to bring the plane back safely, but ultimately couldn't control it.

Former Boeing operations analyst, Rick Ludtke, says during development of the 737 MAX, Boeing had a mandate, make sure any changes to the plane would not require additional pilot training in a simulator.

urn:contentItem:6018-JFF1-JCMN-Y36K-00000-00White House calls Twitter's bluff in war over Trump tweets2020-05-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWhite House calls Twitter's bluff in war over Trump tweetsAFP

May 30, 2020( The Dawn: http://www.dawn.com Delivered by Newstex) WASHINGTON: The White House thumbed its nose at Twitter on Friday by reposting a President Donald Trump tweet that the social media giant had just taken the unprecedented step of hiding, because it violated the platform's rules against 'glorifying violence'.The tit-for-tat marked a new escalation in the row between Twitter and Trump, who has more than 80 million followers and uses tweets daily to announce policies, attack opponents and comment on breaking news.Twitter concluded that Trump fell afoul of its policies with a late-night tweet on violent anti-police protests in Minneapolis, when he called protesters 'THUGS' and warned of military intervention.'When the looting starts, the shooting starts,' Trump had tweeted. Reposts a tweet the social media giant had concealed for violating its rules against 'glorifying violence' Twitter said his words were 'glorifying violence' and hid the post, although readers could still click through to get access.In response, the official White House account called Twitter's bluff by re-tweeting the same post. This time, Twitter responded by saying that while it violated its rules, the company 'determined that it may be in the public's interest for the Tweet to remain accessible.'The White House later defended Trump's tweet, saying: 'The president did not glorify violence.

He clearly condemned it.'And Trump's social media director and Twitter feed manager, Dan Scavino, had his own response. 'Twitter is full of shit — more and more people are beginning to get it,' he wrote on Twitter.The latest spat came a day after Trump signed an executive order in the Oval Office seeking to transform the way social media companies are regulated.That followed Trump's fury over Twitter tagging two of his tweets with fact checks, which was also an unprecedented measure.Trump claims that the platform, where he dwarfs the presence of his Democratic rival Joe Biden for the November presidential election, is biased against him.One immediate result of the blow-up between the social media-savvy president and the high-profile company has been to knock the coronavirus pandemic and recently reached toll of 100,000 dead Americans out of the headlines.It also ties in with one of Trump's major re-election themes: that despite being a billionaire White House incumbent with a Republican majority in the Senate is an outsider fighting a left-wing establishment.End to self-regulation?Trump's executive order seeks to remove social media platforms' decades-long freedom from liability for content posted. Instead of being allowed to self-regulate, this would treat the companies more like traditional publishers, open to government regulation and court challenges over false or harmful material.Trump told reporters at the White House he acted because big tech firms 'have had unchecked power to censor, restrict, edit, shape, hide, alter any form of communication between private citizens or large public audiences'. 'We can't let this continue to happen,' he said.Ironically, his order could spur companies like Twitter to impose stricter lines for users, eventually curbing social media firebrands like Trump himself, who regularly goes online to insult people and support conspiracy theories.How much will change in the near term is unclear, given the legal and political challenges facing Trump's move.Critics say Trump has no authority to regulate private internet operators or change the law, known as Section 230, which backers say has allowed online platforms like Facebook and Twitter to flourish.The American Civil Liberties Union called Trump's order 'a blatant and unconstitutional threat to punish social media companies that displease the president'.Eric Goldman, director of the High-Tech Law Institute at Santa Clara University, said the order was 'more about political theatre than about changing the law.'The order 'is not legally supportable — it flies in the face of more than 900 court decisions,' Goldman said.Published in Dawn, May 30th, 2020
