Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D4HD-00000-00White House Doctor Ronny Jackson Withdraws As Trump's Nominee To Head Veterans Affairs Department; Manhunt Underway For Suspect In Maine Police Officer's Death; Trump Lashes Out At James Comey In New Interview2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWhite House Doctor Ronny Jackson Withdraws As Trump's Nominee To Head Veterans Affairs Department; Manhunt Underway For Suspect In Maine Police Officer's Death; Trump Lashes Out At James Comey In New InterviewLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 26. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Earnings in focus on Wall Street. Futures indicated to open stronger this morning. Stocks are expected to be up at the start of trading with Dow up 55, NASDAQ up 42. Technology bigwigs, Amazon and Microsoft headlining the biggest earning season of -- earnings day of the season rather. This is the single busiest earnings day of the quarter. Both are due out after the bell tonight. We'll be watching those. General Motors meanwhile beat expectations last hour. The stock is under pressure however over the automaker's high restructuring expenses, stock down two percent.

Facebook meanwhile, shaking off the scandal. Shares soaring in the premarket up almost seven percent after the company beat expectations yesterday and posted strong growth in daily users. Take a look at European indices this morning after the ECB left interest rates unchanged last hour, the Ft-100 now changed very much. The CAC quarante is up about a half of a percent and the DAX Index up a quarter of a percent. We are waiting on the ECB President Mario Draghi to start his news conference, that starts in about 30 minutes and we'll tell you if there's anything else that he says that might be market moving. In Asia overnight, markets were mixed. The Shanghai Composite was the worst performer down 1-1/3 percent.

Breaking news this morning, President Trump's pick to head the Department of Veterans Affairs has pulled his name out of consideration. The details as Dr. Ronny Jackson withdraws his nomination in a growing scrutiny from lawmakers. And the West Wing, Kanye not backing down from his support of President Trump. The Rapper's powerful message to his critics coming up. A new robot that's more than meets the eye how scientists in Japan created a real life transformer. All of those coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman along with Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, Fox News Contributor Pete Hegseth. Great to see you guys.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: And great show so far. We got a lot on the docket.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. Sad story about Ronny Jackson. This guy has really served his country honorably and well and this is how Washington treats him on the way out. Just horrendous.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And that is the news of the moment.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: I don't know if he's going to remain the doctor at the White House but really, he didn't deserve this.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Well, it's a way for some people to try and discourage from anybody serving in the Trump administration.

BARTIROMO: That's right. A way to create chaos in President Trump's administration. That is the breaking news. Dr. Ronny Jackson has withdrawn as nominee for secretary of Veterans Affairs. Blake Burman is live at the White House with all the details right now. And Blake, the news just broke about 10 minutes ago.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. And Ronny Jackson has put out a statement within the last few minutes here, Maria. the bottom line with this was the allegations just continue to pile and pile up against Dr. Jackson who is the White House doctor had served under President George W. Bush, President Obama, and now as the personal doctor as well to President Trump who nominated him to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs. The allegations were that he was drinking on the job, overprescribing medicine, fostering a hostile work environment.

Jackson had denied all of that but this morning says he does not want to go forward with this process. In a statement Jackson says the following, "going into the process, I expected tough questions about how to best care for our veterans but I did not expect to have to dignify baseless and anonymous attacks on my character and integrity.

He goes on to say, "the allegations against me are completely false and fabricating. If they had any merit, I would not have been selected, promoted, and entrusted to serve in such a sensitive and important role as physician to three Presidents over the past 12 years." The White House throughout all of this over the last few days continues to stand by Jackson, there was a Press Secretary Sarah Sanders joining the briefing yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Through Jackson's record as a White House physician has been impeccable. In fact because Dr. Jackson has worked within arm's reach of three Presidents, he has received more vetting than most nominees. Given this unique position of trust and responsibility, Dr. Jackson's background and character were evaluated during three different administrations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: One thing that keep in mind here, Maria, is before all of these allegations started rolling in and before the folks up on Capitol Hill put a temporary pause on the nomination process. There were serious questions about whether or not Jackson was qualified to handle such a huge bureaucracy. The Department of Veterans Affairs, the President during that news conference with Emmanuel Macron backed Jackson by saying look, this is his decision to make, he is a qualified to lead this department and we will find out from Jackson what he decides to do. This morning, we have found out he has pulled his name out from the nomination process and now the White House has yet another open slot to fill, someone to lead the V.A. Maria?

BARTIROMO: And that is exactly what the left and the resist movement wants as much chaos as possible around the Trump administration. Joining us right now is Gianno Caldwell, we just saw in the moment. Gianno, thanks very much for being here this morning. Fox News Political Analyst, Republican strategists, Caldwell strategic consulting founder. Your reaction to this. I mean, obviously, this is more -- booby traps in the Trump administration. Who leaked all of this or created this around Dr. Ronny Jackson forcing him to withdraw in your view?

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: We've seen leaks throughout this entire start of this administration. And I think it's very unfortunate. Further, I think Sarah Sanders said something that was particularly interesting and I -- and I thought to be very true that Dr. Ronny Jackson is an individual who's been vetted by three administrations. So if these were to be true why wasn't that found to be the case in these other vetting processes? So it's something that I think that's obviously harmful to the Trump administration because we've seen nominees put their name in and have to withdraw.

BARTIROMO: Right.

CALDWELL: So that particularly problematic. And I'm sad to see him go but I know that there are some other good people that can step in his place.

BARTIROMO: Right.

CALDWELL: I think an excellent candidate with V.P. to be the new V.A. secretary.

BARTIROMO: Well, exact -- well, we talked about that earlier, you're absolutely right. But I mean, is -- are the people going to -- going to come forward and make noise about this? How is this going to stop with all of these, you know, booby traps and barriers that the resist movement is putting in place for the Trump administration?

HEGSETH: I think your only option in situation like this is to fight back and fight back ferociously because it isn't just the leaks, it isn't just the Obama administration. Do watch other networks --

BARTIROMO: The media.

HEGSETH: They go wall-to-wall on person speculation, anonymously source with no verification to smear this guy. I was forced to watch one of these other networks yesterday for whatever reason and they didn't stop, it was all Ronny Jackson, all based on nothing. Gianno, how do you overcome that in this environment?

CALDWELL: You know what, I think that's why it's been President Trump's best quality. You saw that through the 2015 election where they would smear him, they would come at him hard and he wouldn't back down. And I think that that President Trump is going to people who love and that's the reason why he actually won the election.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CALDWELL: And we have to see more of that just that we're going to push back, we're going to push book no matter what you say and how you try to smear people because these are legitimately good people.

BARTIROMO: And it's all shaming, it's public shaming. I'll tell you who is pushing back, Kanye West. He's calling it the mob. Let's talk about his Make America Great moment. The rapper face backlash for praising President Trump yesterday posting on Twitter. Here's what he said, Kanye West. You don't have to agree with Trump but the mob cannot make me not love him. We are both dragging energy, he is my brother, I love everyone, I don't agree with everything anyone does. That's what makes us individuals and we have the right to independent thought. Amen to Kanye West. Good for him.

CALDWELL: Amen.

BARTIROMO: He goes on to -- and then the President actually responded, and the President tweeted out, thank you, Kanye. Very cool. Gianno, your reaction.

CALDWELL: You know, it's interesting. I'm in my hometown at Chicago right now and of course this is where Kanye is from. And I'll be talking about this on largest urban radio station after this interview but this is I think excellent. And I'll tell you why I think it's excellent. Kanye West has been an individual who's not willing to back down, he's unrelenting in what he believes. And I think that the degree, he really appreciates that in President Trump more than anything.

We saw in the 2016 election as I mentioned before, President Trump did not back down, whatsoever and I wrote a piece about him in the Hill why the Republican base (INAUDIBLE) it won't break and he read it and sent me a note. And in that piece, I said that the Republicans chose him as the guy that they wanted to win elections because after the media began to attack him and he was losing business deals, he lost millions saying what he believes.

He didn't step back like most businessmen would, he didn't step back like most politicians would, he doubled down on it. And with that being the case, then says that I'm unapologetic in my view, I'm unapologetic in American First policies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CALDWELL: And I'm unapologetic keeping our country safe. And I think most people can appreciate that, most people can evaluate that and most people voted for that.

MCDOWELL: Gianno though, it's Dagen. Never forget, Kanye is always about Kanye. Kanye is not about -- he is not -- he is not standing up for any issue quite frankly, he is doing --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a shame. He's pushing back on shaming, calling them the mob.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I argue that he is doing it for the attention because he knows that basically siding with President Trump will get him the most attention. Going after President Obama will get him the most attention. He isn't married to the Kardashian clan after all. Maybe they're learning from him rather than the other way around.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But this also started after the USA communications director Candace Owens, she hit back at the Democratic Party and she defend-- she was Fox last night with Martha. Listen to how she defended Kanye and what she said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CANDACE OWENS, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Once they inflate our body's Democratic Party, let's say they haven't slayed our minds, they have told true who we must love, who we must hate, what we must think, what ideas are unacceptable. In the long run, it just -- it just doesn't add up. Listen, I think differently, Kanye West thinks differently. I can guarantee you if he and I get in the same room, we will have a lot of disagreements. The one thing that we will celebrate is our right to think differently. I don't understand what's so controversial for the left to understand this. The way that they had demonized him in the last 72 hours, it's almost sickening but at the end of the day it's going to have adverse effects. I can guarantee you that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well said, Candace. Gianno, what do you make of all of this?

CALDWELL: I agree with what Candace has said and I'm going to have to push back on Dagen just a -- just a bit respectfully. Kanye is about himself, that's unquestionable. I know we all realize that. However, this is an individual who definitely has gone against ever since I have known him before he became a national figure. The marginalization of thought. Specifically marginalization of who we are as individuals so often as the society were programmed.

I believe to do what's reasonable and what were pretty much taught in school and I think he goes beyond that and says look, let's look deep inside ourselves and fulfill our greatest potential. And generally speaking when you do that, when you legitimately do that, it's going to make people uncomfortable and say, hey what you're doing is unreasonable and maybe you should rethink your decision but generally speaking the greatest folks we've seen, Mark Zuckerberg, Kanye West, Donald Trump, the individuals that really succeeded become these megastars are the ones that go beyond what's public as a final thought.

FREEMAN: All right. James Freeman here at the Journal. I'm not sure why we're talking about Kanye allegedly being all about himself. I mean, I don't know -- I don't know what's in his head but the idea that someone puts out a message that compliments the President, encourages people to think freely, and says he loves everyone. Or why are you saying -- well, he's about himself?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You can ask me that question because I'm the one who said it --

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- James because he does -- he does and says things to garner the most attention. And so being complimentary in this environment, President Obama is not going to garner him the most attention.

BARTIROMO: But I'm not going to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: I think he has courage by saying it.

MCDOWELL: He has to --

FREEMAN: It's triggering a very important conversation.

MCDOWELL: But -- he -- Kanye West has never lacked courage. I'm not arguing that. I'm just saying that there's always a motive and it is about -- Kanye is not right or left, not Democrat or Republican, Kanye is Kanye at the end of the day.

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: He has an album that's coming out and he loves --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Right. The album is coming out.

CALDWELL: -- due to his compliments in the President.

BARTIROMO: Well, this -- they shame you if you say anything positive about the President. You know, you get shamed online if you say anything positive about the President. I like to see somebody, who pushes back because it's wrong.

CALDWELL: And he's is breaking the mode on that, yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He's breaking --

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: Because we've got -- we've gone to an extreme point in time where you can't say anything complimentary about President Trump.

BARTIROMO: And then there's Former FBI Director Jim Comey who's been trashing the President in every interview and he leaked memos, a catalyst for the special counsel investigation. That memo was more wildly shared than we thought initially. Sources telling Fox News Comey likely gave the documents to former U.S. Attorney Patrick Fitzgerald and possibly another person along with the with Columbia Law School professor and watch Comey struggle to defend his actions last night at a CNN town hall. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR: You did leak memos, I mean, is it OK for somebody at the FBI to leak something, an internal document even if it's not classified? Isn't that leaking?

JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR: It was a whole lot wrong with your question, Anderson. First, I didn't leak memos, I asked a friend to communicate the substance of one unclassified

(CROSSTALK)

COMEY: I intentionally gave this information to a friend intending that it'd be out in media, I wanted it to get in the media. As a private citizen, I could do that and did that just as I have written about it in my book.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Does he think just saying this is going to make people think otherwise? We're -- we saw what happened. Gianno, your reaction.

CALDWELL: That is my definition leaking. He gave information and now, this is developing at the harvest of the FBI and he gave it to a friend, to spring this special counsel and if I -- if I recall correctly, I think it was reported at The Washington -- Wall Street Journal who said after reading the Comey memos, there is -- they see no reason why there should have been a special counsel to begin with. So with that being the case, Jim Comey definitely is in a position where he's losing all credibility if he had any left.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And let's not forget that zero intelligence that was used to launch the investigation which Devin Nunes told us about. Gianno, thank you. Good to see you.

CALDWELL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

CALDWELL: Good seeing you.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A massive dragnet in Maine after a man shot and killed a sheriff's deputy. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. Police are on the lookout for this man, John Williams. They say that the 29-year-old gunned down Deputy Eugene Cole yesterday morning in Norridgewock, Maine. That is just North of Augusta. Williams drove the cruiser to a nearby convenience store and he robbed it. Police releasing this photo, this captured of him from inside of the stolen car. He then abandoned that car nearby, he has not been seen since. Deputy Cole had been on the force 13 years. He leaves behind a son. The attack coming just a day after two officers were shot at a Dallas Home Depot, one of them was killed there. Officer Rogelio Santander died from his injuries after police say Armando Juarez shot him in the back of the head while trying to make an arrest. 22 officers have been shot and killed so far this year. That is more than double from the same time last year and on average, you're not going to believe this, at least one officer has reportedly been shot to death every week in 2018.

Well, earning season is in high gear this morning. We're just getting results from a couple of big airlines, you know, and let's start with American, the stock is trading lower almost 4-1/2 percent to the downside in the premarket. Their first quarter revenue just missed the street estimate. Adjusted earnings per share of 75 cents actually topped expectations, not helping out though. Let's take a look at Southwest, they also are under pressure ahead of the opening bell down more than 3-1/2 percent. Revenue coming up short of estimates. Southwest did add -- the bookings are down after an engine on its one planes exploded last week killing a passenger and that was Southwest's first fatality in the carrier's history.

And then finally there's this. You want to be careful, the next car that you hop in to might be Megatron. Japanese engineers created a real life Transformer that can actually carry people onboard. This is the first scene we've ever seen anything like this. It's a robot car. It walks over 18 miles an hour and transforms into a sports car with people still inside. The robot creator says he was yes inspired by his childhood Transformer heroes that he watched in the movies in growing up. There you have it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, very cool.

CASONE: Very cool. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up. The outlook on trade with China, big delegation going next week. Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers will weigh in on the new report that Chinese companies are already reconsidering investments in the American market as Steven Mnuchin, the treasury secretary gets set to visit his counterpart in China next week. Then founding partner of AlphaOne Capital Partners Dan Niles joins me to talk about Facebook's quarterly results, he predicted the company would beat. I'll get his take on the company's surging revenue and where it goes next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Focus on Facebook. The social media company beat earnings and revenue expectations last night despite the fallout from the privacy scandal. Yesterday, Facebook reported adjusted earnings per share of $1.69 on revenue of $11.97 billion. That was the first quarter of 2018. Shares of Facebook right now are up seven percent in the premarket. Joining us right now on the telephone is the founding partner of AlphaOne Capital Partners, Dan Niles. One of his big positions is Facebook. And Dan, good to have you. Thanks very much for weighing in here. You predicted that the company would beat revenue and earnings expectations. What's your take away from the numbers?

DAN NILES, ALPHA ONE CAPITAL PARTNERS FOUNDING PARTNER (via telephone): I mean, quite honestly, it's even better than what I was expecting. You have to look at the revenues first and revenues year-over-year in the June quarter were up 45 percent. And the September and December quarters, accelerated up 47 percent. And what's interesting is even with all the negative publicity around the supposed data scandal, the revenues accelerates 50 percent year over year in (INAUDIBLE) they keep the operating income by about 14 percent where their margins were better than expected and they keep the ETF by over 20 percent. I mean, back out some of the one time. So it's really hard to find a whole lot negative in the report.

BARTIROMO: What about expenses going forward in this whole regulatory scrutiny? I mean, are we going to see, you know, new rules regulations that this company is going to have to adhere to in the entire industry, we'll have to adhere to that will change the reason to own the stock because expenses are higher?

NILES: Yes. I really don't think so. I mean, here is a way to think about it. Even though expenses they guided to up 50 to 60 percent, originally they guided up 45 to 60. Estimates are actually going up after this print because they beat the operating income margins by so much that even though their guiding expenses higher most of the street is actually raising EPS.

The second thing is, I'm sure there will be some extra regulations they need to adhere to, obviously they talk on the call about the general protection regulations coming out on May 25th in Europe but the interesting thing as they said, even with those regulations, they don't anticipate those changes really significantly impacting our revenue, they do think daily active users could be cracked down in the second quarter but, you know, that's really not affecting the revenues.

And quite honestly the extra regulations with them, it will -- it will help make their site a lot safer and to some extent it's going to impact their smaller competitors a lot more. They don't have same resources as Facebook to comply with that.

FREEMAN: Hi, Dan. James Freeman at The Wall Street Journal. I'd like to talk about those potential smaller competitors. Normally those kind of fat profit margins attract competition. Who is it that can challenge Facebook, either among startups or existing tech giants moving into their business.

NILES: Well, I mean, you obviously know the list of characters, you've got Twitter, you've got Snapchat obviously, two public companies talked about most often. But I mean, they've been competing since the beginning and you've obviously seen this market is, you know, not necessarily winner take post but it's sort evolving that way as Facebook continues to execute and they're executing really across all of the metrics. So it's not just growing revenue but they're highly, highly profitable.

They have 46 percent operating marks. And so -- and you have to remember, to some extent they are a startup in different businesses, so we talked about Facebook, they've got 2.2 billion users and Instagram 800 million users, so that's great. What we don't talk about that much is the 1.3 billion users for Facebook messenger is that they just started to make money off of and they make absolutely no money off of the 1.5 billion WhatsApp users.

So they've got -- to some extent two startups buried within the company between Messenger and WhatsApp that they still haven't really started to monetize yet and that gives me a lot of comfort especially when you look at the multiples of trading at 20 times non-gap, you know, under 18 earnings. Markets up 17. These are growing the top line at 50 percent.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: I'm sorry.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: The world is wash in venture capital. Are new competitors being funded? And if not, why not? Is Facebook seen as so dominate that that won't work?

NILES: Yes. I mean, I think people are trying to work around the edges but you have to remember with Facebook, there is something pretty unique which is the network effect. You're not going to get off of Facebook and go to Google plus if your friends aren't there. So, you can't really easily switch. If you're dealing with Google for example and somebody came out with a much better search engine, you know, there's nothing to stop you from going to the other one, the problem with this is that even if somebody didn't develop a great other alternative social media site, you're not going to move unless all of your friends move too. And that's probably not going to happen immediately. So --

BARTIROMO: Dan, real quick. Intel and Microsoft after the bell tonight, good quarters? What are you expecting?

NILES: Yes. I mean, Intel is one of our largest positions. We like it quite a bit. I think the real key for Intel is enterprise demand has been really bad for the last couple years. That really started to improve in the fourth quarter and I think it's going to be very good for this year. So we like Intel a lot and it's got a low multiple as well in this environment at about 14 times. So we like that quite a bit and Microsoft, similarly we think they should have a pretty solid quarter. A multiple is quite a bit higher at 24 times, so not as preferred to us as Intel.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Dan, always great to talk with you. Thanks so much.

NILES: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We appreciate it. Dan Niles joining us there. AlphaOne Capital. Coming up. House Republican Conference chair and Washington Congressman Cathy McMorris Rogders joins me next. We'll get her take on French President Macron's state visit with President Trump, trade, and a lot more. Then a new twist on coffee just in time for summer. Starbucks introducing cold foam before reporting earnings after the bell tonight. We break down the expectations. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, April 26th. Your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the east coast. It is the single busiest day for first-quarter earnings, General Motors and Pepsico among the companies reporting their first-quarter this morning. G.M. beat expectations, while PepsiCo was mixed. Both stocks are under some selling pressure this morning by a fraction. Investors are waiting on big tech. Amazon, Intel, Microsoft, all reporting, after the close tonight, all the stocks are trading up about two percent right now.

Broader markets this morning are higher. March durable goods just came out up 2.6 percent versus an estimate of 1.6 percent that was better than expected. The news is a positive for markets, and we are seeing a pretty good tone today. The Dow Industrials set to open about 50 points, that's a quarter of a percent higher.

The S&P is up a third of a percent right now. And the NASDAQ up 50 points, that's three-quarters of one percent. The Dow yesterday snapped a five-day losing streak. And the momentum continues today. That was lifted by Boeing's big earnings beat. Boeing's stock did well as did the Dow up 60 points at the close, a quarter of a percent higher. The S&P was also fractionally better on the day. The NASDAQ yesterday, closed lower by three points.

In Europe, this morning, the major indices are higher. The European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged, and Mario Draghi is about to speak in his press conference. FT-100 up 7-1/2, CAC Quarante up 35, that's two-thirds of a percent. And the DAX Index in Germany up a third of a percent, 43 points higher. In Asia overnight, markets were mixed. The worst performer was China, Shanghai Composite down 1-1/3 percent.

President Trump lashing out against Jim Comey. He's targeting the former FBI Director on "FOX & FRIENDS" moments ago. We will tell you what the President just told our colleagues there. And breaking news this morning, Dr. Ronny Jackson withdraws his nomination as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. President Trump weighed in on the announcement earlier this hour on "FOX & FRIENDS," he placed the blame squarely on Democrats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I even told them a day or two ago. I saw this was -- where this was going. And you know they're very upset because Mike Pompeo who was again first in his class at West Point, top in class at Harvard Law School, a brilliant guy, a great guy, and somebody I get along with very well. You know, Mike got through and they thought they had him stopped. The Democrats are obstructionists. It's horrible what they're doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Reaction from Capitol Hill coming up this morning. And then just in time for summer, Starbucks added -- adds cold foam. The details ahead of the company's earnings report later this hour. The stock is up, half of a percent. Plus, it is National Pretzel Day. We are celebrating pretzel day here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Wait until you see this pretzel that they made of my face. I don't -- I don't think it looks like me but let me see if I can grab this.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: It is Pretzel Day. There you go. OK, we'll get to that coming up this morning, but first, our top story right now, President Trump lashing out at Jim Comey, this morning. Here's what he had to say about the fired FBI Director in a new interview this morning with "FOX & FRIENDS" moments ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Comey is a leaker and he's a liar. And not only on this stuff, he's been leaking for years. He's probably been using his friend, the so- called professor, who now turns out to have FBI clearance which he never said. He even lied about that because he never said that in Congress, he said he gave it to a friend. And he gave it to a friend to leak classified information. It is all classified, it was totally classified. So, he illegally -- he did an illegal act, and he said it himself, in order to get a special counsel against me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is House Republican Conference Chair and Washington Congressman Cathy McMorris Rodgers. Good to see you, Congresswoman, thanks so much for joining me this morning.

REP. CATHY MCMORRIS RODGERS (R), WASHINGTON, CHAIR, HOUSE REPUBLICAN CONFERENCE: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on this. You know, I was actually really struck by the interview last night that Comey did with CNN, and basically he said, no, I didn't leak anything but then went on to talk about how, in fact, he did leak these memos that he wrote which as soon as an FBI Director writes a memo in FBI, you know, headquarters, that is the property of the FBI, but he said he passed it on to his friend and told his friend, oh, just get this to the New York Times but don't actually give them the paper, and he said that's not leaking. Your reaction.

RODGERS: Well, it's -- yes, it begs a lot of questions. And in someone who believes it's so important that we are restoring trust, that we're restoring the rule of law in this country, the FBI is the highest law enforcement agency. This is -- the people within the FBI must be held to the highest standards, and that is what causes me so much dismay right now is just the cloud that is over the FBI, and the questions that it has raised. We need the men and women there to act in the utmost authority, as well as transparency and accountability to the American people. And so, yes, he clearly leaked, and it raises a lot of questions.

BARTIROMO: But is there going to be any accountability here, Congresswoman? I mean, look, last weekend, I had your colleague, Congressman Devin Nunes on my Sunday morning program and he said, after looking at all the electronic communications, he realized that there was no intelligence used to actually launch an investigation into the Trump campaign. So, what happens now? I mean, can we just keep seeing, you know, people at the top of these important agencies abuse their power with no accountability?

RODGERS: No one is above the law and they must be held accountable. And that's the role of Congress, that's the role of the elected representatives of the people within the House to make sure that we are taking action to hold them accountable. So, both in the Intelligence Committee as well as the government oversight and reform committee which Trey Gowdy is the chairman of, that's where these questions are asked and that's where there's been frustration, that documents have not been turned over, that people have not been as forthright in answering the questions, but it is up to us to make sure that people are held accountable and that no one is above the law.

BARTIROMO: All right. Well, we'll be watching what develops then. Then there is this, the breaking news this breaking news this morning, Congresswoman, and that is Dr. Ronny Jackson withdrawing his name for consideration for the head of the V.A., President Trump's pick to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs pulled his nomination in the last hour amid all of these questions surrounding his professional conduct. Congresswoman, your reaction to this news?

RODGERS: I respect his decision. It's most important that we get someone at the V.A. Again, we need to restore trust between the veterans and this agency whose mission is to serve our veterans. And as someone who represents nearly 70,000 veterans in eastern Washington, I hear regularly from veterans who feel like when they contact the V.A. that they're more of a burden than actually having the red carpet rolled out for them. So, we need someone to head up the V.A., we need to get focused on the mission of the V.A., and make sure that our veterans, those who have served are getting the care that they need when the time comes, that has to be a top priority for us.

BARTIROMO: But I mean, can we just ignore all of the barriers and the booby traps that the left is putting in place for the Trump administration? I mean, look at all of the positions that are yet unfilled. Look at all of the slow walking going on in terms of getting his nominees passed. You know, Mike Pompeo got -- you know, got support, but it was close. I mean, what about that, who is doing this? We know that three administrations have said how great Dr. Ronny Jackson is and all of a sudden, somebody leaks all of this speculation about his personal life.

RODGERS: Well, that is -- yes, that's tough to see, and I respect his decision just to pull out. I am concerned that the left is putting politics ahead of what's best for the country, and there's so many -- there's the V.A. position, Mike Pompeo as Secretary of State, he's an honorable man, a well-respected leader, he's proven himself, and yet too many were willing to put politics ahead of what was best for the country. We do need to get these people in place because that is part of making sure that President Trump has the people around him to actually lead, and people equal policy and he needs these people in place so that we can keep moving forward. There's a lot on our plate right now.

BARTIROMO: I think people are figuring this out, that there's -- all of these booby traps that are being put in by the skeptics and critics of President Trump. And then there's China, of course, reportedly threatening to "fierce counterstrike" if the President goes ahead with these another $100 billion in tariffs as punishment for the alleged intellectual property theft. Congressman, your thoughts on this. I know Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury Secretary and a whole delegation are going next week to meet with their counterparts in China to talk this out.

RODGERS: Right. Well, there's too many examples of illegal practices by China, where we have seen them taking our intellectual property and duplicating it. I have examples in Eastern Washington, Washington State, and it destroys companies here in America. I am encouraged that President Trump is focused on making sure that we hold China accountable. I have had concerns about the across-the-board approach to tariffs that, you know, he was talking about imposing upon steel and aluminum. I do believe it needs to be more targeted but we must hold a country like China accountable for illegal practices or free and fair trade will never work.

BARTIROMO: Bottom line, do you think that the President with his tough talk and the team is going to be able to account that budget deficit with China, which is already now up to 375 billion?

RODGERS: Well, if anyone can do it, I believe it's President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes,

RODGERS: And he is focused on this. I had the chance to spend some time with Larry Kudlow just last week. I'm really pleased to see him as the head of the economic advisors, his chief economic adviser. He understands economics, world trade, and also what's going on in China. And he basically told us everything is on the table, tariffs, no tariffs, sanctions, but we must hold them accountable.

BARTIROMO: And he's going to be on that trip as well, Larry Kudlow, and Peter Navarro. What about this budget about face, Congresswoman? President Trump is now urging lawmakers to rescind some of the spending of that $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill which he signed last month. Congresswoman, are there enough votes to make it happen and obviously you must be getting just as much pushback as so many others are, for signing that $1.3 trillion omnibus bill with all the spending?

RODGERS: Right. Well, we must address the spending in this country. It is the number one threat that faces us, both from a military perspective as well as economic perspective, we needed to get a budget in place, but it spends too much, and that's where I am -- I'm actually encouraged that the President, Mick Mulvaney is leading on putting together a rescission package.

We should have been doing this all along, really taking a look at those opportunities to go into programs, go into agencies and actually through the House and the Senate, cut the spending. The budget process is broken, the House passed all 12 of our appropriations bills. We went through program by program, agency by agency, the Senate did zero. So, this has been very frustrating.

This is our fundamental job as the elected representatives, this is where we exercise the power of the purse, and yet this process is broken. So, I am -- I definitely want to look at what the President -- what they can propose. I think the House and Senate should also be using this tool of rescissions to take action that we can to reduce those deficits and reduce the debt.

BARTIROMO: The French President Emmanuel Macron wrapped up his three-day state visit with an address to the joint meeting of Congress. How was it, what was your takeaway? He was critical of the President's planned withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal.

RODGERS: Well, I think, it is important that these conversations continue. I've never been a supporter of the Iran deal. I thought it was bad deal. It did not hold Iran accountable for not developing or obtaining nuclear weapons. And that's where we need our European allies to join us in making sure that we have a deal that is going to accomplish the goal of ensuring that they do not develop nuclear weapons. And right now, we do not have that confidence.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, real quick, who are you supporting for Speaker of the House?

RODGERS: Well, you know, I -- we need to make sure that we are voting on a Republican speaker after the elections, so we need to stay focused on the policy and on our midterms and making sure that we're getting that done.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon. Thanks so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Ford Motor now pulling all but two of its passenger cars from its North American line up as part of a plan to save money and make the company more competitive. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney. Stu, a car company canceling all of its cars?

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Yes. Well, you know, if you can't make money selling cars, I guess you forget about selling cars, and you go to light trucks and SUVs because that's where the money is. It's a perfectly rational move but boy, does it come as a shock. You know, when I think of the Ford Motor company, I think of the Taurus, one of the best-selling marks for almost a generation. It's gone. They're not going to sell that thing in North America any longer. The Fiesta is going. A couple of other marks, I guess you'd call them, are going. I was just shocked to hear that. It's a car company, but it's not a car company. It's now a light truck and SUV company because it wants to make some more money. Look at the stock, up 2-1/2 percent, just because its walking away from the car market. I wondered if General Motors will do something similar or FiatChrysler, walk away from unprofitable lines because you got to make money in this environment and that's what you got to do.

BARTIROMO: It's really fascinating.

VARNEY: I find it fascinating, I really do.

BARTIROMO: It is -- it is fascinating. And remember the last CEO wanted to make it a mobility company.

VARNEY: Yes, that's right. Yes. My, how times change.

BARTIROMO: Well, Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. I know you'll have a lot more on it.

VARNEY: Sure, you will.

BARTIROMO: "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA at 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Join Stuart. It is the busiest day of the earnings season today, G.M. one of the big names out this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the numbers. Nic?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. The busiest day of 68 S&P 500 companies, and to your point, your chat with Stuart, guess what, G.M. is doing much of the same, focusing on a highly-profitable pickup trucks, and that's what's costing them going forward for 2018. So, for the quarter, they beat on both the top and bottom line. Profit was on the rise, and it's the high-margin vehicles that they're going to be working on. So, 2018, they expect that they will have flat profits but expect the all new pickup trucks would boost the margins in 2019. The stock is down a half of one percent.

Then, let's take a look at Starbucks. So, we're expecting for Starbucks to report after the bell today. Global same-store sales are likely on the rise to the tune of about 1.8 percent. They still, obviously or have the P.R. that they have to deal with from Philadelphia, removing those two black men, but big spot is China. That's where they see the growth. In fact, they're opening one new store in China every 15 hours. And also, you can get cold foam on your new -- on your new Starbucks. All right, Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Nicole. So, coming up, it's not your average day. We are celebrating National Pretzel Day. Maria's pretzel with a small business is growing fast. We take you live to plaza, where there is a pretzel truck waiting. I've already eaten one, they're delicious. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We're coming to you outside on the plaza, outside headquarters. What a twist in this National Pretzel Day. We are celebrating in style with a small business that is growing fast. Joining me right now is Dan Dizio, he's the CEO and co-founder of Philly Pretzel Factory and we've got the team here ready to munch on all pretzels. Dan, great to see you.

DAN DIZIO, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, PHILLY PRETZEL FACTORY: Me, too.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us, and I love the MORNINGS WITH MARIA in pretzel. That is very cool, nice touch. You've been selling pretzels since you're 11 on the corner in Philadelphia. Tell us how you started your business.

DIZIO: Yes, my next door neighbor had a pretzel bakery, got stuck with a bunch of pretzels. I'm 47 now. This week, I'll be 47. And he got stuck. A woman asked if I would sell them on the shoe corner and we would split the money. And my mom said it would be OK. He had to ask my mom permission, and, for some reasons, my mom said it would be OK to stand on the street corner all day (INAUDIBLE) but she said it was a different time back then. So --

(CROSSTALK)

DIZIO: And, yes, I did it, and did real well, and the next thing I know every guy was selling pretzels, and did all through middle school and high school. And I went to college and was a graduate, and had a stockbroker job and just didn't like the 9:00 to 5:00 thing, and I want to get back to the pretzel business and I talked my college roommate into doing a pretzel business and that's how it started, yes.

BARTIROMO: You started with the food truck, the Philly Pretzel Factory, you've got the food truck -- Hi, everybody. Did you have a pretzel? Tell me about the food truck business because this is a really successful way to sell.

DIZIO: Yes, we've had the truck for a few years now. We're really doing well with the weddings, bar mitzvahs, just different event. I mean, there's different places we could take it, so it'd be mobile. That's the way you have to be in this moment right now as for -- be able to (INAUDIBLE) and be able to bring the pretzel to the people where they are.

BARTIROMO: And now, you have 170 locations across the country.

DIZIO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You're opening more stores.

DIZIO: Yes, we're actually opening up 25 in New York right now. We just did area development deal to open up 25 in Manhattan over the next few years. So, we're excited about that. And we have about 42 stores under development. So, we're really excited.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: How long does it take to actually bake a pretzel?

DIZIO: It takes about seven minutes to bake a pretzel. Yes, yes.

CASONE: OK. Some of these. OK.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: And some sausage, am I right?

DIZIO: They're hotdogs.

CASONE: I'm digging it.

DIZIO: They're hotdogs. (INAUDIBLE) This is a new product we had. It's our mini hotdog trade. We've done really well over the years with hotdog pretzels.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's a mini-hotdog stand. I like that.

DIZIO: And we do many hotdogs.

BARTIROMO: Fit for a party.

DIZIO: That's exactly what it's meant for. Tailgating parties. It's been a big hit.

BARTIROMO: So, the Republican tax plan, did that impact you as a small business?

DIZIO: It actually did. I mean, more money for the small businesses. Remember, our franchisees are business owners and there are small businesses in communities, and to be able to have a tax break for them, really lets them reinvest, maybe open another location up, reinvest. I mean, these are part of the community, these franchise locations. I mean, they sponsored the little league. They have more money to do these things and it really does have that effect to help everything in their communities.

BARTIROMO: Where does the growth come from now?

DIZIO: It's -- we're doing a lot in Midwest, a lot down south. I mean, Philadelphia has been haven for pretzels and it is where it all started. So, we're stretching out, we're in 19 states now and it continues to grow and people are fascinated and falling in love with the (INAUDIBLE) once we had --

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: These are so good, Maria. We have to get involved. These are so good.

BARTIROMO: Dan Dizio, thank you so much for joining us.

(CROSSTALK)

DIZIO: Thank you. It's great.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Wait, can I have the (INAUDIBLE)?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right. These are just out of the oven. Stuart Varney, over to you. Do you want to have pretzels?

VARNEY: Yes. Delivery, please.

BARTIROMO: I'll have it set up for you.

VARNEY: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Take it away, Stu.

END

urn:contentItem:5WS1-1XF1-JCJY-G2GJ-00000-00White House drafts executive orders to bolster Trump's claim of internet bias against conservatives saying 'most of Twitter is liberal cesspools of venom'2019-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:2White House drafts executive orders to bolster Trump's claim of internet bias against conservatives saying 'most of Twitter is liberal cesspools of venom'Geoff Earle, Deputy U.s. Political Editor For Dailymail.com

The administration is 'exploring all policy solutions'

Trump wants 'fairness' in the system

'Liberal cesspools of venom'

The president tweeted this week that Google CEO Sundar Pichai was in the Oval Office working hard to explain 'how much he liked me'

He claimed that the search giant worked to undermine his 2016 election

Didn't offer evidence, but said it pushed for 'Crooked Hillary'

Also issued a threat saying he is watching 'very closely'

The president misspelled his last name in one of the tweets

The White House aides are trading paper on a possible executive order meant to beef up President Trump's claim of anti-conservative bias in social media and Internet searches.

The action comes after Trump and conservative lawmakers have blasted tech firms for allegedly discriminating against conservatives in their platforms - and the president issued a warning to Google that he is watching the firm 'very closely.'

A White House official called Twitter 'liberal cesspools of venom' and described the potential order as an effort to restore 'fairness in the system,' according to Politico.

Tech firms 'have a vital role and an increasing responsibility to the culture that has helped make them so profitable and so prominent.'

The details were not immediately available, but any order seeking to impose restrictions on how the companies operate to allow Americans to produce and consume information is certain to draw a response from Big Tech's team of corporate lawyers.

If could easily face a court challenge on constitutional grounds.

But such a move would carry out the president's wish to take a look at the issue.

"The President announced at this month's social media summit that we were going to address this and the administration is exploring all policy solutions,' another White House official told the publication.

Trump met with a hand-picked group of conservative media figures at the White House last month and pledged to look at 'all regulatory and legislative solutions' to the situation.

The move could be impacted by the debates over last weekend's mass shootings. Trump called on tech firms to 'develop tools that can detect mass shooters before they strike,' and also blasted violent video games and elements of the culture at large.

A series of shooters, including the El Paso suspect, have used the Internet to broadcast warped manifestos before carrying out their deeds.

Trump this week tore into search giant Google and its CEO Tuesday, touting claims that it worked to undermine his 2016 election and saying he was watching the company 'very closely.'

Trump issued the warning to the tech behemoth amid a legislative push to regulate big tech, and his own repeated claims that forces are arrayed against him in the elections.

He claimed its boss, CEO Sundar Pichai, had groveled to him on how well the administration was performing.

The attack on Google came a day after he blamed social media as one of the reasons for mass shootings, in a speech which also took aim at online forums and the internet as causing a 'culture of violence.'

Trump began his Twitter blasts at the company by claiming its chief executive officer had sought to flatter him, in a likely reference to a meeting held last month at the White House with Pichai and other tech executives.

'@sundarpichai of Google was in the Oval Office working very hard to explain how much he liked me, what a great job the Administration is doing, that Google was not involved with China's military, that they didn't help Crooked Hillary over me in the 2016 Election, and that they...are NOT planning to illegally subvert the 2020 Election despite all that has been said to the contrary,' Trump tweeted.

'It all sounded good until I watched Kevin Cernekee, a Google engineer, say terrible things about what they did in 2016 and that they want to 'Make sure that Trump losses [sic]...in 2020,' Trump continued.

He was referencing a segment on Lou Dobbs' Fox Business Network, which was broadcast Monday, where Cernekee promoted the theory that Google suppressed positive search results on Trump and promoted negative news about him.

He also touted an appearance by 'Clinton cash' author Peter Schweizer.

'@peterschweizer stated with certainty that they suppressed negative stories on Hillary Clinton, and boosted negative stories on Donald Ttump [sic]. All very illegal. We are watching Google very closely!' Trump wrote. The tweet included a typo when it referenced Trump's name.

Cernekee, a former Google engineer, told Dobbs on Monday: 'When President Trump won in 2016, Google executives went up on stage right away and cried, literally tears streaming down their faces over the fact that President Trump won.

'They vowed that it would never happen again, and they want to use all of the power and all the resources that they have to control the flow of information to the public and make sure that Trump loses in 2020.'

Cernekee was fired from Google in 2018. He claims he was subjected to 'bullying' due to his conservative political posture. Google denies his claim.

Hours earlier, Trump had tweeted out a clip of Schweizer telling Dobbs about Google: 'They suppressed negative stories about Hillary Clinton and they boosted negative stories about Donald Trump.'

Schweizer also said that in 2016 Google didn't feel like it had to 'tip the scale all that much' and predicted the firm would go 'all-in' in 2020.

Last year, Trump issued a similar threat, and claimed the firm's search results were 'RIGGED.'

Google issued a statement denying the charge in 2018, which online search experts also have said is untrue.

'Search is not used to set a political agenda and we don't bias our results toward any political ideology,' it said.

'Every year, we issue hundreds of improvements to our algorithms to ensure they surface high-quality content in response to users' queries.

'We continually work to improve Google Search and we never rank search results to manipulate political sentiment.'

The election result did cause upset inside Google. During a company meeting immediately after the election, several execs said they had backed Hillary Clinton but sought to reassure employees.

Said co-founder Sergey Brin at the meeting: 'Myself as an immigrant and a refugee, I certainly find the selection deeply offensive and I know many of you do too ... I think it's a very stressful time and conflicts with many of our values.'

Tensions between Silicon Valley and Trump and the Republican party over what the right claims is anti-conservative bias on Google and social media platforms have been growing.

One pro-Trump senator has brought forward draft legislation which would limit social media companies' ability to produce 'endless scrolls.'

And Republican members of Congress have repeatedly questioned executives on allegations of bias.

They have asked whether Google News results are rigged in favor of liberal outlets, and whether Twitter in particular has selectively censored conservative views.

Trump himself has railed against Twitter, claiming it has made it difficult for users to follow him, although the platform denies that is the case.

In July Trump publicly endorsed a claim by controversial Paypal founder Peter Thiel that Google was working with the Chinese military rather than the U.S. military, which Thiel called 'seemingly treasonous.'

But Trump's Treasruy Secretary Steven Mnuchin walked back that claim, which was made at a conservative conference.

Mnuchin told CNBC: 'We're not aware of any areas where Google is working with the Chinese government that in any way raises concerns.'

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XNS-S751-JBNW-33G0-00000-00White House Faces Bipartisan Pressure Over Big Tech's Legal Shield in USMCA2019-12-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWhite House Faces Bipartisan Pressure Over Big Tech's Legal Shield in USMCABrendan Bordelon

As House Speaker Nancy Pelosi asked her Democratic colleagues to move forward with impeachment proceedings on Thursday morning, Republican Rep. Paul Gosar lashed out on Twitter.

The impeachment hoax makes one thing clear: Democrats will never accept the outcome of the 2016 election, Gosar wrote . I stand with @realDonaldTrump!

The sentiment was typical of Gosar and indeed of most Republican lawmakers as impeachment proceedings drive partisanship on Capitol Hill to new heights.

All that bad blood appears increasingly irrelevant, however, when it comes to sticking it to Silicon Valley.

At the same time Gosar was fuming over impeachment, he was quietly applauding Pelosi s new effort to strip the tech industry s legal-liability protections from the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement.

It s never too late to do the right thing, Gosar said in a statement. Permanently codifying Big Tech's immunity under CDA 230 in the USMCA will constrain Congress' ability to modify the law in the future. When it comes to free speech, free markets, and free elections the stakes are simply too high to cut corners. I urge this particular provision s removal from the USMCA and other future trade agreements.

Gosar isn t the only Trump ally making common cause with Pelosi.

I agree with Speaker Pelosi that they should strip the provision from the deal, said Sen. Ted Cruz. I sent a letter earlier to [U.S. Trade Representative Robert] Lighthizer urging him to delete the provision, and I m very glad Speaker Pelosi is urging him to do the same thing."

It is completely irrelevant to the substance of the USMCA, Cruz later told reporters. It was nothing but a giant gift to big tech that was airdropped into the text of the agreement.

The growing debate over tech regulations on Capitol Hill has already produced an unusual level of bipartisanship. But it s particularly exceptional to watch two of President Trump s strongest congressional supporters back an effort led by his chief antagonist.

TheWall Street Journal first reported on Wednesday that Pelosi was working to remove a provision from the USMCA enshrining big tech s legal-liability protections internationally. The language, modeled off of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, prevents online platforms from being sued for content posted by their users.

Concerned about the proliferation of hateful, violent, and illegal content online and in some cases, worried about the perceived liberal bias of Silicon Valley lawmakers have spent well over a year mulling serious changes to Section 230.

Given the ongoing debate, leadership in both parties now agree that adding similar liability language to future trade agreements is unacceptable. And they haven t been shy in making their displeasure known.

I am troubled that the U.S. Trade Rep has continued to insert this ... at a time when Republicans and Democrats are raising serious questions about how Section 230 has been interpreted by the courts, said House Energy and Commerce ranking member Greg Walden.

In August, Walden joined Energy and Commerce Chairman Frank Pallone in a letter urging Lighthizer not to include similar language in future trade agreements.

Walden was frustrated when the language was nevertheless included in an agreement with Japan and even more frustrated now that, months later, he finds himself still waiting on a response from Lighthizer.

I m talking directly to the White House about it now, Walden said.

As a supporter of the USMCA more broadly, Walden wouldn t go as far as some of his fellow Republicans in supporting Pelosi s effort.

I don t want to upend USMCA, he said. I respect Speaker Pelosi weighing in I get that and there are a lot of us frustrated. But the best we can do on USMCA is get the changes that have been negotiated done and voted.

That puts Walden in opposition with Pallone, his erstwhile ally on the issue, who enthusiastically endorsed Pelosi s effort on Thursday.

I think they should take the language out, Pallone told reporters. I ve said it repeatedly.

Even Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna of California, an occasional ally of the tech industry and a rare congressional supporter of Section 230, said he d defer to Pelosi.

We need to protect Section 230 for the United States, but we shouldn t be imposing it on other countries, Khanna said.

The burgeoning bipartisan opposition to the export of Section 230 and the increasing skepticism of the provision s impact inside the United States has surprised some experts.

The consensus regarding [tech] firms as non-publishers has dissipated so rapidly, it s shocking, said Susan Aaronson, director of the Digital Trade and Data Governance Hub at George Washington University.

Experts in international trade say Pelosi s effort to remove tech s legal shield from the USMCA shouldn t be a huge logistical challenge. Though Mexico has already signed the agreement, they say any changes can be resolved through side letters or amendments.

But those experts also say Walden s fear is likely justified that a successful attempt to remove Section 230 language will make it much tougher for the USMCA to pass the House.

It s not just a nail it s a spike in the coffin of the USMCA, said Gary Hufbauer, a trade expert at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former Treasury official. As I see it, the platforms would lobby very heavily against the USMCA if this was ripped out.

While tech lobbyists seemed momentarily stunned by news of Pelosi s effort, by Thursday afternoon they had begun to coordinate a response.

Failing to include intermediary liability protections which have been a part of U.S. law for two decades in USMCA would negatively impact the countless small businesses and entrepreneurs that use online platforms to export and advertise their businesses, Michael Beckerman, president and CEO of the Internet Association, said in a statement.

Despite their diminished political clout, Hufbauer expects the tech platforms will fight tooth-and-nail to keep the language in the agreement.

They would see this as the camel s nose in the door for opening up legal liability in the U.S., in Europe, and elsewhere, he said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T4S-KX71-JCDN-140X-00000-00White House investigating Google after Trump accuses it of bias2018-08-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:57ZLexisNexisWORLDWhite House investigating Googleafter Trump accuses it of bias

WASHINGTON: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday accused Google's search engine of promoting negative news articles and hiding "fair media" coverage of him, vowing to address the situation without providing evidence or giving details of action he might take. Trump's attack against the Alphabet Incunit follows a string of grievances against technology companies, including social media Twitter Incand Facebook Inc , which he has accused of silencing conservative voices, and Amazon.com Inc , which he has said is hurting small businesses and benefiting from a favourable deal with the U.S. Postal Services. He frequently berates news outlets for what he perceives as unfair coverage. Googledenied any political bias, saying in a statement that its search engine is "not used to set a political agenda and we don't bias our results towards any political ideology."

Trump said in several tweets on Tuesday that Googlesearch results for "Trump News" were "rigged" against him because they showed only coverage from outlets like CNN and not conservative publications, suggesting the practice was illegal. "I think Googleis really taking advantage of our people," Trump said on Tuesday in the Oval Office. "Google, and Twitter and Facebook, they are really treading on very, very troubled territory, and they have to be careful. It's not fair to large portions of the population." Facebookdeclined to comment. Twitter did not comment when asked for a response. In congressional testimony, both companies have denied engaging in partisan censorship. Neither Trump nor the White House detailed how or under what legal justification they would use to probe Google. Trump's economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, later told reporters that the White House was "taking a look" at Google, saying the administration would do "some investigation and some analysis," without providing further details. Earlier this summer, the new Republican chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Joseph Simons, said the agency would keep a close eye on big tech companies that dominate the internet. In a previous investigation, the FTC decided that Googlewas likely justified in developing a search function that harmed other companies. Congressional sources cautioned that it may be difficult for Trump to find a way to probe Googleabout news search results, and that Congress is unlikely to pass any applicable laws. The Federal Communications Commission ceded jurisdiction over regulating online communications when it repealed its net neutrality rules. U.S. member of CongressTed Lieu, a Democrat, said in a tweet directed at Trump that such restrictions on Googlewould violate the U.S. Constitution: "If government tried to dictate the free speech algorithms of private companies, courts would strike it down in a nanosecond." Shares of Alphabet fell 0.8 percent to US$1,245.86. TRUMP'S CRITICISM OF MEDIA While the exact science behind Googlesearches on the internet is kept secret, its basic principles are widely known to be generated with a variety of factors measured by the company's algorithms. The factors Googleuses to determine which websites appear first in search results include how often that page is linked to on other sites, the use of keywords, the popularity and respectability of the news site, and personal browsing history of the person conducting the search. Highly trafficked and cited websites like CNN.com and NYTimes.com, two of the most Trump's most frequent targets, often appear first in search results. Trump's accusation of bias on the part of Googlecomes as social media companies have suspended accounts, banned certain users and removed content as they face pressure from the U.S. Congress to police foreign propaganda and fake accounts aimed at disrupting American politics, including operations tied to Iran and Russia. Companies such as Facebookand Twitter have also been pressed to remove conspiracy driven content and hate speech. Tech companies have said they do not remove content for political reasons. Some Republican U.S. lawmakers have also raised concerns about social media companies removing content from some conservatives, and have called Twitter's chief executive to testify before a House of Representatives panel on Sept. 5. Earlier this month, Alphabet's YouTube joined Apple Inc and Facebookin removing some content from Infowars, a website run by conspiracy theorist Alex Jones. Jones was also temporarily suspended on Twitter. (Reporting by Susan Heavey; Additional reporting by Ken Li in New York and Chris Sanders in Washington; Editing by Frances Kerry and Richard Chang) - Reuters
